image.caption: Intelligent conversation ... Madonna

article.caption: Be the first to hear Madonna's new album
Madonna has a buff time in her new video
Madonna rolls back the years on new album

articles.articlebody:
CALLING Madonna and interrupting her son's French lesson sounds like a recipe for an uncomfortable half an hour on the phone.

A mum of four's time is precious, especially when she has an album to finish and a gruelling tour to play for.

But the Queen of Pop couldn't have been more enthusiastic and open about her 12th studio album MDNA  which might have something to do with the great reviews it has already received.

It's out on Monday but you can hear it first and free here.

In October of this year Madonna will celebrate the 30th anniversary of the release of her first single Everybody.

Since then she has toured the world nine times, won countless awards and scored ten No1 solo albums.

But the singer, 53, still finds the presentation of new material a nerve-racking experience.

Speaking exclusively to SFTW, she said: "I don't think presenting any of my work is less nerve-racking than it ever was because I put my heart and soul into something.

"Whether it's on a film or my record, it's something to work on in privacy and create in a kind of bubble and then put it out in the world.

"You never know how people are going to receive it, whether it's going to move them or inspire them. The world is so full of entertainment now, isn't it? So there are a lot of nerves.

"It's amazing to be back in music. I like the intimacy of a recording studio and song-writing. I'm using a different part of my brain when I work on music versus when I'm directing a film.

"There are a billion more people on a film and I don't have that visceral outlet of being able to sing, scream... jump around.

"It's very different. I love doing both but it was nice to have the simplicity of song-writing after three years of writing a script and directing and editing and talking about my film, to sit down and play my guitar and sing a song. I almost cried."

Her last studio album, Hard Candy in May 2008, experimented with a hip-hop influence. She collaborated with Justin Timberlake, Pharrell Williams and Timbaland.

The album reached No1 around the world but received a lukewarm reception from some fans and critics.

MDNA, a "triple entendre" as she describes it, is a return to what she does best: classic pop songs with a sprinkling of trademark controversy.

And it is down to the return of her winning formula: working with top European producers.

Stuart Price produced some of her best original material on Confessions On A Dancefloor back in 2005. She also made some great material with French electronic guru Mirwais.

But her return to the studio with producer William Orbit, who made Ray Of Light back in 1998, is a master stroke.

The tracks they have made together on the new album, including Gang Bang and Some Girls, slot into her discography perfectly.

She has also employed the skills of Martin Solveig, Italian DJ Benny Benassi and his cousin Allessandro.

And Madonna believes her return to Europe for her producing partners is no coincidence.

She explained: "I think maybe I just have more of a European sensibility. People say that about my songs as well. I like working with people who are well-read and know what's going on in the world.

"Conversation is essential. With William, we always get into discussions about philosophy or quantum physics.

"With Martin Solveig we always end up getting in to discussions about foreign films. When I'm working with people I can't just write music, I have to be able to talk about life and the world, and art. Benny was a tricky one because he doesn't speak English very well.

"I ended up kind of using his cousin Allessandro as an interpreter.

"It was a little bit frustrating at first but eventually we found a way to communicate. You figure out a way. With music it's so much about the vibe and the energy and you know when things are working and when they're not.

"When you're working with someone for the first time, there's a kind of shyness that everybody has, so with Benny it was more challenging because of that but we figured it out and by the end I felt like I knew him very well.

"Martin is such good fun, I adore him. You have to feel like you can say 'No, I don't like that,' and you're not going to hurt their feelings. And vice versa.

"But he's got just the right balance of seriousness and humour.

"He's very organised and methodical in his thinking so I like his work process."

The production on the album is slick, with some great touches.

On Gang Bang the noise of a spent cartridge from a gun hitting a concrete floor illustrates her "Kill Bill" fantasy for the track.

But the contrast of a huge pop track like Superstar, featuring her daughter Lourdes on backing vocals, is followed up with a song called Falling Free  one of her most stripped-back songs for years. She explained: "I have to be completely involved in the production. I like the contrast.

"I like to have something that is just slammed with noise and sound and bass and drum, sensory overload and then create something like Falling Free, which is stripped back and all you can really hear is my voice and the lyrics.

"Sometimes I sit down on a guitar and start strumming chords and things come out.

"Sometimes people bring a song to me that has a title, for instance, or an idea of a lyric and I take it and kind of re-shape it, re-word it and make it my own. It comes in so many different ways, it's always been that way."

The album features some big collaborations with strong female solo stars  M.I.A and rapper Nicki Minaj. Give Me All Your Luvin' was the Superbowl song that ended up causing controversy when M.I.A decided to stick up her middle fin ger.

But that punk spirit is exactly why she got them on board.

She said: "I was looking to collaborate with women who I think have a strong sense of themselves.

"They were a lot of fun to be around in the studio, for sure.

"I think we were all shy of each other in the beginning, that's just human nature.

"I think we got over that pretty quickly.

"They're both very self-possessed people, especially M.I.A. I don't think she's impressed much by stars and celebrities, so we just got down to business. I loved her."

And the key to keeping the music original? Don't listen to chart music while you are writing.

She said: "I wasn't listening to anything to tell you the truth, when I wrote this.

"I was working on the soundtrack to my movie W.E. So just classical music. I actually don't like listening to pop music while I'm working on pop music  it doesn't really work.

"You don't want to hear other people's stuff, you need a clean slate to work off."
articles.teaser: TIME is precious for the mum of four  she has an album and tour to finish
articles.headline: Madonna: I like to work with people who talk about philosophy or quantum physics
articles.subdeck: Intelligent conversation ... Madonna

image.caption: Turning the tables ... axed Cheryl goes from TV judging panel to movie role

video.caption: STAR grabs limelight in trailer for What To Expect When You're Expecting

articles.articlebody:
CHERYL Cole dances on a table in a spoof of her old show, The X Factor.

The Geordie star attempts to upstage Cameron Diaz in a teaser for her first Hollywood movie, What to Expect When You're Expecting.

In the flick she plays a judge on cheesy talent show Celebrity Dance Factor.

The clip also shows the Girls Aloud singer throwing a drink in the face of fellow judge, Black Eyed Peas star Taboo.

And Cameron shows off an incredibly toned midriff in a fringed red bikini, Strictly Come Dancing style.

Cheryl was axed from the American version of The X Factor after a few weeks of filming in May 2011.

And boss Simon Cowell recently admitted he had "crossed the line" when he sacked his former pal from the judging panel.

He said: "I know when I've crossed the line a little bit. I thought there was going to be a big reaction. I wasn't prepared for what was coming next.

"I had to apologise for the way it was handled."

The film, which also stars Jennifer Lopez, Anna Kendrick and Chace Crawford, is based on the bestselling pregnancy guide and follows five couples as they prepare to have their first child.

It marks a film debut for the 28-year-old singer which may lead to more calls from Hollywood.
articles.teaser: SINGER dances on judges' desk in teaser for first movie What to Expect When You're Expecting
articles.headline: Cheryl Cole stars in X Factor spoof
articles.subdeck: Turning the tables ... axed Cheryl goes from TV judging panel to movie role

image.caption: CPR ... Vinnie Jones

article.caption: Footie legend Sir Geoff Hurst answers your questions
Megan Fox goes in search of Crystal
Vinnie Jones is in a spinnie

articles.articlebody:
IT'S just as well Vinnie Jones learned CPR during his ad campaign for the British Heart Foundation.

The former Crazy Gang star has just signed up for the biggest gig of his career, starring alongside Hollywood legends Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone.

With the screen veterans throwing themselves around on another action movie in their senior years, Big Vinnie will need to keep and eye on their tickers. Last night Vinnie told me: "Start filming April 19 in New Orleans. Biggest blockbuster of next summer  $120million budget (£80million).

"It's about three cons in prison looking to bust out.

"Come on Sweaty!"

Sly, Arnie and Vinnie  that should make for an entertaining time on set.
articles.teaser: KNOWING how to do CPR may come in handy as he's starring with two veterans
articles.headline: Vin's in heart of the action

image.caption: Confession ... Usher revealed to fans he will play Sugar Ray Leonard, right, in Hands Of Stone

article.caption: Lana Del Rey teams up with Cheryl Cole for song
Justin Bieber in continents shame
Usher welcomes his second son
Sexy Usher is Daddy Cool

articles.articlebody:
USHER is to play boxing legend Sugar Ray Leonard in a new film.

The singer will be in Hands Of Stone, the story of fighter Roberto Duran  played by Gael Garcia Bernal.

Usher said: "I'm in preparation for an incredible role. If you guys see me running around London, that's what it is.

"If you see me in the corners boxing, I'm doing that while working on this album."

In one of the most famous boxing matches of all time, Duran quit in round eight telling the referee 'No mas, no mas', meaning 'no more'.

Leonard took the WBC Welterweight crown and said: "To make a man quit, to make a Roberto Duran quit, was better than knocking him out."
articles.teaser: SINGER Usher is to play the boxing legend in new movie about fighter Roberto Duran
articles.headline: Usher's sweet movie role as Sugar Ray Leonard
articles.subdeck: Confession ... Usher revealed to fans he will play Sugar Ray Leonard, right, in Hands Of Stone

image.caption: Honeytrapper ... Mundill Mahil smirks as she arrives at the Old Bailey

article.caption: 'Revenge killing' of TV boss
Our son was drugged and murdered for £150 a few hours after this holiday snap... now we want justice

articles.articlebody:
STANDING in front of the shrine to her murdered brother, Amandip is distraught and angry  and feels betrayed.

TV boss Gagandip Singh was just 21 when he was lured to his death in a honeytrap  viciously beaten and burned alive in the boot of a Mercedes car.

Amandip, 19, a business studies student, said: "My mother and I are haunted by the way Gagandip was murdered. We saw his horrifically burned body and we cannot get that image out of our minds."

Medical student Mundill Mahil, 20, was jailed last month for six years for GBH with intent. Harvinder Shoker, also 20, got life for murder, while 20-year-old Darren Peters was jailed for 12 years for manslaughter.

Now, Amandip and her mum Tajinder have asked the Attorney General to review the sentence handed to Mahil and set up an e-petition, Justice For Gagandip.

Speaking out for the first time, Amandip added: "He would not have been murdered if Mundill Mahil hadn't lured him to her flat in Brighton in a carefully orchestrated honeytrap.

"Mahil will be released for good behaviour in three years. It's outrageous. Other cases involving money and fraud get much more punishment. Gagandip's life has been taken. I believe something more needs to be done."

Gagandip's body was found in the burning car in Blackheath, south-east London, in February last year.

He had been violently attacked in Brighton before being driven back to the capital and murdered.

A post-mortem examination revealed he was still alive when the fire in the car was started.

It was the second tragedy for the family in just 18 months. In September 2009 Gagandip's father Charanjit was murdered in India. Eight people are on trial there accused of being involved.

Gagandip took over his dad's packaging firm and also started the Sikh TV channel on Sky.

Amandip said: "We were only just starting to come to terms with the first murder when Gagan was killed. It has knocked the life out of me and Mum."

The court heard that Mahil, from Chatham, Kent, had been Gagandip's girlfriend. He was in love but they split up in August 2010 after she alleged he had sexually assaulted her.

Shoker, his friend of five years, also fell in love with Mahil and decided to take revenge on the businessman.

In February last year she lured Gagandip to her house in Brighton.

She knew that Shoker and Peters, both from London, would be lying in wait for him.

He was beaten unconscious and bundled into the boot of the car.

Amandip said: "I only met Mahil once, when Gagandip brought her to our home. She was very pretty and confident and seemed a nice person.

"My brother and I were very close and were both living at home and saw each other every day.

"He became very close to her and said she was a friend he trusted and who he could talk to about anything.

"Look at how she betrayed his trust. She tried to destroy my brother's character in court.

"But he was a kind, generous man who would have done anything to help anyone."

Detective Superintendent Damian Allain, who investigated the case, said after the conviction: "Throughout the investigation and trial Mahil portrayed herself as a victim.

"It is clear to me, now endorsed by the jury's verdict, that her actions were calculating and that she was at the heart of a criminal conspiracy with Shoker and Peters of tricking Gagandip to Brighton to seriously assault him, which resulted in his death."

The family say Gagandip had the world at his feet.

Amandip said: "He ran the family's successful employment agency and packaging business. He also set up and headed Sikh TV.

"In addition, he was the founder of the British Sikh Student Federation. He had made friends and contacts all around the world."

His mother Tajinder, 45, was equally proud of his achievements.

She said: "He had done so much. I didn't think a 21-year-old would be capable of so much.

"I'm amazed how much he achieved. Never a day goes by when we don't think about him.

"I am devastated by my son's killing and struggling to cope. In my life there's only a dead end.

"There's nothing left ahead. The whole story has finished here."

She now runs the family business, which employs 300 people. But with the emotional turmoil of losing her son she found it almost impossible to carry on with it.

She said: "When I first learned of Gagandip's death I was completely and utterly broken.

"I could barely function on a day-to-day basis and stumbled through each day not really knowing what was going on. I do not have the support of a husband because he also died not so long before Gagan.

"I cannot describe on an average day my life since Gagandip's death because they have all blended into one.

"In the early stages I couldn't hold a conversation without breaking down in tears and there were occasions when the police had to call an ambulance for me after I collapsed."

Cherished pictures from the family photo album show what a loving son and brother Gagandip was.

There was also a picture of him at his 21st birthday party with killer Shoker.

Amandip said: "Shoker turned up uninvited to the party.

"We knew things weren't right between Gagandip and Shoker by that stage. The photo of them together is so ironic as they look like the best of friends  and for over five years they were.

"I'm sickened by the thought that the man who holds his hand lovingly over my brother's heart in the photo is the same person who later beat him so terribly then burned him alive.

"He spent so much time around at our house that he practically lived here.

"What he did is such a terrible betrayal of trust."

Gagandip was cremated and his ashes scattered in a river at the Kiratpur Sahib temple in the Punjab, India.

Like her mother, Amandip broke down when she remembered the precious times they had together.

She said: "I found it hard to go into his bedroom without getting very upset."

Now, though, they remember him with the shrine in the garden and in his former bedroom in south east London.

Amandip said: "Mum and I actually slept in his room as a way of trying to feel closer to him.

"Now we have turned his bedroom into a shrine, with a large photo of him on the bed and all his clothes and possessions are still in the room."

Gagandip's mum and sister are still clearly in pain over his loss  but their grief would be easier to bear if they felt justice had been done.

Additional reporting: MARK CHRISTY

image.caption: Tears for her hero ... Christina Schmid recalls fateful day her husband Staff Sergeant Olaf died

article.caption: Commanding officer's tribute to 'six of our fallen brothers'
Christina Schmid: I had second miscarriage before Oz was killed
Hero's widow receives medal
Brave soldier's funeral held
Hero dies in blast on his last day

articles.articlebody:
WAR widow Christina Schmid read her hero husband's Tarot cards before his fateful tour  with nightmare results.

The burning Tower card, seen as the harbinger of doom, repeatedly cropped up.

It was one of a host of spooky premonitions she had both before and during hubby Oz's fatal five-month mission to the Afghanistan front line, where he defused 70 Taliban bombs.

Today Christina tells of the dreadful day he begged her to read his future  and the moment she saw his destruction in the cards.

In her own words, taken from her memoir about Staff Sergeant Olaf "Oz" Schmid, Always By My Side, she writes: "Oz asked me to do his Tarot cards.

"The Tarot was something I did very rarely, perhaps once every other year. I wasn't sure about doing it this time, but Oz urged me to and I agreed.

"I had done them since I was young and I seemed to be gifted. The card he chose to show the future was the Burning Tower. I did them again, this time for career, Oz chose the Burning Tower again. The worst card there is.

"It signifies death and endings, the worst outcome imaginable and entirely unavoidable. Everything you know gone in ruin or catastrophe.

Oz looked stricken. He said, 'I feel this is going to be a really bad year for me. I've got this feeling as if everything is slipping'.

"I tried to lighten it, saying, 'You'll probably just stub your toe when you're at work  you're always a screamer with loads of bad luck! Don't worry, it might just mean that you won't get a promotion or something'.

"'No', he said. 'It's not the card. That just confirmed what I already know and feel'.

"When it was my turn to choose a card I hoped I might get something that would lift the mood, but I was startled when I got it in my spread of cards, too.

"But then I got rebirth after, and the moon. 'See, hun  always light in the dark. Remember that', he said. I tried to hide my dismay. 'It's a dark time of year. Perhaps we're both just feeling it', I said.

" 'Let's be positive, forget the cards, we've got lots to look forward to', I chirped, waiting for him to follow my lead.

"He usually did, but this time Oz said, 'No, it's bad. I've got this feeling that if I go out after January or February, I'm not coming back. That's what my gut is telling me'. There was nothing I could say that would cheer him and the truth was it was hard even to try, because I felt worried too."

Despite the omen, devoted Christina put aside her foreboding when Oz was sent to the front.

During his dangerous deployment she would make a wish for his protection during the full moon.

But on the last full moon before Oz's return she inexplicably fell asleep with young son Laird and missed her routine.

She writes: "I woke around 4am, disorientated. I was fully clothed and Laird was asleep on me, in his pyjamas. As the realisation dawned that I had missed doing the wish for Oz, the moon had disappeared and I felt distraught.

" 'Oh my God, what have I done?' I whispered. 'I've done it every month. Why now?'

"I told myself it didn't matter, that it was just a bit of silly tradition, that I should forget it. But I couldn't."

Christina's foreboding grew to fever pitch shortly before Oz, who won a gallantry gong on his tour, was due home.

The spooky signs grew to the point where she says she KNEW he was dead even before the fateful news came with a knock on the door from two officers bringing confirmation.

She writes: "Two days before he was due to leave Afghanistan for home, Oz called again. I could hear immediately that he was low.

"He had been out of contact for several days and he sounded shattered. He said, 'Honey, I just feel really bad, I've got this odd feeling, like dread, I don't feel safe, it's bad. Have you got it too?' I had. In the pit of my stomach I felt a lurch as he spoke.

"I had been uneasy, anxious, and had a feeling of dread, but I didn't want to say that.

'You're tired,' I said. 'It's OK, you'll be back soon. Do what you did the last few months in the next couple of days, hun. You've got 48 hours left, that's all'.

" 'Honey', he said, 'I'm mentally and spiritually hammered, I'm hanging out. I've been away too long, worked too much.

" 'And if it's too much for me it's too much for anyone. But I can't let it show. I've got to keep positive and strong, they (the other men) have to trust me. If anything happens to me, I don't want them to blame themselves.

" 'I wish you could come and get me. I need you. Just come and get me now, honey'.

" 'I wish I could', I said, tears running down my face. 'But I can't. You've got to stop talking like this, you're just tired. You can push for 48 hours'. 'I need to speak to Laird,' he said. I handed Laird the phone and he went upstairs and they talked.

"When Laird gave the phone back, Oz said, 'I'm calm, honey, but I can't help how I feel. I don't think I'm coming back, 'cos I'm cuffing it now. I'm drained  it's hard to explain'.

"The next day I kept the phone beside me all evening, hoping he'd ring. I wanted to ring him but I couldn't, so that night I emailed  'Please email me, Don't go out on the ground tomorrow, cut the last day, don't do it.' He never got it."

That night Christina had a visitation in her dreams from another hero bomb hunter, Warrant Officer Gary "Gaz" O'Donnell, who had perished in the Afghan badlands disarming a Taliban device.

She writes: "I slept fitfully then I dreamed that Gaz O'Donnell was standing in front of me. 'Don't worry, Chris, I'm here to get him when he comes over,' he said. 'I'll hold him. I won't let go'.

" 'What are you on about?' I said. 'You've got no arms'. Gaz just looked at me and smiled.

"The next morning, Saturday October 31, 2009, I woke at 6.30am with a feeling I'd never had before. It was as powerful as thunder.

" 'It's today', I thought. 'He's going or has he gone yet?' I felt it so surely that it was in the floor beneath my feet as I got out of bed and in the air around me as I went downstairs.

"I felt numb, suspended in time, as I went through the motions of life. At nine I phoned my mum and told her I wasn't going to take Laird to his swimming lesson that morning. 'What's going on?' she said. 'You sound so quiet. Oz is home tomorrow, you should be happy'.

"I paused. 'He's not coming home, Mum, I know it'. "

Oz was killed, defusing a bomb, on Halloween while Christina was walking in the woods gathering her thoughts.

At the exact moment he died she wept uncontrollably.

Later in her book Christina reveals more spiritual happenings. She tells how Oz's spirit communicated with her through the spiritualist mum of a friend.

She writes what the spiritualist said: "He's saying, 'Coffee, white, one  man-up'. Oh, and what an awful taste, it's something like liquorice. What is that?' I smiled. 'His liquorice rollies, the menthol tips, he always smoked them. And that's how he talked'. She had his intonation exactly right.

"She always passes on an Oz message in his distinctive style.

"And it helps me to keep going and keeps me grounded."

d.willetts@the-sun.co.uk

Always By My Side, by Christina Schmid, is published by Century, £12.99. © Christina Schmid 2012. To buy your copy from the Sun Bookshop for just £10.99, with free p&p, call 0845 271 2136.

articles.headline: War widow predicted death

article.caption: Fabrice Muamba's family give thanks to fans
Fabrice Muamba was 'dead' for 78 minutes
Fabrice Muamba asks: Did we lose?

articles.articlebody:
ONE of the world's most respected doctors and scientists is backing The Sun's campaign for all schoolchildren to be taught basic life-saving skills.

Here, he tells us why even more Sun readers should add their names to our petition.

I HAVE resuscitated collapsed colleagues on five separate occasions in the House of Lords.

This was always after they had just completed a speech.

Speaking in that frightening chamber is very stressful.

It is filled with people with extraordinary expertise.

Someone listening will always seem to know more about the subject than the person speaking.

So when a peer gets up to speak, his or her pulse rate frequently rises dramatically.

I am willing to bet that their blood pressure also rises by around 30 per cent.

To sign The Sun-backed British Heart Foundation petition, click here

So it isn't surprising that, when finished, some members simply keel over. Sometimes they literally just faint. But occasionally, they have a cardiac arrest.

As one of a few doctors there when I joined the Lords 17 years ago, I was appalled how poor were the arrangements for these sudden, terrifying emergencies.

The attendant staff had often been trained in mouth-to-mouth and cardiac resuscitation, but there was no defibrillator anywhere in Parliament. This piece of kit is a life-saver.

When its electrodes are applied across the chest, its sudden pulse of high voltage electricity can jolt the heart back into a normal rhythmic beat. It's a clever device because its detector only allows an electric shock if the collapsed patient has had a cardiac arrest or a fatal change of heart rhythm.

So it is safe and exceptionally easy to use by any layman with minimal training.

Yet when I tried to persuade the authorities in Parliament to obtain one of these portable machines (they are not expensive) officials in both Houses refused. Their excuses were shameful.

One official argued that we could not have a defibrillator as it would cause a problem if a tourist collapsed in the gallery  should we be obliged to offer resuscitation to a member of the public? It was suggested there might be legal consequences if it were used or not used. Four years later, an elderly peer collapsed right after speaking. There were no doctors present in the chamber and he died.

Only then, reluctantly, was a defibrillator installed, and since then at least two lives have been saved. Cardiac arrest is extremely common yet it can be correctable. Clearly, it would help if everybody were trained in external cardiac massage, for example in schools. This knowledge would save some lives.

But a clever defibrillator is a different matter. It is astonishing that so many public buildings do not have them readily available.

Those first few seconds after a cardiac emergency are critical and we must be prepared.

To sign The Sun-backed British Heart Foundation petition, click here

articles.headline: CPR helped me save lives. Everyone should learn it

article.caption: My 8-year takeaway binge cost £25k...and my unborn baby's life
You wouldn't eat 13 teaspoons of sugar in one go... so why drink it?
The Beast: Britain's biggest beef burger
Man's waist measures more than his height
'I'm the world's worst yo-yo dieter'

articles.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity.

The number of calories in certain products made by soft drinks giant Coca-Cola will be cut by 30 per cent by 2014.

It will also pump more cash into marketing Diet Coke and Coca-Cola Zero, which contain no sugar, and increase their availability.

Mars bars will be cut from 300 calories to 250, and super-size "Grab Bags" of Walkers crisps, containing 263 calories, will be phased out and replaced with 185-calorie packs.

The move aims to take FIVE BILLION calories a day off Britain's national food and drink intake. More than two-thirds of adults and one in three 11-year-olds are now overweight or obese. Food manufacturers, supermarkets, pubs and caterers joined with the Department of Health yesterday to announce the "Responsibility Deal".

Producers including Hovis and Mr Kipling will slash calorie counts by 30 per cent across a third of their ranges.

Supermarkets will expand their healthy meal ranges and sandwich chain Subway will include five low-fat subs in its £3 lunch offer. Health Secretary Andrew Lansley hailed the plan as "a great step in the right direction," adding: "We all have a role to play."

Diet expert Dr Susan Jebb, of Cambridge University, said: "This programme is vital to tackle obesity. It's a very encouraging start, but it will take time to change the nation's eating habits."

e.little@the-sun.co.uk
articles.byline: By EMMA LITTLE, Health Editor and DANIEL JONES, Consumer Editor

image.caption: 'I have a walk to make them bounce to show they're real' ... Stephanie Fox has 32K boobs

article.caption: Model with 38KKK boobs is saved by airbags
I was terrified my PIP implants were a ticking timebomb. I just wanted them out
'I'm proud to be UK average size 16. And I'll never yo-yo again'
How to drive Men Mad

articles.articlebody:
STEPHANIE FOX has something she'd like to get off her chest... her back-breaking, all-natural, size 32K boobs are casting a shadow over her life.

The 21-year-old can't get a boyfriend, can't find clothes to fit and can't even walk down the street without getting an earful of abuse.

Men don't look her in the eye. Girls assume she is a porn star. Then there's the back pain.

She says: "Lots of women want big boobs but it's actually a total nightmare.

"The only men I attract are the sleazy type. It's rare that a guy looks me in the face when talking to me.

"Guys will flat-out stare and try all the cheesy chat-up lines. And a lot of the time they want their picture taken with them. Not me  them."

She adds: "Sometimes it can be a bit scary. A few blokes will try to get really hands-on. When I'm out with my male friends they'll usually circle round me. They're my bodyguards."

Stephanie doesn't fare much better with other girls. She says: "Women assume my boobs are fake  they look at me like I'm a porn star. It's older women who always comment on them.

"They'll tut and shake their heads as they walk past me in the street. I can hear them saying, 'They're so fake', and, 'Look at her flaunting them'.

"I try to smile through it. I know they're real but sometimes it can be hurtful.

"I've developed a way of walking so my boobs bounce up and down and people can see they're real. It looks like I'm walking on the moon.

"Women can get quite jealous  that's probably why I have more male friends."

But meeting the right guy is difficult. Glasgow girl Stephanie says: "I broke up with my ex in 2010. He couldn't handle all the attention I get and became insanely jealous.

"When we were out he'd get mad when other guys checked me out. I tried telling him it couldn't be helped  he knew what he was getting into."

Stephanie has seen a few men since the split but no one special has caught her eye.

She says: "They become too obsessed with my boobs, it's all they think about. It's hard to find a guy to see past them.

"A lot of blokes are just after me for the status of it, they see it as just another notch on the bedpost.

"I want my boyfriend to see me for me, I'm more than just a pair of boobs. I'm a laid back and a down-to-earth girl and I love to have a laugh." Stephanie's boobs proved something of an overnight sensation when she was just 12.

She recalls: "It was so weird. I was a total cheeseboard then one day I woke up with a C cup. It was really annoying because I loved PE and sport.

"I was really into hurdles and running but my boobs started to restrict me. And as I got bigger, it was harder to find a sports bra."

During one family holiday in America Stephanie and her mum Josie, 51, went in search of one that would fit.

She recalls: "We tried this lingerie shop to get a measurement. I was 19 and about a 30J at that point.

"The staff couldn't believe it. Instead of measuring me they just kept calling more and more staff members out of the back to stare at them."

Stephanie adds: "Finding a bikini is atrocious. Nothing fits me so I have to buy separates. "I'll buy a size 12 for my lower half and a 20 for my top half  but even that's too small and they'll be spilling out all over the place. I also get serious back pain.

"Exercise is a nightmare. To do any exercise I have to wear a bra then a sports bra on top.

"I'll go to my local gym and I just get stared at. Gym clothes are quite tight so the guys will full-on stare."

Stephanie doesn't know how she got her huge boobs  though there is something in her family genes.

She says: "My mum does have big boobs but she's probably more of a DD or an E. But my sister Morena has normal-sized breasts.

"Whenever I visit her she'll say, 'God, Stephanie, can you give me some of your boobs!'"

She adds: "I think my dad and older brothers found it awkward when I blossomed. They didn't like men checking me out on the beach. We went on holiday to Italy last year. We went to a water park and I was getting a lot of male attention. Wives were whacking their husbands over the head for staring."

Stephanie works in her parents' fancy dress shop, where she is able to stitch her clothes to fit. She says: "If I don't adjust tops they swamp me or I just look huge. So I've become quite the seamstress."

As for the future, Stephanie plans to start her own business and says: "I know it sounds weird but I'd love to run my own corn on the cob stall.

"I saw a stall selling sweetcorn when I was 15 and ever since, that's what I've wanted to do. You can have butter and pepper on it and things like that  it would be pretty cool."

And despite all the aggro she gets over her shape, on balance she wouldn't want to downsize.

She says: "A part of me loves the attention. They're a great talking point and I get to meet a lot of people. But the downsides probably outweigh that one positive.

"And even the attention can be a double-edged sword. Some days I just don't want to be stared at."

myView

By CAROL COOPER, Sun Doctor

ABNORMALLY large breasts can cause a number of problems, mostly due to the sheer weight. They change the way a woman stands, increasing the curvature of the spine and putting extra strain on it.

This makes back and neck pain common. It can be even worse if the woman has to lift anything heavy.

Shoulders can also suffer, with bra straps causing deep grooves from the weight they support. Nerve pain down the arm can occur, sometimes with tingling in the fingers.

Sweating under the breasts is inevitable, so dermatitis and infections are common, with ulceration in bad cases.

Exercise is tricky. Some women wear two bras at once but it is hard to stop breast discomfort.

Adverse comments can make the woman feel very ill at ease and some become stressed and even depressed.

a.jones@the-sun.co.uk

articles.headline: My natural 32K boobs are a nightmare...only sleazy blokes chat me up while girls tut and assume I'm a porn star

image.caption: Driven ... Karren Brady the glamorous businesswoman

article.caption: The Apprentice unveiled
Karren: I'm hired
Apprentice teens 'top the adults'

articles.articlebody:
APPRENTICE star and Sun columnist Karren Brady is the no-nonsense football boss who has become one of Lord Sugar's key TV advisers.

A workaholic, she became the UK's youngest managing director of a public limited company at 23, at Birmingham City FC. She is now vice-chairman at West Ham.

Karren has two kids with hubby, former player Paul Peschisolido.

Here, in extracts from her inspiring new book, Strong Woman: Ambition, Grit And A Great Pair Of Heels, Karren, 42, offers some hilarious anecdotes.

I HAVE a desire for independence, the need for control  or what others call sheer bloody-mindedness.

But recently I've had to dwell on why I became who I am. I don't reflect on such things easily because I've never been an emotional person. I'm logic personified.

Looking back over my life, I tried to work out how and where the desire for independence began to make itself felt.

Among my earliest memories was when I was three and my mum Rita and nan Nina left me at home one day with my grandfather, Gerald, while they went shopping.

I remember my mum and dad, Terry, had this elegant drinks cabinet in the lounge. As a toddler I was fascinated by it.

The door folded down and all these beautiful little glasses and different-coloured bottles glinted away in the backlight.

I decided to get a chair, climb up and have a good look. Everything looked even better close up.

The dainty little glasses (for sherry), the perfect size for me, were so tempting that I started to fill them with the green, yellow and clear liquids I saw in the bottles  crème de menthe, advocaat and vodka.

Taking little sips and inviting my dolls to do the same, I was having a wonderful time  until my grandfather came into the room and asked what I was doing.

Of course, as soon as he twigged, he told me to stop. Three-year-old me instantly replied: "This is my house and I'll do as I want."

He left me to it. He was married to my grandmother, so perhaps he knew not to pick a losing fight.

Not surprisingly, when my mum and nan got home I was rolling drunk and, by all accounts, not much more co-operative.

My grandfather got an earful, I was put to bed and the story passed into family lore.

As my nan used to tell me: "You were such a little cow  and you know what? You weren't sick, not once. Not a drop."

When you've got that streak in you as a toddler, no one's ever going to be able to tell you what to do when you're fully grown.

It wasn't a one-off, either.

A few months later my mum took me to school for the very first time.

Picking me up after my first day, she asked the teacher how I had got on. She had been worried, my mum admitted, because I was very shy.

"Which one is your daughter?" the teacher asked.

"Karren Brady," said my mother.

"Karren Brady?" was the incredulous response. "Shy? She walked in, pulled a boy off his chair and said, 'That's my seat. Move.' I wouldn't be worried if I was you!"

It was advice my mother took to heart. In fact, that was probably the last time she worried about me.

There were other powerful influences in my childhood.

Both of my grandmothers were hard workers, strong women and very important in moulding me.

I was very close to Nina, my mother's mother, in particular, who put an end to that alcoholic tea party when I was three. She was dynamite. She was Italian  from Naples  and incredibly feisty. She would have killed for her family  she wouldn't have thought twice about it.

If someone cut up my grandfather in traffic, she would get out of the car and punch them on the nose.

I'm sure it won't come as any surprise when I say she was definitely the one in control of her house and marriage.

She was great with money  not because she had a lot but because she knew the price of everything and she was in charge.

My grandfather went out to work as a postman but she would take his wages and give him cash to spend.

That was just the way it was. Grandma Nina really believed in me. Her attitude was: You can do it, so go out there and get on with it.

Even if I get a bit feisty at home now, my husband will still say to me, "Oh, Nina's here. Nina's coming out."

I was fiercely determined. If I wanted something and my parents wouldn't give it to me, I would find a way to get it for myself.

I was never given pocket money. My parents always offered to buy me what I wanted but I wanted to be in charge of my own money.

I recall them once saying no to something  I can't remember what it was  but I haven't forgotten what I decided to do. I put up signs in my bedroom window  it was my bedroom so I could do what I liked, I reasoned  saying, "Massages, manicures, come inside!"

My mother was shouting up: "Who are all these weirdos coming to the door?"

And I bawled back: "They're my customers."

I was bloody-minded too. I once put up a Vote Labour poster in my bedroom just because my parents were Conservatives.

My dad roared: "Take that down!"

I said: "It's my bedroom!"

He said: "What does the poster even mean?" And I didn't know, of course. I just knew it would wind him up and cause a debate.

When I was about 14, I'd tell my mum I was going to stay the night with my best friend, Charlotte, who would tell her mum she was staying at my house.

After that we would meet up with our clothes in carrier bags, get changed, take the Tube into central London then go out in Soho.

When everything closed we'd walk around until the Tube re-started in the early morning and go back to our borough  Enfield in north London.

Then we walked around until 10am before we went home.

Mum would say, "Well, you look very tired." But she never knew. Years later, when I told her, she was shocked. But I was even more shocked by what she said to me.

She looked at my daughter Sophie and said: "What goes around, comes around."

I went very cold and felt terrible about what I had done.

But at the time I couldn't have cared less.

Nothing was going to happen to me. I was in control, I was safe  or at least I thought I was.

But if I imagine my 15-year-old Sophie going out all night now, well...



The day I made a name for myself



MY school had lots of careers days and companies came in and talked to us, including advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi and the London radio station LBC.

Lots of people were interested but whereas everybody thought maybe they'd write to them, I got all the right details before the people left.

The next day I was on the phone making appointments.

Both companies I was interested in offered me a job.

I chose Saatchi, leaving school on the Friday and starting work there the following Monday.

Though I was only 18, they put me on their graduate programme. I suppose they saw something in me.

Though I loved it, the programme was very rigid, so finally I got impatient and moved instead to LBC as a 19-year-old selling radio advertising.

I had been given Asian Hour to sell, which was pretty tough  a 4am to 5am slot, the real graveyard shift.

I had been handed a list of companies that spent money on advertising but who didn't advertise on radio. One was Sport Newspapers.

I got through to owner David Sullivan on the phone and he wasn't interested, saying "radio didn't work".

I decided I would drop off some material at his office  persistence is everything  and once I was there I decided to wait to meet him in person.

I waited and waited and waited and in the end he agreed to see me because I had waited so long.

I did a very quick pitch to him and he wasn't buying it at all, so I said: "Look, if you take the advertising and sales don't go up, you don't have to pay for it."

He said: "That sounds good to me."

I didn't have the authority to do a deal like that, so it was a risk  but I remember thinking, "Well, if it doesn't work out, what's the worst that can happen? They can fire me but I can always get another job. I'm only 19."

I still use that kind of thinking and I have done all my life.

In fact, it's the foundation of my confidence and my ability to take risks.

It worked out. Sales went up and, within months, Sullivan was spending more than £2million a year on radio advertising.

I was managing it all and earning more commission than all the other sales staff put together.

Then he offered me a job, which I accepted.

That episode is often considered to have been a turning point in my professional life but, in truth, I think my life had been heading that way since I was a young child.

Adapted by BEN JACKSON Strong Woman: Ambition, Grit And A Great Pair Of Heels, by Karren Brady, is published by HarperCollins on March 29, £18.99.
articles.teaser: FUNNY anecdotes from the Apprentice star and West Ham vice-chairman's new book
articles.headline: Brady: I told Grandad, I'll do what I like

image.caption: Kiss ... lizard George and Lizzie Griffiths show affection

article.caption: Bride's £3k for lizard
Holiday rep-tile
Mantis preys on luckless lizard

articles.articlebody:
BRIDE Lizzie Griffiths told last night why she spent her £3,000 wedding fund on saving her beloved pet lizard George from cancer.

Lizzie admitted: "Some people might think it's mad, but I'd do anything to make George better."

"I was more than willing to spend all the wedding cash on treatment for George  without the treatment he would have been put down."

Lizzie postponed her wedding to fiance Chris Fisher  and last month George became the first bearded dragon in the UK to have radiotherapy.

She said: "I wake up at 5.30am each day so we can have a cuddle because if I don't get much time with him it upsets me.

"He comes into our bed and snuggles under the duvet while I feed him chocolate worms."

The primary school teacher, 26, of Purley, South London, lost her heart to bearded dragon George at an animal rescue centre last year.

Lizzie said: "I took one look at him and fell completely in love. He was so handsome.

"When I first held him he burrowed into my neck. I was so attached I put his tank at the end of our bed."

Chris asked Lizzie to marry him last August. Lizzie had a bow tie designed for George to wear at the wedding.

But in October, she was horrified when she spotted a growth on his face and a vet told her it was cancer.

The couple decided to cancel their big day and spend the £3,000 they had saved on pioneering radiotherapy.

George is now in remission. Chris, 26, said he has accepted that George always comes first. He added: "I think their relationship is adorable."

j.tippett@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: BRIDE tells why she spent her £3k wedding fund on saving beloved bearded dragon
articles.headline: I halted my wedding to save pet lizard George

image.caption: Flight of fancy ... Edward plants a smacker on Airwolf chopper

article.caption: I'm in love with 3ft statue of Adonis

articles.articlebody:
SOME people are accused of treating their partners "like objects"  and that charge is apt here.

The Sun told yesterday how 40-year-old carer Reighner Deleighnie is in a relationship with a 3ft statue of the Greek god of desire Adonis, who she calls Hans.

Reighner, of south London, is the latest in a small but growing group of "objectophiles" who believe their sexual orientation should not have a stigma attached.

The concept is not new. As far back as 1877 a statue of Venus de Milo was the subject of a court case when a gardener was caught trying to have sex with "her".

More recently, American Edward Smith has expressed his love for his VW Beetle, Vanilla, though he admits having "relationships" with many vehicles.

His most intense sexual experience was "making love" to a helicopter from the Eighties TV series Airwolf  but his major love is cars.

Edward said: "I go a little bit beyond appreciating the beauty of a car, to the point of what I feel is an expression of love.

"I write poetry about cars, I sing to them and talk to them like a girlfriend.

"I'm not sick. Cars are just my preference."

We told earlier this month how Leeds shop assistant Amanda Whittaker, 27, has fallen for the Statue of Liberty, or "Libby" as she knows her. At school she loved a drum kit.

In 1979, Eija-Riitta Eklöf from Sweden "married" the Berlin Wall. Eija, who changed her surname to Berliner-Mauer, coined the term Objectum Sexual (OS) for her unconventional orientation.

Mrs Berliner-Mauer says her "long-distance" relationship survived the "tragedy" of the wall being pulled down in 1989  but she has fallen for a red fence. Former US soldier Erika LaBrie, 41, pledged to love, honour and obey the Eiffel Tower in an intimate ceremony in Paris in 2007.

Erika Eiffel founded the Objectum Sexuality Internationale group which has more than 40 members and a website.

Other "inanimate lovers" revealed by objectophiles include a cartoon character, steam locomotives, words, public buildings and a hydraulic flood barrier.

San Francisco sexologist Dr Amy Marsh carried out a scientific survey involving 21 objectophiles and found cars, trains and aircraft are the most common objects of desire.

But more women than men are objectophiles and they are more likely to love structures.

Dr Marsh said: "OS transcends fetishism and is experienced as a sexual and/ or affectionate orientation with an array of emotions.

"It does not seem to be caused by trauma or delusional psychiatric conditions, though it does seem linked with autism.

"Professionals need to learn more about OS and treat OS patients with the same respect they do for other sexual preference minorities."

For more information go to dramymarshsexologist.com.

m.phillips@the-sun.co.uk
articles.byline: By MARTIN PHILLIPS, Senior Feature Writer
articles.teaser: MEET the 'objectophiles'  a growing number of people who are attracted to objects
articles.headline: The best sex of my life?

article.caption: Madonna: I like to work with people who talk about philosophy or quantum physics

articles.articlebody:
MADONNA is back  bigger, brighter and bolder then ever  with her electrifying new album MDNA.

And you can listen for FREE with The Sun below.

The album will be released Monday, March 26 on Interscope, so this is your chance to hear it here first.

The Queen of Pop reclaims her crown with this her 12th studio album to date; a collection of shiny, dancefloor anthems set to take the roof off summer.

Co-written by Madonna, album highlights include the glorious William Orbit-produced I'm A Sinner, which recalls the heyday of Ray of Light, and Falling Free, a beautiful, soaring ballad.

There's a pounding clubland stomper in Turn Up The Radio, produced by French electronic DJ and producer Martin Solveig.

Then there's the poptastic punch of Superstar, featuring Madonna's daughter Lourdes on backing vocals, I Don't Give A featuring Nicki Minaj and first single Give Me All Your Luvin, feat. Nicki Minaj & M.I.A., which were both produced by Martin Solveig.

Renowned Italian electro house DJ and producer Marco "Benny" Benassi adds an extra sheen to salacious rave-ups I'm Addicted and Girl Gone Wild.

article.caption: Adele wants to lose weight
Be a quitter and keep your figure
My 8-year takeaway binge cost £25k...and my unborn baby's life
You wouldn't eat 13 teaspoons of sugar in one go... so why drink it?

articles.articlebody:
THE average 45-year-old woman has been on 61 DIETS in her lifetime, according to a study.

That works out as more than two diets a year every year from the age of 16.

But fad eating habits with names as weird and wonderful as the Lunch Box Diet and the Dukan Diet have left many women with yoyo-ing moods as well as waistlines.

Self-confessed "chubster" Alison Noon admits she has tried everything in her bid to beat the bulge  but with no permanent results.

The researcher from Chiswick, west London, is the "average woman" from the poll  she is 45 and has tried 61 DIFFERENT diets.

Here, Alison explains why her weight-loss quest has left her miserable  and why she is still hooked on dieting.

ALISON NOON has tried every eating plan in the book.

Fluctuating between size 12 and 18 all her life has left her feeling perpetually depressed  and after 61 different diets she still cannot stop.

Alison admits she will try anything to shift some timber and reckons she has spent more than £5,000 on diets.

Since the start of this year she has already tried the Dukan Diet, the Cambridge Weight Plan, the Negative Calorie Diet  and the misery-inducing Cabbage Soup Diet.

Describing that particular fad, Alison says: "I had to weigh up whether the weight loss was worth the horrendous wind. I blamed the bad smells on the dog."

Constantly banning herself from the food she loves has made Alison's adult life a misery.

She says: "My hatred of being big has meant I have spent every day on a dieting roller coaster.

"I'm a fad diet junkie. It has become an addiction."

Alison's first diet memory goes back to when she was just 13.

She says: "I'll never forget the anxiety I felt when a shop girl told my mum there wasn't a school dress big enough for me.

"I squeezed into the size they had and trundled off to secondary school tugging at the hemline in embarrassment."

After being called "fatty" in that first year at school, Alison embarked on her first diet.

She says: "My mum had the Scarsdale Diet book and for six weeks I had grapefruit for breakfast, protein and salad for lunch and protein and veg for tea.

"Although I was always starving and grumpy, I stuck to it and lost a stone over the summer holidays and hit my goal weight of 8st.

"Even though I wasn't as skinny as some of my friends, I was just so happy to have been accepted."

But as soon as Alison stopped the diet plan, she shot back up to 9st, large for her 5ft 6in frame.

So she was actually HAPPY when she contracted glandular fever at the age of 16.

She says: "I lost a stone effortlessly  I was thrilled. I battled to stay that size but the weight I'd lost on the 'Glandular Fever Diet' didn't stay off.

"As soon as the biscuit barrel was in sight, I piled on the weight."

Alison's obsession got worse when she found even quicker fixes. Within six months of turning 19, she had tried the Fit For Life Diet, the Egg And Grapefruit Diet and the Banana Diet.

She adds: "I even tried the Lunch Box Diet. The idea is that you fill a lunch box up with lots of healthy food. That was great... until I started replacing the salad with chocolate."

During her twenties, Alison's weight fluctuated between a healthy 9½st and 10st  but she longed to be a stone lighter again.

A turning point in her dieting nightmare came when she married Frank, a photographer, now 48, in 1988 when she was 22.

She says: "I lost half a stone through a combination of nerves and WeightWatchers but, again, it didn't stay off. Within a year, I'd gone to almost 11st."

Alison got desperate and started the meal replacement Cambridge Weight Plan.

She says: "Within two months I was down to 8½st but, boy, it was hard. It was worth it though. I was slim and loving it."

Yo-yo dieting her way through the Eighties, Alison would spend hours researching gimmicks to keep herself below 10st  until she became pregnant for the first time in 1991.

She says: "I embraced eating for two and indulged in whatever I wanted, whenever I wanted. I looked massive.

"I was more than 14st when I gave birth to Charlie, who is now 20."

Afterwards, Alison got straight back into her fad diet cycle and spent a fortune on books and consultations to get back down to her beloved 9st.

But she explains: "Just as I hit the 10st mark, I found out I was pregnant with baby No2.

"Again, I ate for Britain. This time I was 13½st when I gave birth to Olivia in 1995."

Once more, Alison threw herself into a host of different diets.

She says: "You name it, I tried it. I'd feel motivated at the beginning and lose a few pounds but then I'd have a blip and pig out for a few days before embarking on another 'new' diet, telling myself this would be 'the one'."

Alison did not manage to slim down before becoming pregnant again in 2000.

The cycle of gorging and dieting continued after daughter Florence was born in 2001, and Alison flitted between 11 and 12½st.

Two years ago, Alison's husband told her he was worried because her stomach was bigger than her bust.

The Cambridge Weight Plan had worked for her in the past and, amazingly, she lost three-and-a-half stone in just three months.

She says: "At last I was 10st again. I stayed at that weight for six months by cutting out carbs.

"I looked great but missed bread and pasta."

But gradually the carbs slipped back on to her plate and Alison now admits: "I'm back to 12st... oh all right, 12½st."

"I hate being this big but I can't face another liquid replacement diet  unless the liquid is Sauvignon Blanc.

"Most of all, I'm sick of knowing that if I could just eat less and exercise more, my weight would naturally decrease. Perhaps then I would finally be happy."

image.caption: Cardiac arrest ... Fabrice Muamba is treated on the pitch at White Hart Lane

article.caption: Fabrice Muamba was 'dead' for 78 minutes
Fabrice Muamba asks: Did we lose?
Muamba troll arrested
Prem star Fabrice is still critical
Pray for Fab
Muamba collapses on pitch

articles.articlebody:
IF FOOTBALLER Fabrice Muamba had not received life-saving CPR after his cardiac arrest during a match on Saturday, he might not be here today.

"Every week in the UK, 12 apparently fit young people under the age of 35 die from undiagnosed cardiac conditions," says Dr Steve Cox, director of screening at charity Cardiac Risk In The Young.

He added: "Eighty per cent of these deaths will occur with no prior symptoms."

But how many of us know the skills we would need to save someone if they collapsed in front of us?

Around 60 per cent of kids say they would be powerless to help if a passer-by needed resuscitating, even though CPR could DOUBLE a casualty's chance of survival.

That is why The Sun yesterday launched a campaign to get Emergency Life Skills, or ELS, added to the national curriculum.

The drive  in conjunction with the British Heart Foundation  has won backing from former footballer Vinnie Jones, who stars in new TV ads teaching people what to do.

Below is a simple guide showing how YOU could save someone's life.

It has been compiled by Maureen Talbot, senior cardiac nurse at the British Heart Foundation.

Sign our petition to have CPR taught in schools

She says: "If you're untrained in full CPR or unsure about giving the kiss of life, hands-only CPR can still help save a life.

"Just remember to call 999 then push hard and fast to the beat of Stayin' Alive by the Bee Gees.

Here, we speak to two people who know first-hand how heart problems can affect the young and fit.

Adam Donnelly



ADAM was just 17 when he suddenly died on a family holiday in Cyprus.

Since then his sister Sian, a PA, has been diagnosed with the heart problem that killed him. Sian, 20, who lives with her parents in Welwyn, Kent, says:

Adam was such a fit young man that even now it's hard to accept he died so suddenly.

We were enjoying a family holiday in Cyprus. Just minutes before he died, Adam had been laughing and playing water volleyball.

But then he said he felt unwell. He got out and sat on the side of the pool  before suddenly collapsing head first into the water.

My parents and I had gone for a walk and a friend of Adam's dashed to find us. By the time we got back, Adam had been pulled out of the pool.

An ambulance was on its way and a nurse was desperately giving him the kiss of life, trying to restart his heart.

Now we know Adam had had a cardiac arrest. Tragically, it was too late to save him.

Two post-mortems  one in Cyprus and one in the UK  confirmed he died of Sudden Adult Death Syndrome.

For years we believed it was something peculiar to Adam. Then two years ago Cry, The Sudden Death Charity, suggested the family should all be screened.

My mum Julie, 50, had heart checks first  and, astoundingly, was diagnosed with Brugada Syndrome.

Commonly associated with Sudden Adult Death Syndrome, it is an inherited condition that affects the heart's rhythm. A year later I too was diagnosed with it.

It was a shock to realise this syndrome was undoubtedly responsible for Adam's death in 2004 and the deaths of many other young people.

We then discovered it can be picked up by a simple ECG. Had Adam been tested his death could have been prevented.

In July 2010 I had a mini defibrillator fitted.

It is terrible to think Adam's death has probably saved my life.

That's why I believe everyone should undergo a routine heart trace at 14. If an irregular heartbeat is detected, doctors can investigate further.

Nick Dias



ASSISTANT site manager Nick collapsed in December and has now been fitted with a pacemaker.

The 27-year-old lives with fiancée Lynsey, 25, and their children, Brooke, five, and Riley, seven months, in Radlett, Herts. He says:

As a non-smoker, who is slim and exercises regularly, I never imagined I would have a heart problem.

But in December last year Lynsey and I were walking Brooke to school and after bending down to get her schoolbag from Riley's pushchair I passed out.

Seconds later I came round to find Lynsey looking very concerned. Apparently I'd fallen backwards and cracked my head on the pavement.

We assumed I'd fainted and carried on walking Brooke to school. But as we did so, Lynsey became more worried because I started talking gibberish  I kept repeating myself and asking strange questions.

After dropping Brooke off, Lynsey insisted on driving me to A&E at Watford General Hospital. She was worried I might have concussion.

The doctor said because I'd passed out, he wanted to check my heart. And I was horrified when the ECG detected a problem with the rhythm of my heart.

Terrifyingly, the doctor said I was suffering from heart block where the electrical impulses that make the heart beat don't always reach the heart.

I was lucky my heart had started beating again  but next time I might not be so lucky and if I wasn't treated, could have a full-blown cardiac arrest.

Doctors have been unable to find a reason for my heart block. As they have also found a slight problem with a heart valve, it is possibly something I was born with.

Since then I've had a pacemaker fitted.

Doctors say when the children are ten they will have to be tested too.

But it's something I feel should be routinely tested for in everyone. If it weren't for Lynsey insisting I go to A&E that day, I might not have discovered this.

And ultimately I could have suddenly suffered a potentially fatal cardiac arrest at any time.
articles.teaser: AS Bolton's Fabrice Muamba recovers from heart attack, we show you how to save a life
articles.headline: What would YOU do?

image.caption: Painless ... aspirin has been hailed as a treatment for depression, dementia and even cancer

article.caption: Go brain training
Working without machines
Denise Van Outen: Cycling makes me feel like a kid again

articles.articlebody:
DEPRESSION, heart disease, dementia and now cancer could all be prevented by taking aspirin.

It costs just 1p a tablet, but Oxford scientists said this week that taking an aspirin a day can reduce your risk of cancer.

A study found the pills not only reduce the chances of contracting the illness, but also protect against it spreading.

Experts believe the evidence is so strong that, in future, the NHS watchdog NICE may issue guidelines advising doctors to prescribe it to cancer sufferers.

The research, involving 200,000 patients, found that aspirin can cut the risk of dying of cancer by 37 per cent if taken every day for five years. Aspirin works by suppressing the creation of prostaglandin, a hormone that carries information about pain to the brain. It was first sold as 1899 as a powder by the German firm Bayer.

Aspirin can clearly do more than banish headaches, though some experts believe it could do more harm than good.

Here, we look at some of the surprising uses.

Depression

SOME experts believe depression and inflammation could be linked after small studies found some depressed people have high levels of cytokines  naturally occurring chemicals with inflammatory properties  in the body.

So because it's an anti-inflammatory drug, aspirin might be able to help.

One study followed 386 women for ten years  22 developed depression after the age of 50.

Of these only one had taken aspirin.

But among those who did not develop depression, almost a third were taking it.

Acne

A KEY ingredient in aspirin is salicylic acid, which is used in many of today's off-the-shelf acne products.

Mix a tablet with water then rub the solution on to your skin.

Leave it on for two minutes, then rinse off.

This will dry your pimples out and your spots will go faster.

If you have normal or dry skin don't try this more than once a week as you will lose too much moisture from your skin.

Dandruff

A COMMON cause of this is a tiny yeast called Pityroporum ovale, which lives on the scalp. Aspirin is a mild anti-fungal so it can help.

Crush two tablets and mix them with one serving of shampoo.

Apply the mixture to your hair and leave for about two minutes so it can settle on your scalp.

Rinse it off and shampoo your hair again.

Dementia

STUDIES have found that Alzheimer's disease, the most common form of dementia, is an inflammatory condition of the brain so aspirin might be effective in treating it.

Research carried out in Utah, involving the observation and testing of more than 3,000 people, suggested taking it could reduce the risk of contracting the condition by 23 per cent.

Heart disease

IT IS thought it can help by reducing inflammation in the arteries that supply the heart  making the blood less likely to become sticky and form a deadly clot.

In some studies, taking aspirin reduced the likelihood of a cardiovascular problem, including heart disease, heart attack or stroke, by as much as 44 per cent.

Experts also found it can help someone who has already had a heart attack or a stroke by reducing the risk of having another by a third.

Athlete's Foot

ATHLETE'S foot and other fungal infections can be treated using a few aspirin pills and talcum powder.

Grind three pills until they are in a powder form.

Then mix the powdered aspirin with some talcum powder.

Apply the mixture on to the infected area of skin.

Do this process twice a day to kill the fungi and to treat the irritation.

In-growing hair

HAVE you got a painful in-growing hair that won't budge?

Aspirin is made up of acetylsalicylic acid, which exfoliates skin and has anti-inflammatory properties.

So applying a thick paste made of crushed aspirin and a little warm water could help you remove it with ease.

Apply it to the hair and leave to settle for ten to 15 minutes. Then remove using warm water.

This should get rid of the hair, or at least make it easier to remove.

Pre-eclampsia

A DAILY dose of aspirin during pregnancy could cut the risk of pre-eclampsia, a condition that threatens the lives of both mother and baby.

A study of 32,000 women published in The Lancet medical journal found that mums who took it were ten per cent less likely to develop the condition.

Insect bites

AS these are marked by redness, itchiness and sometimes a burning sensation, aspirin  an anti-inflammatory  can help clear these up.

Wet the affected area and rub a small aspirin over the skin to help relieve the pain caused by mosquito bites or stings from a bee, wasp or hornet.

Taking it orally could also help to reduce any painful swelling.

Shingles

ASPIRIN is thought to be one of the most effective treatments for dealing with the pain and uncomfortable symptoms associated with shingles.

Mash two tablets into a paste and use a clean cotton swab to apply it to the skin.

The risks...

  • ONE in five asthmatics are at risk of a severe reaction to aspirin, according to research in Australia and the UK.

  • A recent London University study linked taking aspirin with a 30 per cent rise in the risk of debilitating  and potentially fatal  internal bleeding.

  • A study last January advised doctors to stop prescribing aspirin to ward off heart attacks as it raises the risk of bleeding in the stomach by a third.

  • Oxford researchers say a daily dose as small as 75mg could increase the risk of abdominal bleeding.

  • Anyone with an allergy to aspirin or a bleeding or clotting disorder should not use it for any purpose.

    If in doubt, consult your GP.
articles.teaser: MANY illnesses and now even CANCER could apparently be prevented by taking aspirin
articles.headline: Aspirin's not just for headaches
articles.subdeck: Painless ... aspirin has been hailed as a treatment for depression, dementia and even cancer

image.caption: 'Cameron fills my life with love and joy' ... Crystal and her 7-year-old son

article.caption: Lover offered me £2,000 to abort our Down's boy... but look how full of life he is now!
Susan Boyle: I can take whatever Ricky Gervais says... he's the one with the problem not me
Twit Joey calls rival a 'mong'
My Down's girl almost died, now she's a model

articles.articlebody:
CRYSTAL Pawson cradled her newborn son and feared, at 16, she was too young to be the mum he needed.

Less than 20 minutes later her worries were magnified when doctors revealed her baby had Down's syndrome.

It was a bombshell blow  but 11 years on Crystal believes she is Britain's luckiest mum.

She said: "Cameron is loyal, funny and affectionate and fills my life with love and joy.

"You couldn't hope to meet a more smashing lad. Having Cameron has been the making of me."

The lad is also a brilliant big brother to Luke, ten, Jake, four, Mackenzie, two, and four-month-old Brooklyn.

As the Down's Syndrome Association runs its awareness campaign this week, courageous Crystal, 27, revealed how Cameron has made her a better person.

Around one in every 1,000 babies born in the UK will have Down's and there are 60,000 people in the UK with the condition.

Although the chance of a baby having Down's is higher for older mothers, more babies with Down's are born to younger women  because they have more children.

Crystal fell pregnant at 15 and as the likelihood of having a Down's baby was considered so rare for a mum-to-be of her age, doctors had not even asked if she wanted to be tested.

Like many women, Crystal assumed only older mums had Down's children. She admits when she was first told of her son's diagnosis at Harrogate District Hospital in North Yorkshire, she was horrified and ashamed.

She said: "I was still getting my head round the fact he had Down's when three hours after his birth he was whisked off for a scan.

"When they brought my baby back and told me he had three holes in his heart and would need a major op to fix it, I just fell apart."

The devastated teenager sobbed in her mother's arms.

Back at home in Wetherby, West Yorks, sharing a room with her sister and her new tot made life even harder.

She says: "I couldn't bear to go out, not because I didn't want to show him off but I was so scared he would die.

"He seemed so vulnerable and I was way out of my depth. I sobbed myself to sleep every night and kept thinking 'why me?'"

Cameron's dad, 16-year-old Drew, stood by her  visiting the pair regularly. But Crystal was convinced he would leave her.

She said: "All his mates were out clubbing and he was a 16-year-old lad with a baby with Down's."

At three months old Cameron went in for the op to fix the holes in his heart.

Crystal was warned he would be in hospital for up to three months but after just three weeks he was doing so well he was discharged.

Back at home, while most girls her age were out having fun, 16-year-old Crystal was caring for a very sick baby. Then something amazing happened.

Crystal said: "Cameron just fought and fought and suddenly I realised it was time to stop feeling sorry for myself. I gave myself a massive boot up the backside.

"OK, my son wasn't the perfect baby but he was my son and he deserved a mum who would fight for him all the way."

Drew and Crystal moved in together and the teen parents learnt Makaton, a language programme using signs and symbols, so they could communicate with Cameron as he grew up.

Crystal said: "Being able to sign was a major bonus.

"Cameron and I formed a remarkable bond and suddenly I realised his disability was anything but."

When Crystal fell pregnant with another child when Cameron was just 18 months old, a few friends said she wouldn't be able to cope.

She was offered a nuchal scan to determine the likelihood of Down's, but turned it down.

She said: "I didn't want to know. I coped with Cameron and I knew I'd cope again."

Baby Luke was born healthy, as was Jake two years after.

Crystal said: "The specialists don't know why I had a baby with Down's so young and then it never occurred again. They say it's extremely rare."

When Cameron was seven, Crystal split from his dad, suddenly finding herself a single mum to three boys.

She said: "I'm not saying it was easy but dealing with Cameron gave me the strength to deal with anything.

"Some people close to me thought I would have a breakdown but it was actually Cameron that kept me going.

"He developed this really cheeky, funny personality. He had me in stitches and when I was down he seemed to sense it and would give me a cuddle. He's just so happy I couldn't be sad around him."

Crystal has since found love with 21-year-old shop worker Darren Hooper. The couple have two sons.

She said: "Life's good. Cameron goes to a special needs school which he loves and has really boosted his speech and learning.

"I'll admit that when I first heard my little boy had Down's I reached the depths of despair but now I don't see him as a boy with problems.

"I see him for what he is  an unbelievably loving little boy who loves cuddles and has tons of affection and love to give.

"I know people thought I didn't have the maturity to cope but having Cameron has been the making of me."

And Crystal has high hopes for Cameron's future: "I would love him to move out of home, get a job, marry and go on to have his own family one day and there's no reason why he can't achieve any of those dreams.

"Cameron has ambitions like any boys his age. He loves playing sports and listening to Lady GaGa.

"He tells me he wants to be a footballer one day and I tell him he should aim high and go for it.

"Every child, no matter if they have Down's syndrome, should be given a chance to prove what they can do and lead as ordinary a life as possible."

Sarah offers other parents hope



DOWN'S syndrome actress Sarah Gordy is proof that people with disabilities can lead a full and rewarding life.

The 34-year-old  who plays Lady Pamela on BBC drama Upstairs Downstairs  has starred in many TV shows and plays. And her mum Jane, 63, could not be more proud of her daughter.

But Jane, speaking about discovering her first-born had Down's syndrome, admitted: "Being completely honest, if I was given a test and told my baby had Down's I would have considered a termination.

"I'd have been terrified about not being able to look after her. But that saddens me now.

"When I fell pregnant I wasn't ready to be a mum. In my 20s at the time, I'd never changed a nappy so I felt very unprepared.

"When Sarah was born I couldn't believe how beautiful she was."

Jane didn't have any tests for Down's syndrome because she was under 28 when she fell pregnant. But the paediatrician noticed Sarah had the condition from the moment he saw her.

Jane said: "Calling my husband Jerry aside, he told him that Sarah had the condition. Not only that, but he asked him not to tell me.

"He said it was important for me to form a bond with Sarah first.

"Looking back I don't know how poor Jerry kept it to himself."

It wasn't until four days later that Jane found out.

She said: "I was heartbroken and terrified I would lose my baby. He kept telling me about potential heart problems and operations she'd need.

"But finding out turned me from a girl into a fully-fledged mother."

Luckily, Sarah didn't need any operations. Jane said: "I wish I knew back then what I know now, about how much of an amazing life she'd have."

Jane had another daughter, Catherine, now 32, 16 months after Sarah and admits she felt relief when tests showed she did not have Down's.

Jane said: "I just didn't know if having two children with the condition would be too much.

"I wish parents-to-be were provided with more information about Down's syndrome before they make a decision about termination.

"No one should ever feel pressured either way, but it's such a difficult decision to make without knowing exactly what it will entail."

While everything took longer with Sarah, Jane says she soon realised her daughter had an incredible ability to feel what other people feel.

She said: "If I'm ever stressed or worried and I tell Sarah I'm fine she will say, 'No you're not,' and I have to come clean. We're very close as no emotion goes unnoticed."

And Jane explains that Down's syndrome actors work very differently to those without the condition.

She said: "The interesting thing about Sarah is she doesn't really act. She feels very emotional on set.

"She can't fake emotion, so instead she believes everything about her character.

"Once she was acting as an abused wife and I saw how much the abusive words were hurting her.

"When she came off set I said, 'Sarah  you're a beautiful, successful actress' and she slowly remembered that.

"I like to think that Sarah being successful on TV gives parents who are expecting a Down's syndrome child strength and confidence that their child can lead a really healthy life."

myView



By CAROL BOYS, Chief Executive at Down's Syndrome Association

WE have seen great improvements in the lives of people with Down's syndrome since the association's formation in 1970.

Today, the average life expectancy of people with Down's syndrome is 60 to 65 years, compared to 35 to 40 back in 1970. They are now legally entitled to quality healthcare, good education and jobs and live fulfilling lives.

People with Down's all have a degree of learning difficulty but with the right support they are able to reach many milestones that other people reach.

See downs-syndrome.org.uk or call 0208 614 5100.
articles.byline: By KATE THOMPSON and JENNY FRANCIS
