article.caption: Drink kills 25% more in 8 years
Sunder the influence...

articles.articlebody:
MEMORY loss, weight gain and depression can all be symptoms of regular heavy nights out drinking.

Many celebrities, including Fearne Cotton, Leona Lewis and Jessie J, are choosing to ditch alcohol.

Prince Harry has stopped pubbing to concentrate on his helicopter training.

Increasing numbers of people are binning the booze and banishing binge drinking from their lives to seek out a healthier lifestyle.

According to NHS figures, at least one in six adults has sworn off alcohol completely, shunning peer pressure in favour of a hangover-free life.

JENNY FRANCIS meets five women who have gone teetotal to find out what life is like without booze.

Linda Obena, 28



THE digital producer from Crystal Palace in south east London went teetotal in October. Sick of her unhealthy lifestyle and size 18 waist, Linda decided to ditch booze for good. She says:

Last autumn I was stuck in a destructive routine of drinking and eating too much.

I'd just broken up with my boyfriend and wanted to move on. I'd read about the LighterLife diet and wanted to give it a go.

Overnight I gave up alcohol and started eating four food packs a day, containing 5-600 calories.

It was a complete shock to the system and the first week was really hard, but I knew it would be worth it.

I used to drink a bottle of wine most nights, on Fridays I'd have work drinks and Saturdays I'd be out drinking with non-work friends.

Sundays were spent recovering. It was relentless. Drinking with clients and colleagues was part of my life and I'd got myself into really bad habits.

It was only after I gave it up I noticed what a big impact it had.

Now after a work night out I'll come into the office whistling and full of energy, while my colleagues are often a step behind me. And I remember all the office gossip!

It's been five months now and I feel stronger, more confident and I have more energy than ever before.

I've gone from 14st 9lb to 12st, from a size 18-16 to a size 14-12  and I know I look as good as I feel.

Laura Coventry, 33



WEDDING photographer Laura, from Glasgow, went teetotal two years ago after bingeing on boozy nights out left her with huge memory blanks. She says:

Like most girls in their twenties and thirties I lived for the weekend.

The prospect of partying and heavy drinking got me through the working week and I'd wish away Monday to Friday.

I drank a lot, not just a couple of glasses of wine, but enough to get seriously drunk. I just loved the euphoria and the buzz that it gave me.

I'd suffer terrible hangovers, I'd regularly be in bed until 5pm with headaches and feeling sick, but I saw it as a price worth paying to let my inhibitions go.

On occasions I'd been out with friends, woken up with a shocking hangover  and realised there were huge blanks in my night out I couldn't remember.

It really scared me and for the first time I questioned why I was doing this to myself. I knew I had to change.

The first two weeks were the hardest, but I managed the first three-month goal I set myself, then extended that to six months.

Now not one drop of booze has passed my lips since February 2010.

Some friends want me to start going out drinking with them again and say that I've proven my point, but I'm determined not to drink again.

I have a fantastic new boyfriend now and I wake up on Mondays smiling, something which never happened before.

I still party but I don't need alcohol to get a buzz. Life feels so much fuller and better.

Lucy Troughton, 31



IT was last October when Lucy went teetotal after realising the damaging effect alcohol was having on her mood. The waitress, from Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, says:

I lived in London between the ages of 19 to 22 and I was out drinking socially most nights. But when I fell pregnant at 23 I didn't drink for the best part of a year.

It's not that I missed it but I still felt very young to be stuck at home, not out partying like I used to.

I was in a band so drinking was almost expected of me.

Most of my friends didn't have kids so there was always someone around to go out drinking with. I soon reverted back to weekend drinking.

I got stuck in a rut of Mondays being a write-off, like I was waiting for the day to finish the moment I woke up.

I wanted to be on form for my daughter Grace, now seven, but I was tired and only realised when it was too late that I was becoming depressed.

In mid-October last year I decided enough was enough and gave up alcohol completely.

It was, and still is, very hard. I didn't go out and became a bit of a recluse, focusing more on my music, gardening and reading.

It's had a huge effect and I really love the mornings now.

I feel so clear-headed. And people often comment on how I'm 'glowing' now.

The idea of a glass of wine with a meal is still a temptation but it does get easier to say "No".

Going teetotal has taught me what I really value. And I'm happier than ever.

Katie Carr, 22



BARMAID Katie from Bridlington, East Yorks, was a beer-swilling, pizza-scoffing ladette.

She went teetotal in July 2010 after binge drinking caused her to have a seizure and a new love interest persuaded her to transform her life. Katie says:

Tequila, sambuca, Jägerbombs  I wasn't fussy. I could get through 20 pints of lager in a night.

In June 2010, I'd been fired from my job as a waitress for consistently turning up to work reeking of alcohol.

Three weeks later, I'd spent £1,200 in my local pub. I put on nine stone in a year on a diet of booze and pizza, weighed 18.5st and was a size 22. I didn't wear make-up or dress girly.

One night in July, I was out with friends when I had a seizure in a nightclub.

I was carried out by a bouncer and taken to hospital by ambulance. The doctor instructed me to stop drinking for six weeks while they ran tests.

While I was sober, I had time to re-evaluate who I was.

Wanting to seize the day, I contacted the bouncer and asked him, "When are you going to take me out?". I was amazed when he said later that week.

Luckily, the CT scans came back clear  I'd just drunk too much. I've not been back on the booze since and have now lost eight stone.

Going teetotal is one of the best things I've ever done.

I've gone from ladette to lady.

Rebecca Spencer, 35



THE charity worker from Southend, Essex, went teetotal seven years ago after a charity trip shocked her into a lifestyle change. She says:

In 2003 I moved to London from Newcastle in search of a new job.

I had a big group of friends and we used to go out every weekend and always drank a lot of vodka. It was just something we did and I didn't see it as a problem.

In 2005 I embarked on a charity trip with Help The Aged to India to photograph how people were rebuilding their lives after the 2004 tsunami.

It was the most eye-opening, inspiring and horrendous experience, all at the same time.

The destruction was overpowering and having an alcoholic drink in that context seemed completely ridiculous.

The experience changed my values and made me completely reassess myself.

Just a few days after being in India I was in Covent Garden surrounded by young professionals knocking back drinks without a thought.

I'd seen people with absolutely nothing and I decided to re-focus my life on the things that counted. Alcohol seemed such a self-destructive extravagance.

As soon as I gave up I realised I'd never even really liked the taste of alcohol  it was just the social side of it I enjoyed.

Nine months after the charity trip I fell pregnant and later had my son.

I felt great and no part of me wanted to drink again.

I've been teetotal for seven years now and feel healthier, more energetic and have much more in my pocket  why go back?
articles.teaser: INCREASING numbers of people are binning alcohol  here five women reveal what it's like to live without booze
articles.headline: Why we're all tee totally happy

articles.articlebody:
THIS is the season to embrace dewy skin. Forget heavy tans, thick layers of foundation and cakey bronzer  radiance is now the key word in the beauty world.

Catwalk models have all been given little else but radiant, glowing skin, while celebrities such as Natalie Portman are setting the precedent for softer, fresher looks.

If YOU fancy brightening your complexion, a few simple tricks can lift your skin.

LAUREN NAYLOR shares her skin secrets so you can get up and glow.

Skin perfection



LET'S face it, we'd all love to feel confident make-up free and be blessed with a radiant, glowy complexion.

But daily exposure to harsh elements can make it difficult to pull off. Look out for nourishing and calming skincare ingredients to give your skin radiance and combat dryness and redness.

Head therapist Sherelle at celebrity skin care spa Linda Meredith, whose clients include Kate Beckinsale and Gwyneth Paltrow, says: "Start by using a cleanser packed full of naturally occurring vitamins, omega oils and amino acids.

"We are exposed to various chemicals throughout our day so look for paraben-free formulas.

"Take a generous amount of cleansing product mixed with warm water and with a feather-soft touch gently massage the product in with your fingertips.

"By massaging softly you are pushing the product into your skin rather than moving facial muscles about aggressively.

And the warm water heats the skin for the products to penetrate deeper. When you rinse, use a soft sponge, gentle cotton wool pads or your hands  flannels are too abrasive.

"An old-school, tried-and-tested method that we use is to give your skin a deep steam once a week over the basin. This will help open up and deep-clean any clogged pores.

"There is nothing wrong with squeezing out blackheads  just make sure you take a thick piece of tissue and use the sides of your fingertips to push them out.

"Only do this for three to five minutes max. If they won't come, they're not ready, and if you use your fingernails you will break and damage your skin."

We love REN Hydra-Calm Cleansing Milk with peroxidase enzymes from fennel seed extract to protect distressed skin and Omega 3 and 7 essential fatty acids to reduce inflammation, £18.

Linda Meredith Paraben-free Cream Cleanser with avocado and citrus fruit oils, £39 (stockists, 020 7225 2755). Team with a brightening moisturiser such as Simple Radiance Brightening Moisturiser, £6.99 (Boots).

Pep up



IF your complexion is looking lacklustre, it's likely you need to exfoliate sluggish skin cells. Look for natural ingredients that gently slough off dead skin.

Walnut shell, papaya and pineapple are all fantastic natural exfoliators. Try Origins Never A Dull Moment skin-brightening polisher with fruit extracts to help reveal a healthy glow, £24 (Origins).

Put your feet up and slather on Elemis Papaya Enzyme Peel, £28.60 (Elemis counters). We love the intoxicating Victoria sponge-like scent.

Make me up



SKIN highlighters add radiance in an instant. You can layer under make-up or wear stand-alone.

If you are going out and want to appear more made up, try adding highlighter along the cheekbones, down the bridge of the nose and on the forehead  this gives a shimmering dewiness.

You can also place highlighter on the brow bone and under the arch of the brow to make your eyes appear brighter.

L'Oreal Lumi Magique Concealer, £8.49, (Boots) will help to brighten the eyes if you dab a small amount in the darkest areas, ie, underneath, and Bobbi Brown Creamy Concealer in Chestnut, £17, is great for darker skins. Gorgeously rich and luxurious, MAC's Strobe Cream is used by many of the world's high-profile make-up artists.

Wear it under or over make-up for a dewy, almost wet-look effect and team with MAC's Lustre Drops in Sun Rush, £17.50, for a pop of warmth.

Last but not least, finish your face with a burst of brightening blusher on the apples of your cheeks such as Gosh Natural Blush in Electric Pink, Max Factor Miracle Touch Creamy Blush in Soft Pink, £6.99, or Maybelline NY Dream Soft Blush in Peach 02, £4.49 (all Superdrug).
articles.teaser: FORGET heavy tans and thick layers of foundation  radiance is the key word on the catwalk

articles.articlebody:
CUT-price Kate is at it again  but this time the High Street style queen has been hitting the thrift shops.

Last week it was revealed the Duchess sent aides to a second-hand dress agency just a few miles from her Berkshire family home to find her outfits.

Her nearly new purchases from The Stock Exchange, in Sunninghill, include the grey Jesire coat dress she wore to a National Portrait Gallery event last month.

Described as a "premier venue for the fashion-conscious bargain hunter", the shop sells unwanted designer gear for clients and takes a 50 per cent cut of the sale price.

We sent Sun stylist Nana Acheampong to the shop to put together a wardrobe that was fit for a princess.

She found top High Streets labels including Kate's favourites LK Bennett and Karen Millen, plus fashion house labels including Chloe.

Nana, 25, said: "Staff revealed the store takes donations from a host of local TV presenters. They get a cut of any sales but anything not sold after five weeks goes to charity.

"They haven't seen the Duchess in the store but they were really excited when they saw Kate on TV wearing the Jesire dress.

"It looks like the Duchess has a secret shopper and The Stock Exchange are keen for whoever it is to continue shopping there."

Nana managed to put together four outfits for less than £180.

Here, Kate lookalike Chelsea Collins, 22, from Poole, Dorset, models our princess perfect looks.

image.caption: Risky business ... new warning highlights danger of unqualified beauty therapists

article.caption: I was terrified my PIP implants were a ticking timebomb. I just wanted them out
I spent £10,000 to look like one of my Barbies

articles.articlebody:
THOUSANDS of women are putting themselves at risk by inviting rogue beauty therapists into their homes.

Some agencies, such as online beauty therapist directory mobilebeauty.uk.com, allow anyone to register and advertise for work with NO checks.

Lauren Shalson, co-founder and director of reputable company Spa By Car, says: "Many online beauty agencies offer work or let therapists register based simply on a phone call. How can you safely send someone into a client's home without at least meeting them in person?

"After a thorough interview process, to be accepted on to our books our therapists need a minimum of NVQ level 2 and 3 and arrive in branded clothing, a branded car and bring proof of certificates to the appointment.

"We, as clients, need to be fully aware we could be letting anyone into our home and of the danger we could be placing ourselves in, especially if opting for a specialist treatment like intimate waxing. The mobile beauty sector is enjoying a surge because clients want therapies in the safety of their own home.

"Yet unscrupulous operators are sending unvetted, unqualified and uninsured therapists to clients' homes  exposing them to unimaginable risks. If you are using a mobile beauty therapist I would ask for references. If you are to use one at all I would use one that has been recommended to you and who has proved they can do a good job.

"I would ask who their insurance provider is and for proof of training  especially if you are going for eyelash extensions, where sharp tweezers are used which could cause a lot of damage in the hands of the wrong person. Be warned!"
articles.teaser: THOUSANDS of women are putting themselves at risk by inviting rogue beauty therapists into their homes
articles.headline: Truth about rogue beauticians...
articles.subdeck: Risky business ... new warning highlights danger of unqualified beauty therapists

article.caption: Britain's Gold Talent
Will.i.am: Simon gives his acts the Cowell shoulder
Simon Cowell: Voice rivalry is waste of telly fee
Judge and fury
Cheryl Cole Voices single in Simon Cowell snub

articles.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S Got Talent judge Amanda Holden ramped up the battle with rival The Voice with a sick dig at veteran star Tom Jones.

Urging viewers to watch her tonight instead of 71-year-old Tom in his spinning judge's chair on the BBC1 show, she joked: "He might be spinning in his grave next week."

Boss Simon Cowell looked shocked by her gag at the launch of the ITV1 show's sixth series. It followed her own near-death experience when she gave birth to new daughter Hollie.

But show insiders last night insisted Amanda meant no offence to the Delilah singer, adding: "She has the utmost respect for Tom."

A fierce spat erupted between the rival show's stars before they clash in a ratings war tonight.

Amanda, 41, joins boss Cowell and fellow judges Alesha Dixon and David Walliams on the ITV1 show.

Last night Cowell  who had been criticised by Sir Tom over his right to judge singers  hit back at the Welsh crooner's ability to pick wannabe stars.

He said: "Most artists who try and run record labels fail. That's why they are artists. Can a singer judge another singer as well as a record executive?"

The music tycoon also blasted "petty" Beeb bosses over the scheduling clash, laying the blame firmly at their door.

He said: "They're the ones who seem to be making it into a battle. We were always going to air in March because of my timings.

"The BBC are doing this as the more they talk about us the more headlines they get. But I don't like it when the shows clashes. It is petty scheduling."

But BBC1 controller Danny Cohen played down the battle for viewers, saying: "I'm not going to put a number on what we see as success for The Voice."

Yesterday Cowell said this year's BGT will be the best ever, erasing memories of last year's uninspiring run.

He said: "There's a mixture of good and what I call good old-fashioned British eccentricity.

"The best way to judge the show is not to take it too seriously, but the good ones are always going to get through and that is the important thing."

With a glint in his eye, he added: "There will be some strippers of course  one or two."

And he said there will be nine acts in the semi-final instead of eight, ensuring even more talent gets through.

Simon, 52, also sang the praises of Walliams, 40  who rose to fame alongside Matt Lucas in BBC1 comedy Little Britain. Cowell said: "I've been trying to get David to do this show for the past two years. There were these two bellringers last year and I texted him saying: 'It's you and Matt!'

"Some of his characters on Little Britain are like some of our contestants. I thought he'd really fit into that kind of British eccentric humour. He's been a revelation."

l.holmwood@the-sun.co.uk



Big Jon's a belter



UNLIKELY singing duo Jonathan and Charlotte have the judges wincing when they wander on to the BGT stage  but leave to a standing ovation.

Bulky Jonathan and his pretty auburn partner, who were introduced by their singing teacher, impressed all four judges with their performance.

Simon says: "Wow, wow, wow. Charlotte you are good but Jonathan you are unbelievable."

But when he asks Jonathan, 16, if he would continue solo, the hopeful replies: "We've come on as a duo and we're gonna stay here as a duo."

  • BOOKIES have already predicted that BGT will win the Saturday night ratings war  with William Hill putting the ITV1 show at 2/9 on and BBC's The Voice trailing on 3/1.

    A spokesman for the firm said: "The return of Simon to the BGT panel will probably be enough on its own to secure an opening week victory over the Beeb."

    TV recorders will be needed by those who want to see both  the shows overlap by 20 minutes.

  • Britain's Got Talent starts tonight on ITV1, 8pm



    'I've put it all on the line for show'



    Says Tom Jones



    SHOWBIZ veteran Sir Tom Jones told The Sun yesterday how he was staking his reputation on the success of The Voice.

    And he said he even fears taking abuse in the street if he gets it wrong.

    The 71-year-old crooner explained: "You are throwing yourself out there and making decisions. People at home could be thinking, 'What the f***? Why would he do that? What's the matter  is he deaf?'

    "When you are out and about on the Tube, or in a cab, the drivers are going to go, 'Hey Tom, the show is s***'. We have to make the show as good as we possibly can and whatever is thrown against you, fight back."

    BBC1's The Voice, which starts at 7pm, clashes with Britain's Got Talent, beginning at 8pm on ITV, for a vital 20 minutes  but Sir Tom said: "The ratings war is out of our hands.

    "As long as we get a fair crack of the whip, then it is up to the viewers. At the end of the day it is always up to the viewers."

    He added: "With some other shows, like BGT, all kinds of talent comes on. But The Voice is purely about what people sound like  that's the unique thing."

    Sir Tom  on the show with fellow mentors Will.i.am, Jessie J and Danny O'Donoghue  had warmed up for tonight's ratings fight by taking a stinging swipe at Simon Cowell.

    The Welsh legend insisted ITV show guru Cowell was NOT a good judge of singers because he has NEVER had a go himself.

    Sir Tom said: "I have problems when people who have never got up on a stage to sing judge those who do. Who are they to say?

    "Simon Cowell is a record man, not a singer. How can someone give advice if he or she is not qualified?

    "The shows with judges from other areas of show business are all very well and good.

    "But The Voice is unique because the four coaches are all singers, can all make records and know what they're talking about."

    The Sex Bomb and It's Not Unusual star believes he already has five potential winners lined up. But he told The Sun he hated having to dash hopefuls' dreams.

    Tom added: "That's the hardest part  sending people home. I don't like that at all. I have never had to do that before in my life.

    "When I have watched other talent shows and seen people getting all emotional, I thought that it was just showbusiness.

    "But when you are there, you realise how difficult it is. You have their future in your hands. It's not easy. In fact I'm going to be in trouble when I get home. There was a Welsh girl singing a Linda Perry song, very similarly to the original. I didn't pick her.

    "But I did say to her she hasn't lost forever  she is young enough to come back next year."



    No swear Script



    MENTOR Danny O'Donoghue says he is having coaching  to stop himself swearing on The Voice live shows.

    The foul-mouthed rocker said: "I tend to curse a lot so forgive me when I get to the live shows.

    "I'm in training now for the next seven weeks to not curse on the live shows. I'm very passionate and I have a limited dictionary to express myself with." The Script frontman said he had been impressed by the "nerves of steel" singers on the show so far.

    He confessed he would not have had the courage to audition for a TV talent show.

    Irish star Danny, 32, added: "I think in the day we are living every phone is a camera, so kids are a lot less shy."

  • THE Voice coaches got the shock of their life when Sam Buttery stepped on to the stage  after they mistook him for a girl.

    The youngster sings Adele's Set Fire To The Train on tonight's opening auditions.

    Sporting a huge quiff and a very retro style, he revealed The Script frontman Danny O'Donoghue thought it was a female singing, until he turned around. He said: "When he saw me, he was like 'oh... you're a man!"

  • The Voice UK starts tonight on BBC1, 7pm

articles.articlebody:
SAUCY Tulisa Contostavlos follows up her notorious sex tape by cavorting in a sizzling NEW one  but this time she WANTS fans to get an eyeful.

Telly's X Factor judge, 23, flashes her cleavage as she frolics with pals on holiday  in a raunchy pop video.

At one point in scenes for her new single she even bends over seductively to lick up spilt ice cream.

Another hot encounter sees her tie a man to a bed  and write on his bare chest.

The video emerged just hours after X Factor supremo Simon Cowell insisted the former N-Dubz singer's job on the ITV1 show was safe despite the scandal over the leaked six-minute tape showing her performing a sex act.

He branded whoever posted it on the internet a "scumbag".

An insider said as tight-lipped Tulisa yesterday continued to keep her head down: "She was thrilled by the kind words Simon said."

Tulisa's only comment was a line from her debut solo single  which the new video plugs.

She declared on Twitter: "Forgive us for what we have done, 'cause we're young."

A pal said last night: "Tulisa is still devastated by what has happened and is keeping a low profile. She is mortified that so many people have seen what is such a private thing.

"She wants to move on and put this behind her  and hopes fans will now concentrate on her music."

The Sun told yesterday how the ex-boyfriend Tulisa says appears in the sex tape with her  Justin Edwards  told her lawyers last year he had no copies of it.

The rapper, who calls himself MC Ultra, said: "Even if I did, which I do not, I would have no desire to publish them, simply because I would find that ungentlemanly. I was brought up better than that."

l.holmwood@the-sun.co.uk

articles.articlebody:
SIMON Cowell's new TV rival Will.i.am has blasted The X Factor for letting down acts created by the show.

The Black Eyed Peas star  a coach on BBC1's The Voice  laid into the ITV series just hours before his show goes head-to-head with Cowell's other vehicle, Britain's Got Talent.

He reckons teen Cher Lloyd, who came fourth in The X Factor in 2010 and is signed to Cowell's Syco label, hasn't been allowed to reach her potential.

That's despite her debut album spawning two UK top ten hits including a No1.

Will said: "I love Cher Lloyd. She should have been the biggest star in the world. She should have had the coolest freaking music.

"It's like they put them out, juice them, juice them, juice them, and give people something to watch on TV.

"Then, who is making sure she has the right material? That is wrong."

Cher's album gets a US release next month but Will still reckons he will be more dedicated to helping the acts he guides on the UK version of The Voice, which kicks off tonight at 7pm.

He said: "I told every person on my team that I am going to try my hardest to see their career is jumpstarted or revitalised regardless of whether they win or not."

Will.i.am described the panel on The Voice  which also includes Tom Jones, Jessie J and The Script's Danny O'Donoghue  as like "hungry people fighting over a steak, the fangs are drawn". But the US producer does fear ruining a contestant's chances in the industry if he gets it wrong.

He said: "There is a fear of that. We could mess up these people's careers." Will.i.am, who is pals with Cheryl Cole, who he manages, admitted he would stop at nothing to win the show but was tight-lipped about which stars he will be inviting on to the series.

He said: "I don't want to reveal my tricks. I'm just trying to do as much as I can, I swear to God, including technology and people."

He confessed that show bosses asked him and Jessie J to ramp up their banter during filming to boost ratings but both refused. Will said: "Before the cameras went on before the first day they asked us to turn it up for TV and Jessie told me, 'I'm not going to do that for TV ratings, that's fake.'

"We said it to each other, then two days in the crews were like, 'Thanks a lot'  but then the banter was real."

Despite claiming he is mentoring four potential superstars, Will.i.am is worried about competing against "legend" Tom Jones because he knows every trick in the book.

He said: "I think I have about four people who are really big, out of the ten in my team  four big global artists.

"Out of all the singers, I am nervous about Tom's team. Me and my team, we have a lot of homework to do for the real live battles."

But he reckons TV viewers will vote for the acts purely based on their voice  after the huge success of Brit Adele.

He claims she forced people to forget about "the industry mould of the model figure".

articles.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S Got Talent kicks off tonight and it's full of surprises.

Judges Simon Cowell, Amanda Holden, Alesha Dixon and David Walliams are even lost for words at some of the wackier acts.

Zany Denis Egel travelled from Germany to sing Evanescence's Bring Me To Life wearing a black cloak, but threw it off to reveal a gold outfit, before releasing four giant gold sails from behind him.

Unfortunately one sail fell to the floor  prompting hosts Ant and Dec to intervene.

And things didn't go well for an African stilt dancer called Buba, from Margate in Kent who failed to impress the panel.

Simon deadpanned: "For me it was like having some insane nightmare."

But Amanda couldn't hold back the tears when a coachload of unemployed teenage lads from the South Wales valleys called Only Boys Aloud, bowled over all the judges with their performance.

In stark contrast BGT new girl Alesha told of the show's grossest moment  when a man bit into a cockroach on stage.

She said: "I was like, that's one thing you never thought you'd see in your lifetime."

She added that the chemistry between the judges was good  though they do bicker.

She told Capital Radio: "There is this preconceived idea that judging panels don't get along but this is my second one and on both of them I've got along with everyone."

articles.articlebody:
CHICO Slimani has had a bust up with Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean ahead of tomorrow night's show.

The Dancing On Ice finalist was upset after the Olympians ordered him to recreate his topless Sexy And I Know It routine.

The former X Factor star has complained his back and wrist are too sore to do the spectacular seat lift where he has to raise partner Jodeyne Higgins above his head with just one hand.

And he fears that because he is in a topless costume, viewers will think he's trying to win votes by showing off his muscles.

He said: "I got a phone call and they said, 'Chris and Jayne want you to do Sexy And I Know It for the tour and could you do it for the final?' I thought, 'Here we go... people are going to say he can't skate, he's getting his body out for the vote,' and I've had a real problem with it."

However, after asking fans what they thought, he reluctantly agreed.

He said: "Then I thought to myself, 'Let the voting public decide.' So I went on Twitter and said, 'I can't really tell you what I am doing but what's your favourite routine if I had to do it?'

"Around 99.9 per cent of them said Sexy And I Know It. So I thought, 'OK, let's do it then.'"

But Chico has insisted on changes to the dance moves as weeks of training have left him with a bad back and a weak wrist.

He said: "I am having nightmares about it, to be honest. I have a back problem that I've got from the show and in all the weeks it had to come back  it's this week.

"I can't do one lift, I've had to change it because of my wrist  it's the seat lift where your hand is right up her bum!

"I managed to get her so far up but they wanted it travelling and turning and my wrist can't handle it so we had to change it."

But Chico admits he is pleased with his second routine  he is skating to Happy Days and will be dressed as The Fonz. He said: "I'm doing Happy Days which I'm really happy about because I get to be The Fonz  I've spent my whole life trying to be cool and now I've become cool by default.

"The Fonz is here and I have to walk up to everyone and I was like, 'Can't I just skate it?' They were like, 'No'  it's that that's driving me crazy."

Finalists also have to prepare their version of Torvill and Dean's Bolero.

He said: "With the Bolero, where we create our own routine, we have got the people at the top of their game at our beck and call to make our dream a reality.

Chico, who is up against Matthew Wolfenden and Jorgie Porter, added: "In this final, there is no room for error.

"The skating level has come up to such an extent that one slip, one error, one fall, will highlight it to such a degree."

Louie said X Factor reject Chico did not have the experience to see off rivals Jorgie Porter and Matthew Wolfenden tomorrow night.

articles.articlebody:
DANCING On Ice star Jorgie Porter will perform the show's most dangerous ever stunt in a bid to win tomorrow night's Dancing On Ice final.

The Hollyoaks actress, 24, will be thrown up in the air by three male ice skaters, who will then spin around before catching her.

It is so dangerous that they have been practising with a carpet  which they keep dropping.

Until now Jorgie has wowed judges Robin Cousins, Katarina Witt and Louie Spence with her fearless approach to lifts and stunts with partner Matt Evers.

But the last lady celebrity skating in the competition admits she is suffering the first bout of fear about the daring trick for her final routine as she goes up against Chico Slimani and Matthew Wolfenden.

Injured skater Sylvain Longchambon, boyfriend of Jorgie's co-star Jennifer Metcalfe, is even making a comeback for the special stunt after recovering from a severe arm injury picked up in training.

Professional Mark Hanretty will also skate with them.

Jorgie, who has chosen Fame for her final dance, said: "There is definitely some scary stuff with my routine. We practised with a carpet and it absolutely collapsed and fell on the floor.

"I looked at it and went  'That's me!' I'm glad we practised with that first.

"There are three of them in a line, Sylvain, Matt and Mark, and I'm lying across them then they throw me in the air and spin around and catch me."

Jorgie was so terrified after they dropped the carpet that she made Jayne Torvill prove it was safe.

She said: "I was scared so I made Jayne do it first as well. She was really up for it. And she wanted to do the other parts too but the physio wouldn't let her.

"I've never said no, I've always been quite fearless throughout the show.

"But I thought they were lying when they were saying what they wanted to do with me. I thought, 'Is this a joke?'"

She added: "I still can't believe I'm the last girl standing.

"I think in days or weeks to come I'll be like, 'Oh my God, I did this'. At the minute I am just taking it in.

"I can feel myself crying my eyes out no matter what happens."

articles.articlebody:
LOOSE Woman Denise Welch has vowed to quit her famous heavy boozing sessions  for the sake of her career and love life.

The actress and presenter, who is about to tour Britain in stage show Steel Magnolias, has had a long-standing battle with drink and depression.

But Denise, whose new love, Lincoln Townley, has offered to show solidarity by quitting booze too, said: "I can't do theatre and hangovers, and also Lincoln and I are in a new relationship.

"He's not really drinking now either. We decided we don't want to jeopardise our relationship by alcohol so we are reining it in a bit.

"I'm not giving up partying and I don't want anyone to think I am, but I'm just going to calm things down.

"I have to be on top for this show. There are too many people to let down."

Denise split from actor hubby Tim Healy at Christmas. He revealed this month he is dating Joan Anderton.

She said: "It was like a weight off my shoulders when Tim and I announced we were going to split up.

"We both knew we had other partners so we just decided to go our separate ways and be happy."

articles.articlebody:
A CONTESTANT on TV dating show Take Me Out has received death threats from cyber bullies on Twitter.

Internet trolls have threatened to kill Charles Sherwin, 38, "bottle" him, put rats in his house  and even set fire to his farm.

Charles, 38, said: "I am scared for my family and my livelihood  it's terrifying."

The abuse started after the farmer from Cheshire appeared on the popular ITV1 show. "I woke up the next morning and I already had dozens of abusive messages on Twitter," he said. "I've had people saying they wished I was dead."

Charles now regrets agreeing to go on the show, hosted by Paddy McGuinness. He appeared for two consecutive weeks after being picked to go on a date with farmer's daughter Steph telling viewers how they failed to click last Saturday.

"If I'd known I was going to become one of the most hated men in the country I'd never have gone on," he said.

"People said I was arrogant, flash and vain  I'm not any of those things. It's horrible and upsetting. "I don't know what I did to upset them but I wish it would stop. It's just a shame people feel it necessary to send such poison.

"I only went on the show to find love. Now I doubt I'll ever get another woman to date me again."

j.atkinson@the-sun.co.uk

MATTHEW Wolfenden has caused a stink on Dancing On Ice  with his smelly skates.

The Emmerdale hunk's footwear has been QUARANTINED after the whiff got too strong as he sweats it out at rehearsals.

A show insider confirmed: "Matthew's skates have been banned from the same room as everyone else's because of the pong they were giving off."

And his skates are not the only part of his wardrobe causing problems.

Extra pairs of PANTS have had to be provided for him as he perfects his routine for the finals.

The actor is skating to Singin' In The Rain  and gets soaked with a water machine to recreate the famous film scene.

A source said: "Fresh pairs of boxers had to be called in to make sure Matt didn't catch a chill."

articles.articlebody:
EMMERDALE star Matthew Wolfenden says if he wins Dancing On Ice he will dedicate his award to fiancée and co-star Charley Webb.

The show favourite reckons the competition has been harder on her and their son Buster than it has for him.

Matt said of Charley, who plays Debbie Dingle in Emmerdale: "I see her go white before we go on the ice. They go through more turmoil than us.

"If I won I'd have to dedicate my award to my family who came down every week to see me.

"I always look out for Charley, then my mum and dad, when I get on the ice."

For tomorrow night's final, each contestant must perform a showcase routine, recreate their favourite from the series and prepare one based on Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean's Bolero. Only the top two finalists will get to skate it.

But Matt isn't sure he'll be lifting the trophy. He reckons the competition is too tight to call.

Matt, who will perform to Singin' In The Rain and Don't Stop Me Now, said: "If it was the judges picking a winner we might have some idea but because it's the public vote nobody knows which way it will go. Nobody knows how we will perform on the night. If somebody falls over, that's it.

"I know these shows can often be a popularity contest but this has genuinely gone down to talent.

"I couldn't have wished to have been in the final with two better people  and I think it is the right people in terms of the skating. Chico would be the first to admit he has made the clearest leap from when he started to where we've got to now, and Jorgie has been great from the start.

"But our boleros will show off our personalities. With me and Nina the routines are usually quite tricky and fast and we have lots of little tricks. Jorgie is graceful and beautiful so her routines are like that while Chico is quirky and funny."

There have been more injuries than ever this year but Matt will ignore the risks. He said: "You just have to go for it  we don't think about falls before going on the show."

The only thing on his mind tomorrow will be having a good time.

He added: "This will be the last time we are ever going to skate in front of millions of people live on TV.

"The competition comes second. It's just been brilliant  I've loved it."

article.caption: How the unsinkable Titanic met her end
Jenna-Louise Coleman can breathe a sci-fi of relief
'Cameron's film was a love story, my Titanic tells whole tragedy'
First look at iceberg disaster series Titanic

articles.articlebody:
WORKING on ITV1's epic new blockbuster Titanic gave two of its stars a sinking feeling  as they had already had their own watery dramas.

Jenna-Louise Coleman and Geraldine Somerville appear in the mini-series from Downton Abbey creator Julian Fellowes, which starts tomorrow.

Jenna-Louise, who this week was announced as Doctor Who's new companion, plays second-class stewardess Annie Desmond, who falls for one of the ship's waiters.

The former Emmerdale star recalled: "I was on holiday in Portugal when I was younger and I got stuck on a lilo that went way too far out to sea.

"It was very dramatic  my dad had to swim out to save me, so I know what it's like!

"It felt like I was in serious danger, but that's probably because I was young  about six or seven."

Geraldine, who starred as Lily Potter in the Harry Potter films, plays the snobby Countess of Manton in the new drama.

She said: "I have been on a boat that was sinking  I was swept out to sea on a dinghy when I was a child and it was absolutely terrifying.

"I was with my sister and we couldn't sail. I got in the water to try to swim to safety, but then I suddenly remembered Jaws!

"This was in the Irish Sea, so I really wasn't going to be killed by a shark, but even so I had this absolute terror and got back in the boat pretty quickly."

Geraldine continued: "It was really frightening  but the sea is. It's just so huge and we're not really meant to be there. Fortunately a lifeboat came and rescued us."

You will have to watch all four parts of Titanic to see if Jenna-Louise and Geraldine's characters have such a lucky escape.
articles.teaser: JENNA-LOUISE Coleman has revealed her own escape from the sea when she was a child
articles.headline: Titanic left us all at sea

articles.articlebody:
HOLLYOAKS student Ash Kane will be left fighting for life after being struck down with meningitis next week.

Pals of the party girl, played by Holly Weston, think she just has a hangover  until she collapses at her university halls.

Her loved ones will be left terrified that she will not pull through after she falls into a coma.

Speaking about the dramatic new twist, Holly said: "I think it's a very relevant storyline for Hollyoaks to do, because meningitis tends to affect younger adults.

"That's why they try to make people at university more aware of it."

Holly admits she has grown fond of her brash alter ego.

She said: "I love that Ash just doesn't care! As it's Hollyoaks, I'd wondered whether I'd have to wear loads of make-up and be dolled up all the time.

"But it's nice to be a bit different. It's fun to play a cooler, messier character."

articles.articlebody:
TAKE Me Out spin-off show host Zoe Hardman has tan-talised fans by copying Myleene Klass' famous outdoor shower.

The bronzed brunette, who fronts ITV2's The Gossip with Mark Wright, showed off her white patches as she cooled off from the African heat.

Wearing a zebra-print bikini, Zoe, 29, posed for these snaps while on holiday in Kenya, where her parents live.

And she saucily removed her bikini top for the final moments of her shower.

Zoe has previously revealed that an eating disorder almost destroyed her chances of having kids.

After she appeared as a contestant on Channel 4 dating show Playing It Straight in 2005, the star admits she became addicted to exercise and ate a low-fat no-carb diet.

She told Closer magazine: "I felt under pressure to look a certain way and dropped a lot of weight fast. Friends and family were really worried about me."

She started eating properly again when doctors warned her that her lifestyle could affect her chances of having a family.

articles.articlebody:
SPORT Relief is taking over BBC1 tonight and it promises to be to a televisual treat for all.

From 7pm many of the biggest names in sport and comedy will come together for a mammoth night of fundraising.

Hosted by stars including Gary Lineker, Davina McCall, James Corden, Claudia Winkleman, David Walliams and Miranda Hart, we can expect comedy sketches and musical guests galore.

Between 7-8pm, Frank Lampard and his fiancée Christine Bleakley try their hand at acting in a sketch with the Brockman family from Outnumbered, while boxer Amir Khan and footballer Jermain Defoe join the Horrible Histories cast.

Chelsee Healey and McFly's Harry Judd have a dance-off with a difference, with a Strictly Come Dancing underwater special.

Staying in the water, from 8-9pm, Frank Skinner faces his life-long phobia and attempts to swim a length of his local pool, plus David Walliams  who swam the length of the Thames for his own epic challenge  will be in the studio.

And award-winning comic Miranda Hart takes on Tiger Tim Henman in a tennis match with a difference, as she plays the former British number one at the Royal Albert Hall.

She also has hilarious encounters with a host of top sporting heroes, including Mo Farah, Robbie Savage and Roberto Mancini.

From 9pm, it's Benidorm's Got Talent, as the cast of the ITV1 sitcom try out in front of scary BGT judges David Walliams, Alesha Dixon, Carmen Electra and Simon Cowell to see if they've got what it takes to entertain the Queen.

Then members of the England football team, including Theo Walcott and Scott Parker, don their aprons to take on the Saturday Kitchen omelette challenge with chef James Martin.

Over on BBC2 from 10pm, it's Sport Relief by Royal Appointment, as Zara Phillips joins the cast of Olympic comedy Twenty Twelve, along with sporting hero Sir Steve Redgrave. And there are special instalments of QI and Never Mind The Buzzcocks, hosted by Formula 1 presenter Jake Humphrey.

Back on BBC1 from 10.35pm it's the Absolutely Fabulous special, which sees fashionistas Kate Moss, David Gandy and Stella McCartney joining regulars Eddie and Patsy and lining up alongside Olympic heroes Linford Christie and Colin Jackson.

And then as we move toward the late night fun, there will be special Sport Relief editions of Celebrity Juice, 8 Out Of 10 Cats and Mock The Week.

Musical guests playing in the studio will include JLS  with the official Sport Relief single Proud  Snow Patrol, LMFAO and Emeli Sande.

So settle back in front of the box, get watching  and get donating!
articles.teaser: BIG names including Jennifer Saunders, Miranda Hart, David Walliams and James Corden will be on the box tonight
articles.headline: The stars come out for Sport Relief
articles.subdeck: Having a laugh ... celebs will provide a little light Relief to raise money for charity tonight

image.caption: Geordie joker ... Cheryl Cole tweeted her congratulations to One Direction

article.caption: 2Shoes 'to lose 2 stone after scoring record deal'
Alesha Dixon's sky-thigh look for BGT
Simon Cowell: Voice rivalry is waste of telly fee

articles.articlebody:
CHERYL Cole has claimed One Direction's success is down to HER.

The boyband made history this week by bagging the number 1 slot in the US charts with their debut album, and former X Factor judge Cheryl has joked that they have her to thank.

She congratulated the lads on Twitter, and added: "Remember who really mentored you when @simoncowell wasn't there LMAO!! #proudofyouboys."

The Up All Night stars appeared on the 2010 series of the X Factor.

Cheryl was in charge of the girls category that year, while Simon had the boys.

And while the lads have flourished since, One Direction were pipped to first place in the show finale by Geordie singer Cheryl's act Rebecca Ferguson.

It'll be interesting to see what Simon, who signed the group to his Syco label last year, makes of his former best pal's claim.

He had earlier sent his own message to the triumphant boys, saying: "I couldn't be happier for @onedirection, it is an incredible achievement. They deserve it. They have the best fans in the world."
articles.teaser: AS One Direction bag US number one, Cheryl Cole says SHE was their X Factor mentor
articles.headline: Cheryl jokes One Direction's success is down to her
articles.subdeck: Geordie joker ... Cheryl Cole tweeted her congratulations to One Direction

image.caption: From ice star to author ... Chloe Madeley

article.caption: The Only Way Is Big Fat Strictly Downton Factor
Sam 'still Att it with Chloe Madeley'
Chloe Madeley's been made over
Chloe Madeley finds new Dirty Sexy Thing

articles.articlebody:
CHLOE Madeley is set to expose what she claims to be the "backstage bitchiness and corruption" of Dancing On Ice in a novella based on her experience of the programme.

Chloe, who came third in last year's series, has said that her time on the show has inspired her first foray into fiction.

The 24-year-old said: "Obviously, I will have to change the names for legal reasons, but it is based on what goes on behind the scenes of these contests.

"It started as a short story, but now it is at the stage of a novella."

Chloe went on to reveal that she felt like the relationships between judges and contestants were akin to those of teacher and pupil.

She added: "I don't know if it's coincidence or deliberate, but the judges kept their distance from us.

"They kept themselves pretty separate. It's a bit like school.

''We all gossiped like mad. We moaned if we were on the receiving end, but when we found out something about someone else we'd all be huddled in the corner smoking and swapping titbits."

During the show Chloe fell for eventual winner Sam Attwater but they split at the end of last year.
articles.teaser: STAR will expose the 'backstage bitchiness and corruption' of the show in novella
articles.headline: Chloe Madeley to reveal Dancing On Ice 'corruption' in tell-all book
articles.subdeck: From ice star to author ... Chloe Madeley

image.caption: False claims ... Jenna-Louise Coleman

article.caption: Jenna-Louise Coleman can breathe a sci-fi of relief
Jenna-Louise Coleman is the new pal for Dr Who

articles.articlebody:
ONLINE scammers are allegedly tricking people into visiting adult websites by claiming to offer a sex tape featuring Doctor Who actress Jenna-Louise Coleman.

Users going through to the websites have found there is no tape of the star and are at risk of downloading computer viruses, a report said.

It was announced earlier this week that Jenna-Louise, 25, is to join BBC hit Doctor Who this autumn.

And spammers were quick to exploit the sudden interest in the former Emmerdale actress on social networking site Twitter.

They sent out a flood of tweets with her name in, claiming to have a secret sex tape of the star, a newspaper reported.

But Twitter users clicking the links found they were taken to an adult website  which did not feature Jenna-Louise.

And watching videos on that website causes the user's Twitter account to start following another account without them realising.

This process, known as "clickjacking", can even be used to download dangerous software on to computers.

Sophos internet security expert Graham Cluley said: "The point is that you should always be cautious about the links which you click on.

"Of course, it's Jenna-Louise Coleman today and will be someone else tomorrow.

"Twitter spammers are simply grabbing the latest trending topics and shoving them in their tweets in the hope that users will stumble across them and fall into their trap."

Jenna-Louise is set to become the latest assistant to the Time Lord, played by Matt Smith, when Karen Gillan bows out later this year.
articles.teaser: ONLINE scammers trick Brits with false claims of footage featuring Doctor Who star
articles.headline: Twitter users hit by fake Jenna-Louise Coleman sex tape
articles.subdeck: False claims ... Jenna-Louise Coleman

image.caption: This was OK ... gay rights flag is flown at the town hall

article.caption: Pensioners' fury at council clash over solar panels
Parents banned from kids' football tournament
Council spends £100k on films about washing hands

articles.articlebody:
COUNCIL bosses were branded "a disgrace" last night for carpeting a worker who lowered the town hall flag after six British soldiers died in Afghanistan.

Weeks ago the same council flew a rainbow flag in support of gay rights.

But it could now SACK the employee, an ex-serviceman, for supporting Our Boys.

The man, whose military experiences left him with post-traumatic stress disorder, made his gesture after a Taliban bomb wrecked the soldiers' vehicle on March 6. On Tuesday, the day their bodies were flown home, he was served with disciplinary papers alleging "gross misconduct".

He is also being probed for failing to carry out a "thorough health and safety assessment" before flying the council's own flag at half-mast.

It highlights The Sun's Crack The Numbskulls war on council killjoys.

Friends now fear the unnamed worker, a Royal British Legion standard bearer, may harm himself because of Bassetlaw District Council's action in Worksop, Notts.

One said: "This is an outrage. The council knows about his stress disorder.

"They promote gay rights but have piled into an ex-serviceman for honouring six guys who died fighting for their country. This has sent the guy into bad depression." The widow of Gary Thompson, 51, the oldest serviceman to die in Afghanistan, called the council "an utter disgrace".

Jacqui Thompson, 45, of Nottingham, said: "How can showing respect to soldiers be misconduct? I applaud this man."

The council refused to discuss the case. But the flag of the local Mercian Regiment WAS at half-mast over the town hall yesterday in honour of a soldier killed on Wednesday. Five of the soldiers the worker paid tribute to served in the Yorkshire Regiment.

A council spokesman said: "We have a strong association with the Mercians. It is policy to lower the flag in the tragic event of loss of life."

a.parker@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: BASSETLAW Council branded 'a disgrace' for carpeting man who supported Our Boys
articles.headline: You mast be joking
articles.subdeck: This was OK ... gay rights flag is flown at the town hall

image.caption: Catching some rays ... personal trainer Tara Hammett at Langland Bay, near Swansea, south Wales

articles.articlebody:
BRITAIN is basking in glorious sunshine today  with temperatures soaring to more than DOUBLE the March average.

Thousands of sun-seekers headed for beaches and parks to soak up some rays as the mercury rose above 21C, making the UK hotter than the Costa del Sol and resorts in Portugal.

The warmest place in Britain was Swansea, south Wales, where 21.7C was recorded at lunch time - and daytrippers including personal trainer Tara Hammett made the most of it on the sandy beaches.

Forecaster Paul Mott said temperatures are well in excess of expectations for this time of year, and added the heatwave, caused by high pressure, is expected to continue tomorrow and into next week

He described the current spell of warm weather as "quite unusual" for March, and warned there was no significant rainfall in the drought-affected areas of southern England.

He said: "It's looking fine and warm for much of the coming week. It will last until at least Thursday or Friday and will probably be milder next weekend."

Gardeners at Cornish National Trust mansion Cotehele were celebrating today as the peak blossom time of their daffodils has coincided with their annual weekend celebrating the plant.

A spokesman said it is the first time in four years they have got their timing perfect for the two-day event.

Senior gardener Aimee Kingdom said: "It's a fantastic chance for garden lovers and families to see our wonderful collection of historic daffodils, including some varieties which are 200 years old."

At the National Trust's Cotehele estate in Cornwall, hundreds of people took advantage of the good weather to see more than 150 varieties of daffodils that grow in the grounds of the Tudor house.

For the first time in four years the annual daffodil weekend is taking place while the flowers are at their peak and the orchards and gardens at the property near Plymouth was bursting with colours.

Vicky Dillon, one of the gardeners at Cotehele, said the Tamar Valley in which the house and gardens are situated has its own microclimate.

This has historically made it excellent for growing anything from flowers to soft fruits like strawberries.

He said: "It was very much a market garden industry at one point and a lot of the daffodils were grown for the cut flower industry.

"The daffodils were thrown away into the hedgerows at one point in the Second World War when the land was needed for food and they have survived in the hedgerows and woodlands because of that.

"We were able to gather a large selection of the daffodils from the estate and preserve them for future generations so people can enjoy them.

"A lot of the varieties we have got in the gardens are what I call 'nice and delicate', they are not the big and blousy ones you see now; they are pastel shades, pale colours, very small flowers and they have their own character."
articles.teaser: GLORIOUS sunshine and baking heat expected to last into next week and beyond
articles.headline: Britain soaks up the sun as 21C heatwave hits - and it'll last
articles.subdeck: Catching some rays ... personal trainer Tara Hammett at Langland Bay, near Swansea, south Wales

video.caption: BOLTON face Blackburn in first match since Fabrice Muamba collapse

image.caption: Salute ... the fans' tribute to brave Muamba
Support for Muamba as Bolton win on return - Wanderers triumph in first game since star collapsed

articles.articlebody:
FANS and players paid tribute to stricken Bolton hero Fabrice Muamba as Wanderers won their first match since the stricken star's collapse.

The home crowd held up hundreds of banners to create a giant mosaic spelling out the 23-year-old's name and his shirt number before kick-off.

There were emotional scenes before and after the game which Bolton won 2-1 at the Reebok Stadium.

Bolton players wore shirts with "Get well soon Fab" on the front and his name and number on the back in tribute to Muamba during warm-up.

And at Arsenal - the club where Muamba started his career - fans unfurled an enormous banner showing their support.

It comes after the star suffered a near-fatal heart attack on the pitch last Sunday during Bolton's FA Cup quarter-final match at Tottenham.

A huge spread of tributes was also laid outside the Reebok Stadium this morning.

Earlier, Bolton chairman Phil Gartside wrote an open letter to fans thanking them for backing midfielder Muamba, who remains in hospital in London.

He wrote: "I am writing on behalf of Fabrice's family, to pass on to Wanderers fans and the people of Bolton their sincere gratitude and thanks for the love and support they have received from you.

"As I am sure you are aware, the response has been amazing with messages and gestures of support from all around the world, inside and outside of football.

"I have been humbled to witness first-hand the power of positive thought while spending time with Fabrice's fiancie Shauna and his father Marcel.

"They in turn have drawn great strength from all the kindness and concern that has been shown.

"I personally want to thank you all for the support you have given Fabrice's family and also pay tribute to our fans that were at White Hart Lane.

"Throughout those difficult moments they were dignified, resolute and an absolute credit not only to Bolton Wanderers, but football.

"Our club doctor Jonathan Tobin has said the only time anything ever broke into his consciousness while he was on the pitch tending to Fabrice, was when the Spurs fans joined in with our supporters and began singing Fabrice's name, 35,000 people willing him on, together.

"We will be at the Reebok today, together, to support Fabrice. He is still in intensive care and still in a serious condition but, as Owen has said, Fabrice is a fighter.

"I would ask you all to keep him in your thoughts and prayers."

Bolton manager Owen Coyle also spent much of the week at the London Chest Hospital, where Muamba was rushed following his cardiac arrest.

He added: "If Fabrice can show what a battler is, I am sure we can play a football match."

Muamba's family have also praised fans for their support since the player's cardiac arrest and said God had answered their prayers.

Marcel Muamba and Shauna Magunda expressed their "enormous gratitude" to the Bolton and Tottenham medical teams for their quick reaction and praised the "fantastic team" caring for him at the London Chest Hospital.

Mr Muamba and Ms Magunda said: "We would like to firstly thank God for answering our prayers.

"The support we have had from the fans - not just from Bolton but football supporters around the world - has given us so much strength."
articles.teaser: CLUB chairman Phil Gartside writes open letter to fans about hero midfielder
articles.headline: Fans show support for brave Muamba as Bolton return to the pitch
articles.subdeck: Salute ... the fans' tribute to brave Muamba

image.caption: Record ... Davina McCall and Dermot O'Leary announce £50m record

articles.articlebody:
GENEROUS Brits dug deep to donate a record £50million to Sport Relief during last night's charity telethon.

Celebs Gary Lineker, Davina McCall, James Corden, Claudia Winkleman, David Walliams and Miranda Hart hosted the evening of music and comedy.

Donations flooded in from across the country, with the total standing at £50,447,197.

Even more cash will be raised tomorrow, when more than a million people are expected to run the Sport Relief mile.

The money will be used to help disadvantaged people in the UK and worldwide.

Highlights of last night's show saw funnyman Frank Skinner come to grips with his fear of water, swimming just one length of his local pool.

After completing the challenge, Frank, 55, said: "I'm absolutely knocked out. I'm so relieved and excited. I lay in bed last night thinking about all the different ways I wouldn't finish that length.

"I want someone to learn to swim because of this. I know it looked really tough and frightening but I've had a good laugh and it will stay with me forever."

Benidorm's Got Talent saw the cast of the sitcom Benidorm auditioning in front of Britain's Got Talent judges David Walliams, Alesha Dixon, Carmen Electra and Simon Cowell.

But Cowell was unimpressed, saying: "I've done this a while and this was arguably one of the worst groups I've heard in my life."

Also some of England's top footballers, including current captain Scott Parker, Theo Walcott, Rob Green and Glen Johnson, donned their aprons for the Saturday Kitchen omelette challenge with chef James Martin.

And fashion-mad duo Edina and Patsy returned to the small screen with a one-off special of Absolutely Fabulous, with cameos from Kate Moss, Stella McCartney, Linford Christie and Colin Jackson.

Boyband JLS visited a hospital in Uganda and were moved by what they saw. Band member Marvin Humes said: "There are so many kids in here and they're all not well. It's amazing how young they are. It's just not right."

International Development Secretary Andrew Mitchell announced yesterday that the government will match £10million of public donations.

But the Premier League was slammed on Twitter for its "pathetic" donation.

The megabucks organisation, which boasted a turnover more an £1billion in the last financial year, donated just £250,000.

Viewer Beth Parker tweeted: "All the money the Premier League have and they only donate £250,000 to Sport Relief! What a joke!"

Another, Pat Eccles, added: "Congratulations to the Premier League for using all their resources and scraping together £250,000 for Sport Relief. Pathetic."

Other businesses were more generous, with Sports Direct and its customers managing £1million and Sainsbury's and its customers donating just over £4million.
articles.teaser: GENEROUS Brits dug deep to donate a record amount during last night's telethon
articles.headline: Brits dig deep to raise record £50m for Sport Relief
articles.subdeck: Record ... Davina McCall and Dermot O'Leary announce £50m record

image.caption: Explosive ... the grenade was removed by specialists

articles.articlebody:
A POLICE station was evacuated and a bomb disposal unit called after a woman brought in a HAND GRANADE.

She told officers the weapon, which dated back to the Second World War, was once owned by a relative.

Hampshire Police called for support from the Army after the device was taken into Alton police station last night.

The grenade, which contained explosive material, was safely removed.

A police spokesman said: "A member of the public attended the police station with a World War Two hand grenade.

"The area was secured by local officers while specialist advice was sought and then following this advice the Army attended.

"The grenade was then removed by an Explosive Ordnance Disposal unit.

"Although the risk to the public was low the grenade was found to contain an amount of explosives."
articles.teaser: COPS called in Army to remove the Second World War-era explosive weapon
articles.headline: Police station cleared after woman strolls in with a grenade
articles.subdeck: Explosive ... the grenade was removed by specialists

video.caption: A PASSENGER was killed and 27 others injured after horrific motorway accident
PASSENGER talks of horrific moment that a lorry hits broken down coach on motorway
PARAMEDIC Nathan Hudson talks of initial moments after motorway crash

image.caption: Tragic ... one bus passenger was killed in the crash
M-Way death smash: Bus Driver held - Arrest after one person killed and 40 injured on M5

articles.articlebody:
A PASSENGER was killed and 40 others injured - two critically - in a horror crash involving a bus and a lorry this morning.

Police said the bus had broken down in the slow lane of the M5 in the West Midlands when a lorry crashed into the back of it at around 6.30am.

This afternoon, the 49-year-old driver of the bus, from Birmingham, was arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving.

A 35-year-old man from Birmingham died at the scene of the crash.

Images from the scene showed an articulated lorry branded with Fowler-Welch Coolchain embedded into the rear nearside edge of a single-decker bus.

Several ambulances and other rescue vehicles were sent to the scene on the southbound carriageway between junctions three and four.

West Midlands Ambulance Service said 40 people had been assessed and treated at the scene, and 27 were taken to four different hospitals around the region.

A spokesman said: "While the majority of patients appear to be walking wounded there are a small number with potentially serious injuries."

West Midlands Police said no children had been involved in the accident and confirmed that the driver of the lorry was among those seriously injured.

The affected stretch of the M5 is likely to remain closed in both directions for a considerable time and motorists are being advised to find alternative routes.

Eye witness Paul Guppy said there were patches of heavy fog on the motorway at the time of the crash.

He said: "There were fog patches, because I was driving through it with my fog lights on. That area is renowned for having fog, there's a lot of low-lying land.

"It was quite horrendous at the time, and then it cleared. Whether the fog was a contributory thing, I don't know."

The bus seemed to have been hit from the rear and was leaning virtually intact against a crash barrier, he added.

Artwork on the side of the bus shows Laurel and Hardy with the words "This is another fine bus you've gotten me into" - a reference to the comedy duo's famous catchphrase.

It is branded with the livery of bus company Stagecoach, but the vehicle had been sold by the company to a dealer 18 months ago.

The accident comes a week after 28 people - including 22 children - were killed and 24 injured in a coach crash in a tunnel in Switzerland.
articles.teaser: BUS driver is arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving
articles.headline: Bus driver arrested as 1 person dies and 40 are injured in M5 crash
articles.subdeck: Tragic ... one bus passenger was killed in the crash

image.caption: Tears for her hero ... Christina Schmid recalls fateful day her husband Staff Sergeant Olaf died

article.caption: Commanding officer's tribute to 'six of our fallen brothers'
Christina Schmid: I had second miscarriage before Oz was killed
Hero's widow receives medal
Brave soldier's funeral held
Hero dies in blast on his last day

articles.articlebody:
WAR widow Christina Schmid read her hero husband's Tarot cards before his fateful tour  with nightmare results.

The burning Tower card, seen as the harbinger of doom, repeatedly cropped up.

It was one of a host of spooky premonitions she had both before and during hubby Oz's fatal five-month mission to the Afghanistan front line, where he defused 70 Taliban bombs.

Today Christina tells of the dreadful day he begged her to read his future  and the moment she saw his destruction in the cards.

In her own words, taken from her memoir about Staff Sergeant Olaf "Oz" Schmid, Always By My Side, she writes: "Oz asked me to do his Tarot cards.

"The Tarot was something I did very rarely, perhaps once every other year. I wasn't sure about doing it this time, but Oz urged me to and I agreed.

"I had done them since I was young and I seemed to be gifted. The card he chose to show the future was the Burning Tower. I did them again, this time for career, Oz chose the Burning Tower again. The worst card there is.

"It signifies death and endings, the worst outcome imaginable and entirely unavoidable. Everything you know gone in ruin or catastrophe.

Oz looked stricken. He said, 'I feel this is going to be a really bad year for me. I've got this feeling as if everything is slipping'.

"I tried to lighten it, saying, 'You'll probably just stub your toe when you're at work  you're always a screamer with loads of bad luck! Don't worry, it might just mean that you won't get a promotion or something'.

"'No', he said. 'It's not the card. That just confirmed what I already know and feel'.

"When it was my turn to choose a card I hoped I might get something that would lift the mood, but I was startled when I got it in my spread of cards, too.

"But then I got rebirth after, and the moon. 'See, hun  always light in the dark. Remember that', he said. I tried to hide my dismay. 'It's a dark time of year. Perhaps we're both just feeling it', I said.

" 'Let's be positive, forget the cards, we've got lots to look forward to', I chirped, waiting for him to follow my lead.

"He usually did, but this time Oz said, 'No, it's bad. I've got this feeling that if I go out after January or February, I'm not coming back. That's what my gut is telling me'. There was nothing I could say that would cheer him and the truth was it was hard even to try, because I felt worried too."

Despite the omen, devoted Christina put aside her foreboding when Oz was sent to the front.

During his dangerous deployment she would make a wish for his protection during the full moon.

But on the last full moon before Oz's return she inexplicably fell asleep with young son Laird and missed her routine.

She writes: "I woke around 4am, disorientated. I was fully clothed and Laird was asleep on me, in his pyjamas. As the realisation dawned that I had missed doing the wish for Oz, the moon had disappeared and I felt distraught.

" 'Oh my God, what have I done?' I whispered. 'I've done it every month. Why now?'

"I told myself it didn't matter, that it was just a bit of silly tradition, that I should forget it. But I couldn't."

Christina's foreboding grew to fever pitch shortly before Oz, who won a gallantry gong on his tour, was due home.

The spooky signs grew to the point where she says she KNEW he was dead even before the fateful news came with a knock on the door from two officers bringing confirmation.

She writes: "Two days before he was due to leave Afghanistan for home, Oz called again. I could hear immediately that he was low.

"He had been out of contact for several days and he sounded shattered. He said, 'Honey, I just feel really bad, I've got this odd feeling, like dread, I don't feel safe, it's bad. Have you got it too?' I had. In the pit of my stomach I felt a lurch as he spoke.

"I had been uneasy, anxious, and had a feeling of dread, but I didn't want to say that.

'You're tired,' I said. 'It's OK, you'll be back soon. Do what you did the last few months in the next couple of days, hun. You've got 48 hours left, that's all'.

" 'Honey', he said, 'I'm mentally and spiritually hammered, I'm hanging out. I've been away too long, worked too much.

" 'And if it's too much for me it's too much for anyone. But I can't let it show. I've got to keep positive and strong, they (the other men) have to trust me. If anything happens to me, I don't want them to blame themselves.

" 'I wish you could come and get me. I need you. Just come and get me now, honey'.

" 'I wish I could', I said, tears running down my face. 'But I can't. You've got to stop talking like this, you're just tired. You can push for 48 hours'. 'I need to speak to Laird,' he said. I handed Laird the phone and he went upstairs and they talked.

"When Laird gave the phone back, Oz said, 'I'm calm, honey, but I can't help how I feel. I don't think I'm coming back, 'cos I'm cuffing it now. I'm drained  it's hard to explain'.

"The next day I kept the phone beside me all evening, hoping he'd ring. I wanted to ring him but I couldn't, so that night I emailed  'Please email me, Don't go out on the ground tomorrow, cut the last day, don't do it.' He never got it."

That night Christina had a visitation in her dreams from another hero bomb hunter, Warrant Officer Gary "Gaz" O'Donnell, who had perished in the Afghan badlands disarming a Taliban device.

She writes: "I slept fitfully then I dreamed that Gaz O'Donnell was standing in front of me. 'Don't worry, Chris, I'm here to get him when he comes over,' he said. 'I'll hold him. I won't let go'.

" 'What are you on about?' I said. 'You've got no arms'. Gaz just looked at me and smiled.

"The next morning, Saturday October 31, 2009, I woke at 6.30am with a feeling I'd never had before. It was as powerful as thunder.

" 'It's today', I thought. 'He's going or has he gone yet?' I felt it so surely that it was in the floor beneath my feet as I got out of bed and in the air around me as I went downstairs.

"I felt numb, suspended in time, as I went through the motions of life. At nine I phoned my mum and told her I wasn't going to take Laird to his swimming lesson that morning. 'What's going on?' she said. 'You sound so quiet. Oz is home tomorrow, you should be happy'.

"I paused. 'He's not coming home, Mum, I know it'. "

Oz was killed, defusing a bomb, on Halloween while Christina was walking in the woods gathering her thoughts.

At the exact moment he died she wept uncontrollably.

Later in her book Christina reveals more spiritual happenings. She tells how Oz's spirit communicated with her through the spiritualist mum of a friend.

She writes what the spiritualist said: "He's saying, 'Coffee, white, one  man-up'. Oh, and what an awful taste, it's something like liquorice. What is that?' I smiled. 'His liquorice rollies, the menthol tips, he always smoked them. And that's how he talked'. She had his intonation exactly right.

"She always passes on an Oz message in his distinctive style.

"And it helps me to keep going and keeps me grounded."

d.willetts@the-sun.co.uk

Always By My Side, by Christina Schmid, is published by Century, £12.99. © Christina Schmid 2012. To buy your copy from the Sun Bookshop for just £10.99, with free p&p, call 0845 271 2136.
articles.teaser: WIDOW reveals spooky premonitions in book about her husband Sgt Olaf Schmid
articles.headline: War widow predicted death
articles.subdeck: Tears for her hero ... Christina Schmid recalls fateful day her husband Staff Sergeant Olaf died

image.caption: Strong stuff ... cider will hit £7.20

article.caption: PM's 40p a unit war on bingers
1m more will pay 40% tax
Budget 2012 offers crumb of comfort for workers
Shops to open for 24hrs on Sundays

articles.articlebody:
DAVID Cameron's war on binge drinkers was slammed by his backbenchers last night.

The backlash came as drinks firms threatened a legal challenge over the PM's idea that alcohol should be sold for a minimum 40p per unit  saying it breaches EU law.

It would end "buy one get one free" booze offers and set high-strength lager at a minimum £1.20 a canand set see a two-litre bottle of 9 per cent cider rise from £3 to £7.20.

Tory Philip Davies accused the PM of "living in cloud cuckoo land" to believe it will stem rowdy teen boozing.

He said as Home Secretary Theresa May unveiled the policy yesterday: "It's the nanny state running riot."

Conservative Therese Coffey said it could harm families who have to "budget carefully". And colleague Nigel Mills claimed more booze would be smuggled to the UK.

Furious drinks firms insisted the 40p tariff broke competition rules.

The Wine and Spirit Trade Association said last night: "Minimum pricing is illegal under European laws."

Labour's Eric Joyce, who drunkenly assaulted MPs in a Commons bar, said he was also against minimum pricing. He admitted on BBC's Newsnight: "This has no impact on people like me."
articles.teaser: PRIME Minster's 40p unit minimum for booze has been slammed by backbenchers
articles.headline: Cameron in 40p 'cuckoo land'
articles.subdeck: Strong stuff ... cider will hit £7.20

image.caption: Joker ... actor Sacha Baron Cohen as Borat

video.caption: KAZAKHSTAN national anthem replaced by spoof version from movie comedy

article.caption: Jagshemash!  Kazakhstan replace national anthem with Ricky Martin song

articles.articlebody:
KAZAKHSTAN'S sport stars were left in shock after their national anthem was replaced at a medal ceremony  by the spoof version from movie comedy Borat.

The side-splitting ditty from Sacha Baron Cohen's hit flick includes the lines "Kazakhstan's prostitutes cleanest in region" and calls other nations "run by little girls".

It was mistakenly played at a ceremony for the central Asian nation's shooting team in Kuwait.

Footage from the presentation shows confused gold medallist Maria Dmitrienko listening to the anthem before grinning.

The Kazakh team's coach revealed organisers accidentally downloaded the wrong anthem from the net.

Borat's parody also brags: "Kazakhstan  Number One exporter of potassium," adding: "We invented toffee and trouser belt". It invites foes to: "Come grasp the mighty penis of our leader."

The music gaffe was the second to hit Kazakhstan's sports stars this month. Ricky Martin's 1999 No 1 hit Livin' La Vida Loca was played instead of the country's official anthem called "My Kazakhstan" at a skiing event on their own soil weeks earlier.

m.wilkinson@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: THE country's sport stars were left in shock after hearing the spoof version from the film
articles.headline: Kazakh stunned
articles.subdeck: Joker ... actor Sacha Baron Cohen as Borat

article.caption: 1m more will pay 40% tax

articles.articlebody:
NOT a vote has been cast and already the Tories have managed to get taxes down.

Labour's surrender on 10 per cent extra cider duty is a triumph for David Cameron.

The Tories also blocked Labour's planned broadband tax.

Not a bad start as the Tories were clear winners on Day One of the election campaign.

In the Commons, Mr Cameron exposed Gordon Brown's weasel words over Labour's jobs tax.
