Mr Brown says the business world has been deceived by the Tories into thinking that Labour's National Insurance tax rise will cost jobs.

Business leaders say Mr Brown is patronising, "economically illiterate" and insults their intelligence.

Almost seventy of Britain's biggest employers  including one of Mr Brown's own advisers  say the Tories are RIGHT.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

Only in the warped world of Gordon Brown does raising National Insurance help unemployment.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn't hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in  and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.
articles.teaser: READ The Sun Says leader comment to see our take on pressing issues of the day
articles.headline: Sub standard

image.caption: Critical ... German Gorbuntsov
Banker gunned down in London - Exiled Russian in a coma after 'assassinatin attempt'

articles.articlebody:
A RUSSIAN banking tycoon was in a coma last night after he was gunned down outside his London flat by a "drive-by" hitman.

Exiled financier German Gorbuntsov, 45, fell in a hail of sub-machine gun bullets fired by the would-be assassin.

Blood was smeared all over the walls of the lobby of his exclusive apartment block and the bullets also took out chunks of the front door and smashed windows.

One witness to the terrifying shooting near the Canary Wharf financial district said Gorbuntsov seemed to be targeted by a drive-by gunman.

Bart Fogler, 27, who works on the front desk of a nearby block, said: "I heard from a resident the shots may have come from a car.

"I ran next door where I saw the shot man and his wife who was hysterical. I saw holes in his clothes.

"He was bleeding heavily. He was trying to stand but he fell to the ground."

Resident Lynette Johnson, 43  who saw the lobby after the shooting  said: "There was blood everywhere, all over the walls.

"The windows were smashed so he may have been shot through them."

Gorbuntsov  who used to own banks in Russia and Moldova  was last night under armed police guard in hospital where he was said to be critical but stable. His coma is medically induced.

It is thought he may have been targeted after he was named as a witness in the shooting of a Russian banker in Moscow in 2009.

He had apparently told his lawyer: "If I go back to Russia, they will kill me."

One neighbour last night said police told him Gorbuntsov knew the hitman.

The 54-year-old  who did not want to be named  said: "They mentioned that the attacker was known to the man who was attacked."

Former Kremlin adviser Aleksander Nekrassov said: "It looks like a contract hit because a sub-machine gun is not a weapon that would be used by some amateur."

The Met's Trident gang crime team were last night probing Tuesday evening's shooting in Byng Street, East London, which they are treating as attempted murder.

a.france@the-sun.co.uk

Pro killers on streets



THE attempted assassination of Russian Gorbuntsov is not the first time hitmen have struck in Britain.

In 2006 ex-KGB dissident Alexander Litvinenko, 41, was poisoned with radioactive polonium in London.

Russian authorities have refused to extradite the prime suspect, fellow former agent Andrei Lugovoy.

MI6 agent Gareth Williams, 31, was mysteriously found dead in a bag at his flat in Pimlico, South London, in August 2010. A couple seen there weeks earlier have never been traced.

And one of the most famous assassinations saw Bulgarian dissident Georgi Markov, 49, killed by ricin poison delivered by a pellet embedded in the end of a brolly on Waterloo Bridge in 1978.

The crime was never officially solved but years later two ex-KGB men said the Soviets were behind it.
articles.byline: By ANTHONY FRANCE and RYAN SABEY
articles.teaser: GERMAN Gorbuntsov in critical condition after being shot near Canary Wharf, east London
articles.headline: Former Russian banker shot
articles.subdeck: Critical ... German Gorbuntsov

image.caption: Thanks ... grateful Nicolle Marshall and quick-thinking coach driver Phil Forster

video.caption: HARDMAN footballer-turned-actor demonstrates CPR in 'Stayin' Alive' ad

article.caption: What would YOU do?
Coronary granny is saved by Holby City fan

articles.articlebody:
A HERO coach driver saved the life of a girl passenger after she had an epileptic fit and stopped breathing.

Phil Forster, 48, pulled over into a lay-by and performed CPR on Nicolle Marshall, 19, as she turned blue in front of terrified pals.

As he battled to revive the sick teen, his wife May, 51  on board as co-driver  leapt behind the wheel and drove the coach to meet an ambulance.

Phil  who is a St John Ambulance-trained first aider  saved laundry worker Nicolle as he drove fans of ice hockey team the Solway Sharks to a match in Sheffield.

The driver, from Carlisle, said: "We were on the A66 when one of Nicolle's friends said she had stopped breathing.

"I pulled over immediately and started doing chest compressions.

"She coughed and started breathing again.

"Someone had phoned for an ambulance so I said to May it would be quicker if she drove to Scotch Corner. We got there before the medics."

JOIN OUR CAMPAIGN FOR CPR IN SCHOOLS BY CLICKING HERE

Nicolle  who has made a full recovery  had a chance to thank Phil and May when they drove her to another Solway Sharks fixture last week. The teenager, of Dumfries, said: "I thanked them for all they did. I can't really remember the coach trip at all."

Solway Sharks secretary David Morrison  who was on the coach  said: "Phil's fast actions were amazing. I have no doubt he saved Nicolle's life. He and May were both quite superb."

It is the second time Phil  a coach driver for 12 years and a trained first aider for five  has saved a life. Five months ago he revived 18-month-old Jessica Howard after she choked on a grape in a supermarket.

He said: "It's all down to the training I've had."

r.perrie@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: A HERO coach driver saved the life of a girl passenger after she had an epileptic fit and stopped breathing
articles.headline: Sick girl saved by busman
articles.subdeck: Thanks ... grateful Nicolle Marshall and quick-thinking coach driver Phil Forster

image.caption: One-off .... Ferrari has promised never to build another like it

article.caption: The fastest Ferrari yet
Youtube Ferrari driver arrested for speeding
The 200mph new Lamborghini with no roof or windscreen
Yours for £1.5million  a 1953 Ferrari hydroplane

articles.articlebody:
ERIC Clapton has spent £3MILLION on having this Ferrari supercar specially built.

The Slowhand guitar idol, 66, was involved in the design of the one-off 202mph motor which does 0-62mph in 3.4 secs.

Fellow fans of the Italian marque got to briefly drool over the car as it went on show at a London dealership. But it caused such a sensation Ferrari had it whisked away on a low-loader.

Clapton, who is worth £125million, already owns a fleet of rare Ferraris.

His latest is based on a 458 Italia model  which cost £173,000 before it was completely rebodied. The revamped version does not even have an official name.

Ferrari has promised never to build another like it.

Thrilled Tim Burton  among supercar fans who glimpsed the beauty  said: "It caused a huge stir."

n.syson@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: GUITAR idol Eric Clapton was involved in the design of the one-off 202mph motor
articles.headline: Bet Ferrari goes like Clappers
articles.subdeck: One-off .... Ferrari has promised never to build another like it

image.caption: Strong pong ... the Corpse flower Amorphophallus titanum at botanic gardens in Kiel, Germany

articles.articlebody:
HERE'S one for those who kick the bouquet ... a monster flower that pongs of DEATH.

The aptly named Corpse flower, or Amorphophallus titanum only blooms for three days a year, if at all. It has a scent resembling rotting flesh to attract insects.

So it was a brave undertaking for visitors to venture close to the plant after it started flowering at a botanic gardens in Kiel, Germany.
articles.teaser: HERE'S one for those who kick the bouquet... a monster flower that pongs of DEATH.
articles.headline: Death petal
articles.subdeck: Strong pong ... the Corpse flower Amorphophallus titanum at botanic gardens in Kiel, Germany

image.caption: Counting the calories ... 'low-cal' heroes Mars and Coca-Cola are joining the fight against obesity

article.caption: My 8-year takeaway binge cost £25k...and my unborn baby's life
You wouldn't eat 13 teaspoons of sugar in one go... so why drink it?
The Beast: Britain's biggest beef burger
Man's waist measures more than his height
'I'm the world's worst yo-yo dieter'

articles.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity.

The number of calories in certain products made by soft drinks giant Coca-Cola will be cut by 30 per cent by 2014.

It will also pump more cash into marketing Diet Coke and Coca-Cola Zero, which contain no sugar, and increase their availability.

Mars bars will be cut from 300 calories to 250, and super-size "Grab Bags" of Walkers crisps, containing 263 calories, will be phased out and replaced with 185-calorie packs.

The move aims to take FIVE BILLION calories a day off Britain's national food and drink intake. More than two-thirds of adults and one in three 11-year-olds are now overweight or obese. Food manufacturers, supermarkets, pubs and caterers joined with the Department of Health yesterday to announce the "Responsibility Deal".

Producers including Hovis and Mr Kipling will slash calorie counts by 30 per cent across a third of their ranges.

Supermarkets will expand their healthy meal ranges and sandwich chain Subway will include five low-fat subs in its £3 lunch offer. Health Secretary Andrew Lansley hailed the plan as "a great step in the right direction," adding: "We all have a role to play."

Diet expert Dr Susan Jebb, of Cambridge University, said: "This programme is vital to tackle obesity. It's a very encouraging start, but it will take time to change the nation's eating habits."

e.little@the-sun.co.uk
articles.byline: By EMMA LITTLE, Health Editor and DANIEL JONES, Consumer Editor
articles.teaser: BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity
articles.headline: Top UK brands to go on 'diet'
articles.subdeck: Counting the calories ... 'low-cal' heroes Mars and Coca-Cola are joining the fight against obesity

image.caption: Set for boot ... Abu Qatada

article.caption: Exile hate preacher's web rants
Abu Qatada law ruse ruled out
May tries harder to kick out Qatada
Ken Clarke's torture jibe KOs May's Qatada talks
Give terror suspects MORE human rights

articles.articlebody:
BRITAIN may have to take back hate preacher Abu Qatada after he has been kicked out, Home Secretary Theresa May warned yesterday.

She admitted the deportation was "taking time"  but if she rushed sending him home to Jordan, European human rights judges could demand his return.

Britain has been banned from deporting the terror suspect, 51, to his homeland after he claimed they tortured witnesses.

The Strasbourg ruling led to him being bailed after 6½ years behind bars.

Mrs May has met officials in Jordan seeking a guarantee they will not use evidence from torture.

She said she wanted to make sure Qatada's deportation cannot be reversed before acting.
articles.teaser: BRITAIN is banned from deporting the terror suspect to Jordan amid claims of torture
articles.headline: 'Abu Qatada's exit could backfire'
articles.subdeck: Set for boot ... Abu Qatada

image.caption: Wounded ... cop taken from raid by medics

article.caption: Dead...but why did cops let siege beast kill 7?
Toulouse killer is dead as 32-hour siege ends
French cops 'prepare to storm siege flat'
Gun fiend filmed school bloodbath for sick kicks
Hunt for 'Nazi' soldiers after four are killed in France school shooting

articles.articlebody:
THE brother of the al-Qaeda maniac who massacred seven people including three kids has said he is proud of the killing spree.

Abdelkader Merah, 29, was arrested as cops cornered crazed Mohammed, 23, in his flat and shot him dead.

The older brother is also linked to militant Islamic groups and is being held over alleged terror offences with his girlfriend and mother.

He told cops: "I am very proud of my brother. I regret nothing for him and approve of what he did."

His chilling comments came as new pictures were released yesterday of Thursday's raid in Toulouse in which Merah was gunned down by French special forces. Four cops were wounded during the 32-hour siege and one was shown being stretchered away.

Officials last night said an autopsy on Merah showed he died of two bullet wounds to the head and stomach  but was hit by 20 bullets, mainly in the arms and legs.

The terrorist staged a bloodbath at a Jewish school on Monday  killing a teacher, his sons aged five and three and the head's daughter aged eight. The week before he killed three off-duty soldiers.

Police believe Abdelkader may have known about his terror plans.

The brothers were involved in a militant network known as the Toulouse group which allegedly hatched a plot to attack a shopping centre in the city.

French PM Francois Fillon yesterday defended security agencies who left self-confessed alQaeda terrorist Merah at large to kill. He said: "There was no single element to allow for his detention."

Meanwhile, an English teacher sparked outrage across France yesterday after calling for her pupils to observe a minute's silence for "unhappy" Merah. There were calls for Lorraine Collin, 56, to be suspended from her high school job in Rouen.

- EUROPEAN security officials yesterday warned of the growing danger of home-grown Islamic militants who act independently of known terror networks.

n.parker@the-sun.co.uk
articles.byline: By NICK PARKER, Chief Foreign Correspondent
articles.teaser: CHILLING comments come after Mohammed Merah kills seven people in massacre
articles.headline: I'm proud my brother killed kids
articles.subdeck: Wounded ... cop taken from raid by medics

image.caption: Chat ... David Cameron and freed kidnap victim Judith Tebbutt

article.caption: Kidnap Judith flies home
Cry freedom
Somali pirates release kidnapped Brit Judith Tebbutt
Ed's HQ burgled..no policies found

articles.articlebody:
A MEMO advising the PM on how to talk to freed British hostage Judith Tebbutt was found at a railway station.

An aide to David Cameron dropped the "script" as he got off a train at Leeds on Thursday.

Hours later he was due to chat to kidnap victim Judith, 56, on the phone.

The memo, addressed to the Premier, offers detailed points from the Foreign Office on what to say.

One suggests he should remark: "I am delighted to be able to speak with you, Judith. I cannot imagine what you have experienced over the past six months.

"I have closely followed your ordeal from the outset and I am thankful you have been released safely."

Another mentions Judith's son Oliver, 25, who organised a reported £800,000 ransom payment to the Somali pirates who snatched her. They shot dead her husband David, 58, in a raid last year on a resort in Kenya.

The memo suggests the PM should tell her: "Please accept my condolences on the tragic death of your husband."

Judith, of Bishop's Stortford, Herts, landed at Heathrow Airport last night.

It appears Mr Cameron kept to his script. On Thursday he told factory staff at her hometown of Ulverston, Cumbria, that he found her "courageous, brave and resolute" during their telephone conversion.

A source said: "If she finds out the conversation was pretty much scripted then I can't imagine she will be very impressed."

The PM's spokeswoman insisted the memo had "no sensitive information".

r.perrie@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: A MEMO advising the PM on how to talk to freed British hostage Judith Tebbutt was found at a railway station
articles.headline: Aide loses PM's freed Brit memo
articles.subdeck: Chat ... David Cameron and freed kidnap victim Judith Tebbutt

image.caption: Fury ... George Osborne's fuel tax is unpopular with MPs and motoring chiefs

article.caption: Madness of snacks tax
Bandit George has robbed our bandits
So nasty to hit pasties
PM's 40p a unit war on bingers
1m more will pay 40% tax
Osborne: Elderly will not lose out

articles.articlebody:
MOTORISTS last night called on the Chancellor to make a U-turn on fuel  as petrol prices soared above 140p per litre for the first time.

Unleaded hit a staggering record AVERAGE price of 140.2p.

It means the cost of filling up a typical 70-litre family Mondeo is more than £98.

Diesel raced to an all-time high of 146.72p. On the M4, it's 154.9p.

Motoring chiefs and furious MPs said the rise made it all the more unbelievable that George Osborne was pressing ahead with a 3p duty hike in August.

The AA said it meant TWO-THIRDS of the Budget's increase in personal tax allowance would be swallowed up by fuel price rises.

Tory Robert Halfon said: "If we stand up for hard-working Britons and get the UK moving again, cutting petrol prices must be the number one priority."
articles.teaser: MOTORISTS last night called on the Chancellor to make a U-turn on fuel  as petrol prices soared above 140p per litre for the first time.
articles.headline: Fuel plea as petrol hits 140p
articles.subdeck: Fury ... George Osborne's fuel tax is unpopular with MPs and motoring chiefs

image.caption: Campaign ... clock tower

article.caption: Queen's historic speech praises Brits and Duke

articles.articlebody:
DAVID Cameron, Ed Miliband, Nick Clegg and Boris Johnson joined forces last night to back calls to name the Big Ben clock tower after the Queen.

The four spoke out after The Sun's "Big Ben v Big Liz" story yesterday revealed a cross-party bid to change its official name to Elizabeth Tower.

The PM believes it is a perfect way to mark the Diamond Jubilee. Mr Cameron said: "It's a really great idea and would be a fitting tribute."

Deputy PM Mr Clegg added: "The Jubilee is an occasion the whole country is keen to celebrate."

Labour leader Mr Miliband told The Sun it would recognise Her Majesty's "amazing service".

London mayor Mr Johnson added: "I think this is an excellent way of honouring Her Majesty." The man behind the campaign, Tory MP Tobias Ellwood, stressed the tower would continue to be known to millions as Big Ben, after its 13.5-ton main bell.

But he said it would be a fitting honour to change its official name.

A similar tribute was paid to Queen Victoria in 1860 when Parliament's King's Tower was changed to Victoria Tower. A Commons motion backing the Elizabeth Tower was unveiled yesterday.
articles.teaser: PM David Cameron joins clamour for Elizabeth Tower
articles.headline: It's Big Liz time
articles.subdeck: Campaign ... clock tower

image.caption: LEAP OF FAITH ... Aguero is so happy he made City switch

article.caption: Nasri: City won't bottle it
Mancini's desperate
Tony's Mancini fear

articles.articlebody:
SERGIO AGUERO has handed Manchester City a title boost by insisting he has no interest in joining Real Madrid.

The Spanish giants have been linked with a summer swoop for the £35million striker following his sensational first season in English football.

But Aguero  who has 24 goals to his name already this term  says he plans on staying at the Etihad for the long term.

The Argentine ace wants to mark his first year with a Premier League title medal and hopes it will be the first of many in a sky-blue shirt.

City's top scorer said: "None of the stories about Real Madrid have come from me and the City fans can rest assured I am happy here.

"First and foremost, the major aim is to win the league title this season. Then I want to stay here for a long time after that.

"I'm very, very happy here. From the moment I arrived, everyone has treated me really well.

"It's down to me to repay that kindness and good feeling I've had from everyone with some performances out on the field."

City have nine games left to try and edge out champions Manchester United  meaning Aguero still has plenty of time to add to his haul. He is excited by the return of fellow Argentinian Carlos Tevez and hopes it can help him reach 30 goals for the season.

Aguero said: "It would be lovely to score 30  but the most important thing is the team getting the right results at the end of the day.

"The main thing about scoring is not setting targets for yourself but scoring the goals that win points for the team."

Tevez made a sensational comeback after six months on the sidelines by creating the winner for Samir Nasri against Chelsea in midweek.

And while Aguero, Mario Balotelli and Edin Dzeko have carried City through in his absence, the former skipper has been welcomed back.

His countryman believes the experience Tevez has of English football can be crucial over the last nine matches.

Aguero, 23, said: "He was really keen to play, he was bursting to get out there on the field. We all know he's an important player for us, a key player. With the nine games remaining in the season, I think he can bring a lot to the side.

"If and when selected, I think it's an important time for him to come back.

"He's got five years' experience of playing in the Premier League.

"We have a lot of good players here and he is one other player. But he will be very, very important to us because he's one in a long list of top-quality players at this club. He will bring a lot to the party for what remains of the season."

Balotelli looked out of sorts against Chelsea, while a question mark still hangs over the future of Bosnian hitman Dzeko in the summer.

All three have played their part for City this season  but Aguero believes Tevez will freshen things up.

He said: "Through what happened and the situation that came about, I've not had much chance to play with Carlos.

"But what we have done between the three of us  myself, Mario and Edin  is to give a good account of ourselves in terms of goalscoring. We've done fairly well but it would be nice to have Carlos on board to add goals to the threesome.

"But it's down to the manager and hopefully he continues to pick me."

City's late comeback to beat Chelsea 2-1 at the Etihad on Wednesday was the sort of triumph which rivals United have mastered over the years.

And Aguero reckons it was proof that City have what it takes to go all the way and lift the title on May 13.

He said: "That's what it's all about in a title race, not giving up.

"We are fighting for the title, we have confidence.

"We're the sort of team who know if we go behind we can come back and win the game.

"The key is we are in a position now where we can't afford to drop any points. Manchester United are quite experienced in these title chases but we have to focus on ourselves.

"We have dropped a few points here and there along the way but that's in the past. We are playing well and we must carry on in that vein and concentrate on not letting more points go  that's the key to it."
articles.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: ARGY star insists stories linking him to Madrid have not come from his camp
articles.headline: Aguero: I stay
articles.subdeck: LEAP OF FAITH ... Aguero is so happy he made City switch

image.caption: PETER'S PERFECT ... Crouch's stunning volley gives Stoke City the lead
REST YOUR BUM TIME ... Carlos Tevez takes his place on the bench
TOURE DE FORCE ... Yaya Toure slams in the equaliser for Man City
HANDY WORK ... Stoke's Marc Wilson tries to muscle Man City's David Silva off the ball
JUMP TO IT ... Stoke's Peter Crouch is challenged by Man City captain Micah Richards
GOING POTTY ... Stoke fans celebrate their first goal by mocking 'The Poznan' celebration of the Man City fans

articles.articlebody:
PETER CROUCH smashed a wonder goal to shell-shock Man City.

But Yaya Toure hit back with a long range strike of his own as Roberto Mancini's side edged back in front of their arch rivals in the red half of Manchester.

What little action happened in the first hour was all but forgotten when Crouch delivered a stupendous two-touch control and volley from 30 yards that flew over Joe Hart and became the main - if not ONLY - contender for goal of the season.

The game has started in timid fashion. The injured Sergio Aguero was replaced by Edin Dzeko and Carlos Tevez was again on the bench but the visitors did control the early possession.

But it was not until the ninth minute that Gael Clichy found space to deliver a ball into the Stoke box but Asmir Begovic claimed easily.

Stoke had their first opening after a free-kick was crossed to the back post for Crouch but Cameron Jerome was unable to turn his downward header goalwards.

At the other end, David Silva and Pablo Zabaleta both had efforts deflected wide and Yaya Toure shot over from distance.

Dean Whitehead was given a talking to by referee Howard Webb after catching Silva with his arm challenging for a high ball, with play held up while the Spaniard received treatment.

Stoke almost took the lead in the 41st minute when a Matthew Etherington corner was met by a deft glancing header from Ryan Shawcross but Pablo Zabaleta cleared off the line.

Mario Balotelli broke through as the first half went into injury time but shot tamely at Begovic.

Dzeko had a chance to break the deadlock in the opening minute of the second half as he controlled a lofted pass from Barry, but he could not get it down quick enough to round Begovic.

Cameron Jerome was replaced by Jermaine Pennant in the 51st minute and Hart was forced to block an effort from Walters at point-blank range.

Stoke claimed the lead with a sensational strike from Crouch just before the hour.

A long clearance from Begovic was headed on by the lanky front man, before he took the return from Pennant, flicked it up and twisted to volley over Hart and into the top corner.

Mancini reacted by sending on Adam Johnson for Silva and then Tevez for Barry in the hope of gaining more width.

But it was Yaya Toure from a central position - a non-threatening 35 yards out - who sledgehammered in the equaliser.

The Ivorian's firecracker caught the head of Shawcross and it was enough to wrong-foot Begovic and slam into the net.

Pulis introduced Wilson Palacios in place of Etherington to shore up his side and Shawcross came close with a header that looped agonisingly over.

Yaya Toure came close at the death but another powerful effort from the all-action midfielder flew just over the top.

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS AVAILABLE FROM MONDAY
articles.teaser: PETER CROUCH smashed a wonder goal to shell-shock Man City but Yaya Toure hit back with a long range strike of his own as Roberto Mancini's side showed they are well up for the fight
articles.headline: Stoke City 1 Man City 1
articles.subdeck: PETER'S PERFECT ... Crouch's stunning volley gives Stoke City the lead

article.caption: Bolton 2 Blackburn 1

video.caption: OWEN COYLE reveals ill Bolton star sent good luck note to team-mates
BLACKBURN boss claims emotion of the day caught his players out in first half

image.caption: IN OUR THOUGHTS ... Coyle says Bolton were buoyed by Muamba's message

articles.articlebody:
OWEN COYLE says a private message from Fabrice Muamba inspired Bolton's basement-battle victory.

Midfielder Muamba, in intensive care following his cardiac arrest at Spurs last week, wished his team-mates good luck for Saturday's emotional visit from Blackburn.

And David Wheater netted two goals for the first time in his career as the Trotters beat their in-form drop rivals 2-1 to move out of the bottom three.

Bolton boss Coyle said: "Fabrice managed to send us a message yesterday through one of the consultants to say he wished the lads well.

"It was great when we heard that.

"Our chairman has been in touch with (Fabrice's dad) Marcel this week and I am pretty sure the information about today's game has been passed on to Fabrice."

Coyle expects Marcel and Muamba's fiancee Shauna to tell the popular star, 23, that the Trotters are now on course to stay up.

The Bolton chief declined to say what words his team exchanged as they huddled together in victory.

He said: "It is a private thing. I wanted to thank everybody for their efforts.

"It has been an emotional week and the players were out on their feet at the end, both physically and mentally.

"But that is a small thing compared to the fight Fabrice has got."

Coyle added: "The team talk wasn't long today. Nothing is more important to us than Fabrice.

"If he is able to recover and have a great life with Shauna and his son Josh, that will be fantastic.

"But, God willing, he is able to play football again at this level, and if it is, our aim is for him to do that as a Premier League player."

Blackburn boss Steve Kean, who was equally dignified, said: "I told the lads to separate the occasion from the game.

"We wish Fabrice all the goodwill we can give but we had to play the match.

"The Bolton players had a spring in their step and once they got their noses in front it was difficult."
articles.teaser: OWEN COYLE has revealed that a private message from Fabrice Muamba inspired Bolton's basement-battle victory
articles.headline: Fab wished us luck
articles.subdeck: IN OUR THOUGHTS ... Coyle says Bolton were buoyed by Muamba's message

article.caption: Chelsea 0 Tottenham 0
It's Harry Redcap!
Redknapp: What a load of nonsense

video.caption: SPURS boss says team must not take eye off ball if they want Champs League
BLUES boss claims says the Benfica game will be hard physically on stars

image.caption: POINTS TARGET ... Harry Redknapp

articles.articlebody:
HARRY REDKNAPP celebrated a crucial point  and set his side a target of SIX wins in eight to make the Champions League.

After drawing 0-0 with Chelsea at Stamford Bridge, Spurs are now FIVE games without a win.

But Redknapp feels they have an easier run-in than their London rivals, who remain their closest top four challenger.

Redknapp said: "We've got decent games, I think, not easy games, all hard games.

"We've got to make sure now that we win six out of the last eight anyway, if we can. You'd like to think we've got a chance of that."

Blues stand-in manager Roberto Di Matteo conceded his side now had their work cut out to leapfrog their London rivals.

He said: "To make the gap up, we would have to win all of the last eight games. I'm not sure it's as easy as that.

"You look at the scheduled fixture list and you just have to try to win the next one."

Tottenham could have ended 22 barren years at Stamford Bridge had Emmanuel Adebayor and Rafael van der Vaart not missed virtual open goals.

Redknapp added: "The longer it went, I felt like we were getting at them and I could see us winning it, really.

"I think they were probably more happy at the end to hear the whistle than we were.

"We were getting corners, free-kicks in dangerous positions, and I thought the keeper's made a couple of good saves."

Di Matteo did gripe about ignored penalty appeals when Ramires went down after colliding with Benoit Assou-Ekotto.

He said: "Assou-Ekotto just pulled him down because he wasn't aware of him. It wasn't a doubtful one  that was an absolute penalty."
articles.teaser: HARRY REDKNAPP set his Tottenham side a target of six wins to clinch a Champions League spot ahead of Blues
articles.headline: Six from eight will hit the spot for Spurs
articles.subdeck: POINTS TARGET ... Harry Redknapp

image.caption: EYES DOWN ... Steven Gerrard cracks in a shot under pressure from Gary Caldwell
PUTTING HIS FOOT IN IT ... Martin Skrtel concedes a penalty
AIR WE GO ... Steven Gerrard loses out to James McCarthy's acrobatic challenge

article.caption: Kenny keen to learn from mistakes
I would not swap cup glory for a top 4 place*
Paul Scharner hopes Wigan survive after equaliser

articles.articlebody:
GARY CALDWELL was the unlikely hero as Wigan piled on the misery for Liverpool.

The Latics defender displayed a striker's touch with a superb second-half winner to give Roberto Martinez's men a boost in their battle against the drop.

But it is Liverpool who are showing relegation form as they slumped to a fifth defeat in six games.

Luis Suarez struck their goal as he cancelled out Shaun Maloney's opener from the spot. But Caldwell's strike left the home fans frustrated once more with just five league wins at Anfield all season.

Liverpool once again struggled to find any fluency early on and Wigan gave them a scare when Victor Moses ghosted past Jose Enrique to fire in a shot that Martin Skrtel did well to block.

Steven Gerrard bobbled a shot wide for the hosts before Stewart Downing's effort whistled wide after he exchanged passes with Suarez.

But the Reds were stunned when Skrtel gave away a penalty as he swung a boot at Jamie Carragher's aimless headed clearance and caught Moses in the face.

Referee Lee Mason pointed to the spot and, after a couple of minutes' delay for Moses to receive treatment, Maloney tucked his penalty past the goalkeeper's right hand.

Five minutes before half-time Liverpool finally forced Ali Al Habsi into a save when Suarez's 25-yard curling effort was tipped around the post.

Despite returning to the field Moses was replaced by Albert Crusat before the interval.

Another Gerrard shot forced Al Habsi to palm the ball behind but from the corner Jordan Henderson's dipping shot was easily claimed by the goalkeeper.

Henderson, who had incurred the ire of Anfield on a number of occasions, was replaced by Andy Carroll for the second half.

But it was Liverpool's two most reliable attacking forces Gerrard and Suarez who combined for the equaliser just two minutes after the restart.

Skrtel's sliding challenge reached Dirk Kuyt on the edge of the penalty area and he bounced a pass back to Suarez who played the ball to Gerrard on the right and continued his run to convert the return with a shot across Al Habsi.

Liverpool should have been ahead in the 53rd minute when Skrtel's downward far-post header bounced over Al Habsi but Suarez, under pressure from Gary Caldwell, inexplicably punched the ball over the line when he was so close to the goal he could have let it hit him and it would still probably have gone in.

The Reds were made to pay in the 63rd minute when Carroll's header defending a free-kick dropped to James McCarthy just outside the area.

His shot deflected off Carragher to Caldwell, who showed composure not usually befitting a centre-back in front of goal to sidestep Carroll and fire past Reina.

Jonjo Shelvey's 74th-minute arrival for Downing allowed Gerrard to move into a more advanced position.

With seven minutes to go Raheem Sterling, signed from QPR for £600,000 just over two years ago, was given his debut as a replacement for Kuyt.

The youngster had one good run along the edge of the 18-yard box which almost set up a shooting opportunity but it was asking a lot for the teenager to have an impact on a game in which a number of his vastly more experienced team-mates had failed to impose themselves.

At the final whistle Wigan's small band of travelling fans were ecstatic but the pervading feeling at Anfield was one of growing discontent.

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS AVAILABLE FROM MONDAY
articles.teaser: GARY CALDWELL was the unlikely hero as Wigan piled on the misery for Liverpool
articles.headline: Liverpool 1 Wigan 2
articles.subdeck: EYES DOWN ... Steven Gerrard cracks in a shot under pressure from Gary Caldwell

image.caption: GRET IN THERE! ... Bolton hero David Wheater celebrates with Rafn Steinsson
WHEATER NICKS IT ... defender puts Bolton in front
WHEAT TREAT ... ace David Wheater gets his and Bolton's second goal
ZI GLEE ... Steven Nzonzi bundles Blackburn back into it

article.caption: Steve is Kean to be mean
Karren Brady's football diary
Fab opened his eyes, saw me and said: 'All right, Nige..?'

articles.articlebody:
DAVID WHEATER'S first-half headed double lifted Bolton out of the drop zone on an emotional day - and halted Blackburn's revival.

Steven Nzonzi nodded Rovers' consolation in a contest charged with feeling as it was Bolton;s first match since Fabrice Muamba's collapse last weekend.

StBolton manager Owen Coyle named an unchanged line-up from his side's last Premier League game as the Lancashire side aimed to put the emotion generated by Fabrice Muamba's cardiac arrest last week to one side against Blackburn at the Reebok Stadium.

With Muamba still in intensive care, none of Coyle's players took up the option of sitting the game out, instead committing themselves to try and gain three valuable points in pursuit of top-flight safety.

Blackburn have adopted a respectful tone in the build-up, but Steve Kean's men were chasing a third successive win and were also unchanged.

The Bolton supporters applauded from the moment the montage of Muamba began, right through until the handshake, a stand full of placards reading 'Muamba 6' held up opposite the directors' box.

It was soon evident the Bolton fans would be in full voice and Mark Davies fed David Ngog, whose cross was scrambled out of the Rovers penalty area.

Martin Petrov was inches away from finding Ngog with an intelligent through-ball that ended up running on to Paul Robinson.

Petrov let fly himself a couple of minutes later and Robinson had to watch the ball carefully in flight before beating it away.

There was little doubt Petrov was keen to make an impression and the Bulgarian shrugged Jason Lowe off the ball rather too easily, only to roll a disappointing shot wide of the far post.

Bolton keeper Adam Bogdan was thankful Davies was on hand to clear after he dropped Robinson's deep free-kick in a packed penalty area.

Ngog got his head to a Petrov cross at the other end, but his effort lacked power and Robinson gathered with ease.

Martin Olsson's diving header turned Petrov's deep cross away for a corner, which Bolton could make nothing of.

Blackburn should have had a penalty when in-form striker Junior Hoilett went charging into the box and was nudged over by Gretar Steinsson.

TV replays showed there had been contact with the man, and none with the ball, but referee Andre Marriner waved play on.

Bolton were indebted to Tim Ream, who slid in to ensure Yakubu did not get on the end of a Marcus Olsson cross that looked like presenting him with a tap-in.

And they immediately profited when Petrov crossed from the right and Steven Nzonzi only succeeded in flicking it on to David Wheater, who seemed as surprised as anyone when the ball ended up in the bottom corner.

Pratley was just off target as Bolton tried to press home their advantage, although Yakubu was inches away from equalising as he rose to meet Olsson's cross with a powerful header that just went wide.

Petrov's shot was touched behind by Robinson, which only offered Bolton the chance to cause more damage from the corner.

And this time there was no look of surprise as Wheater profited from Ryo Miyaichi's cross to power home his second.

Bogdan did not pay the penalty for yet more poor handling and not long afterwards Scott Dann's diving far-post header landed in the side-netting.

Martin Olsson needed treatment within seconds of the re-start after he was caught from behind by Miyaichi.

The full-back was able to continue, although as he was ushered back on to the field Miyaichi curled narrowly over for Bolton.

Wheater cleared after some slack play from Nigel Reo-Coker had almost put them in trouble and from the throw-in, Bogdan came to collect Nzonzi's back header.

Ngog was close to a third for Bolton at the other end as he rose to meet Petrov's inswinging cross.

Davies completely mis-kicked as he was presented with a shooting chance just outside the box.

And Bolton were made to pay as Bogdan failed to shift Yakubu from his line of vision until it was far too late as the hosts attempted to defend Morten Gamst Pedersen's corner and Nzonzi took advantage to nod home.

It was breathless stuff and Davies should have restored Bolton's two-goal cushion when Miyaichi picked him out from the right, completely unmarked, six yards out. Somehow though, he glanced the header wide.

Martin Olsson barged Steinsson off the ball by the corner flag but Hoilett let the pull-back run under his foot.

Bogdan needed treatment after taking a thud in the ribs from Yakubu.

In the meantime, David Dunn was introduced for Mauro Formica.

When play began again, Davies carved out an excellent opportunity for Petrov, but his shot nearly struck the corner flag it was so far wide.

Ivan Klasnic replaced Ngog 11 minutes from time as Petrov waited to take a corner which he eventually dropped on to Pratley's head. But he was off target too.

Yakubu bundled Hoilett's near-post cross just the wrong side of the post.

Blackburn were now looking to take advantage of Bolton's anxiety and Yakubu was not far away with a close-range header two minutes from time.

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS AVAILABLE FROM MONDAY
articles.teaser: DAVID WHEATER'S first-half double lifted Bolton out of the drop zone and halted Rovers' revival
articles.headline: Bolton 2 Blackburn 1
articles.subdeck: GRET IN THERE! ... Bolton hero David Wheater celebrates with Rafn Steinsson

article.caption: Sunderland 3 QPR 1

image.caption: X-RATED ... Djibril Cisse leaves Fraizer Campbell up in the air after two-footed lunge

articles.articlebody:
MARK HUGHES branded Djibril Cisse 'crazy' after the striker was sent off for the second time in four games.

The Frenchman saw red after an reckless challenge on Fraizer Campbell as QPR lost 3-1 at Sunderland.

Cisse will now miss half of the relagation run-in, with a four-game ban looming.

R's boss Hughes said: "That's going to hurt us because when we have been able to keep him on the pitch he has been excellent for us.

"He has scored something like three in five, but we can't really dwell on it.

"It's spilled milk from our point of view. We have got to get on with it. I have got to focus on the personnel who are available to me.

"It's a crazy challenge by Djibril, and he knows that. I wasn't too delighted.

"It obviously compromised us, but in fairness, even if he had still stayed on the pitch, I don't think we would have won this game because we didn't start in the right manner and didn't do the right things on enough occasions.

"If you don't do that at Premier League level, you lose, certainly at places like Sunderland."
articles.teaser: DJIBRIL CISSE will miss half of QPR's run-in after his second red card in four games
articles.headline: Hughes raps 'crazy' Cisse
articles.subdeck: X-RATED ... Djibril Cisse leaves Fraizer Campbell up in the air after two-footed lunge

image.caption: FRANKS FOR NOTHING ... Frank Lampard appeals in vain for a penalty
BLOCKED ... Ashley Cole gets in the way of Rafael van der Vaart's shot at the end of the first half
RAM RAID ... Ramires attempts to get past Tottenham's Luka Modric
WELSH WIZARD ... Gareth Bale attempts to get things going in a tame first half

article.caption: Terry not too bossy
He's Roberto Di Chatteo
It's Harry Redcap!

articles.articlebody:
CHELSEA missed the chance to move to within two points of Spurs in the race for the Champions League places after a stalemate at Stamford Bridge.

In a boring first half only Rafael van der Vaart came close to scoring but his double chance was saved by Petr Cech and then blocked by Ashley Cole.

Juan Mata hit the post with a free-kick after the break as the Blues pressed for a much-needed win.

But it was Tottenham who came closest to nicking victory through William Gallas, Emmanuel Adebayor and then Gareth Bale who crashed a header against the bar.

Bale again tested Cech with a dipping last-minute free-kick but it was to remain goalless  a result which suits Spurs more than the Blues.

Fernando Torres was back on the bench as Didier Drogba returned to the Chelsea starting line-up.

But that change did little to ignite a surprisingly cagey opening.

The hosts looked the more threatening but any danger was well snuffed out by a Spurs defence without skipper Ledley King.

Scott Parker was his usual industrious self while Sandro was providing an effective shield in an unusually advanced role.

But in what has been such an exciting Premier League season the opening half of this London derby was a bore.

Despite the Blues in desperate need for three points to close the gap on fourth-placed Spurs, both teams seemed too scared to lose.

Chelsea did have a half-hearted penalty appeal when Frank Lampard broke in the box and went tumbling under a challenge by WGallas but Martin Atkinson rightly waved play on.

And Stamford Bridge had to wait until first-half injury time for the first real goalmouth action as Bale played in a neat ball to Luka Modric.

His deflected pull back found Van der Vaart ten yards out but the ball fell awkwardly on the Dutchman's right foot and he struck straight at Cech.

Cole then reacted quickly to block Van der Vaart's follow up and as the ball looped in the air, Adebayor could only head on to the roof of the net.

Things livened up a tad immediately after the break and Daniel Sturridge should have done better after Drogba headed him clear but he dragged his left-footed strike wide.

At the other end, Kyle Walker had Cech worried with a fierce right-footed drive after a lovely reverse pass by Bale but his effort crashed into the side of the net.

Ramires was up in arms after a coming together with Benoit Assou-Ekotto but Atkinson was again right to ignore the weakest of penalty claims.

Both sides were beginning to press forward with more purpose without either seriously threatening to get an opening goal.

That was until Juan Mata stepped up with a beautiful curling free-kick which had Brad Friedel beaten but struck his left post and bounced clear.

Then Spurs  having hardly threatened all game  had three glorious chances which all went begging.

First William Gallas headed over with a free header from a teasing Modric free-kick.

Then Adebayor latched on to a Modric dink but he lost his balance after rounding Cech and Gary Cahill was back to clear his strike at an empty net.

The visitors were then cursing their luck as Bale crashed a header from a corner smack on to the bar and Adebayor again headed the rebound over.

Lampard tested his luck at the other end with a strike from distance as Chelsea ran out of ideas.

But it was Bale again who came closest with a last-minute free-kick which had Cech scrambling to save and secure at least a point for his side.

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS AVAILABLE FROM MONDAY
articles.teaser: CHELSEA missed the chance to move closer to the Champions League places after a stalemate at Stamford Bridge
articles.headline: Chelsea 0 Tottenham 0
articles.subdeck: FRANKS FOR NOTHING ... Frank Lampard appeals in vain for a penalty

image.caption: BOOTS YOU SIR ... Theo Walcott celebrates his goal
GIV HIM NO CHANCE ... Villa keeper given is beaten by Kieran Gibbs' opener
IT'S WAL OVER ... Theo Walcott doubles Arsenal's lead

article.caption: Wenger Wilshere warning
Stop the party
Big Eck's RVP KO

articles.articlebody:
KIERAN GIBBS, Theo Walcott and Mikel Arteta powered Arsenal three points clear in the race for third place with a SEVENTH straight Premier League win.

Gibbs clipped a 15th minute opener and Walcott fired inside the near post 10 minutes later as the Gunners profited from Tottenham's earlier 0-0 draw at Chelsea.

Then Arteta's superb stoppage-time free-kick confirmed Arsenal's dominance.

Central defender Laurent Koscielny suffered what was thought to be a knee injury in the warm-up so Johan Djourou came into the starting XI.

Koscielny's absence meant the break-up of a Gunners back four, also including Kieran Gibbs, Bacary Sagna and Thomas Vermaelen, which has never lost in the Premier League.

Before kick-off, there was applause as a banner of former Arsenal midfielder Fabrice Muamba was passed among supporters, the Bolton player now making good progress following his cardiac arrest last weekend.

Spurs' goalless draw at Chelsea meant Arsenal could strengthen their grip on the top three with another home victory.

There was an early stoppage when Djourou went down following a stray elbow from Heskey.

The Swiss international needed treatment for a bloody nose, but there was no action taken by Phil Dowd - much to the annoyance of Gunners boss Arsene Wenger.

It was Villa who created the first opening when Marc Albrighton charged down the right and into the Arsenal penalty area, only to stumble and fire the ball over the bar.

Arsenal were soon on the offensive, with Theo Walcott's shot blocked before right-back Bacary Sagna blasted the loose ball wide.

In the 15th minute, Stiliyan Petrov was cautioned for a late challenge on Mikel Arteta.

Arsenal were soon ahead, through an unlikely source.

Gervinho fed Gibbs into the left side of the Villa box, and the defender's low, angled drive squirmed under Shay Given's arm on 16 minutes for the England international's first Premier League goal.

Arsenal maintained momentum, with Walcott the main outlet down the right.

After 25 minutes, the England winger dispatched a magnificent effort to double Arsenal's lead.

Alex Song's chipped pass into the Villa box was taken in his stride on the run by Walcott, whose next touch was to calmly stroke the ball into the bottom corner.

The Gunners were rampant now, with Arteta's fierce drive from 20 yards tipped over by Given.

When Villa did get some respite on the break, their delivery into the Arsenal penalty area was poor.

Robin van Persie almost beat Given with a clever backward header from a high ball forward, but this time the Villa keeper was spot-on with his handling.

After 38 minutes, Stephen Warnock then denied the Dutchman with a desperate flying header on the line after more slick build-up from the hosts.

Villa had to come out positive for the second half, a tactic which left gaps at the back as Arsenal looked to capitalise on the counter attack.

The visitors made a change seven minutes in when Gary Gardner replaced Chris Herd.

Arsenal were awarded a free-kick some 25 yards out, left of the penalty arc, after Gardner tugged back Tomas Rosicky. Arteta struck his effort into the wall.

On the hour, a quick thrown out by Wojciech Szczesny sent away Czech midfielder Rosicky, who fed Gervinho down the left, but his cut-back from the byline flew across the six-yard box.

Rosicky was central to the action now, with Given beating away his 25-yard drive.

On 65 minutes, Heskey was replaced by Weimann.

Arsenal soon made a double change as Ramsey and full-back Andre Santos came on for Gervinho and Gibbs.

The Brazilian's first contribution on his return to action from a broken ankle was to give the ball away to Weimann, but the Austrian lost composure in the Arsenal box and fluffed his big chance, stabbing across goal and wide.

Ramsey made space for a shot on the turn from the edge of the penalty area, but was just wide.

With 13 minutes left, Walcott was replaced - to a standing ovation - by Oxlade-Chamberlain, while for Villa, Alan Hutton came off and Eric Lichaj went into the overworked defence.

Arsenal were screaming for a penalty when Oxlade-Chamberlain scampered away down the right and went down under a sliding challenge from Stephen Ireland, but referee Phil Dowd correctly ruled the midfielder had just got the ball first.

Arteta cracked home a 25-yard free-kick in stoppage time to round off a fine afternoon's work from Wenger's reborn side.

Arsenal: Szczesny, Sagna, Djourou, Vermaelen, Gibbs, Arteta, Song, Walcott, Rosicky, Gervinho, van Persie. Subs Fabianski, Andre Santos, Oxlade-Chamberlain, Ramsey, Jenkinson, Chamakh, Benayoun.

Aston Villa: Given, Hutton, Collins, Cuellar, Warnock, Petrov, Herd, Albrighton, Ireland, Heskey, Agbonlahor. Subs: Guzan, Bannan, Weimann, Lichaj, Baker, Gardner, Carruthers.

Referee: Phil Dowd (Staffordshire)

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS AVAILABLE FROM MONDAY
articles.teaser: KIERAN GIBBS, Theo Walcott and Mikel Arteta fired dominant Arsenal to a seventh straight win
articles.headline: Arsenal 3 Aston Villa 0
articles.subdeck: BOOTS YOU SIR ... Theo Walcott celebrates his goal

image.caption: TOP MAN ... Grant Holt lifts the ball over Wayne Hennessey before scoring his first
JARVIS ROCKER ... Matt Jarvis stuns Carrow Road by netting the opener

article.caption: Take heart from rival wins
Mick still in touch
Jamie groin groan
Jarvis: Terry is the man to keep us up

articles.articlebody:
GRANT HOLT saw red for Norwich - but still proved the main man as he sunk Wolves.

The striker netted twice after Matt Jarvis had given Wolves the lead.

But he was ordered off four minutes from time for a second booking.

But there was not enough time for Wolves to make their numerical advantage count and they now find themselves cut adrift at the foot of the table.

Wolves began brightly, Stephen Ward firing wide inside the first minute and John Ruddy forced into a smart stop to keep out Kevin Doyle's header from a Michael Kightly free-kick.

Recalled Wolves defender Roger Johnson had to be alert to block two goalbound efforts in quick succession before Simeon Jackson controlled a loose ball in the box and forced Wayne Hennessey into action.

Zak Whitbread's header for Norwich was cleared off the by Kightly before Jarvis gave Wolves the lead on 25 minutes.

Kightly, impressing on his return to the team, darted down the right flank and sent over a cross that was touched away from the Norwich defenders by Doyle for Jarvis to fire home low into the bottom right-hand corner.

However, Wolves showed a minute later why they had the worst defensive record in the league when Jackson played through Holt to equalise.

The 30-year-old latched on to the Canada international's ball and lifted it over the head of the onrushing Hennessey, before heading home from six yards.

Buoyed by his 13th goal of the campaign, Holt flashed wide a speculative effort moments later as Norwich again attacked with intent.

Wolves were forced to defend in numbers to keep the home side at bay and it looked like the only moment of note as half-time approached would be a tiff between team-mates Ruddy and Elliott Ward.

That all changed in the 45th minute, though, when Holt had a fierce shot superbly blocked by Stephen Ward and Wes Hoolahan's follow-up was handled in the box by Eggert Jonsson.

The former Hearts midfielder was booked for the incident and referee Mark Clattenburg awarded a penalty, which Holt duly dispatched.

Kyle Naughton began the second period in place of Simon Lappin for the hosts, who started the half in the same vein in which they ended the first.

Elliott Bennett and Jonny Howson had early shots blocked as City looked to extend their advantage, before Jackson lost his footing when through on goal.

Wolves were impressing in flashes and Steven Fletcher almost connected with a deflected Jarvis cross-shot, before Norwich returned to the attack.

Sebastien Bassong's last-ditch challenge prevented Holt heading in his hat-trick goal in the 60th minute and Howson came close with a fierce drive from the resulting corner.

Johnson was harshly booked for a challenge on Holt as Norwich continued to dictate play, with Whitbread shooting wide before Hennessey sprinted out of his box to prevent Jackson.

Wolves searched desperately for an equaliser as the clock wound down, with the hosts welcoming them on in the hope of catching them on the break.

Hennessey did well to save a stinging Howson effort in the 80th minute but that was the last chance of note as Norwich's defence held off Wolves late on.

The victory was their first in five attempts in the league but was tempered somewhat by Holt's late red card for a challenge on Kightly.

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS AVAILABLE FROM MONDAY
articles.teaser: GRANT HOLT saw red for Norwich - but still proved the main man as he sunk Wolves
articles.headline: Norwich 2 Wolves 1
articles.subdeck: TOP MAN ... Grant Holt lifts the ball over Wayne Hennessey before scoring his first

image.caption: GOT THE NOD ... Nicklas Bendtner heads Sunderland into a first-half lead
NO HOOPER ... Djibril Cisse ends QPR's chance of picking up a point by getting sent off
SHAKEY TIMES ... Martin O'Neill attempts to greet QPR boss Mark Hughes
SILLY CISSE ... Djibril regrets his two-footed lunge
SOT IT OUT ... Sunderland's Sotirios Kyrgiakos clashes with QPR's Bobby Zamora
BENCHED ... QPR midfielder Joey Barton
CLAWS OUT ... Black Cats' David Vaughan flies in at QPR's Adel Taarabt as Bobby Zamora looks on
THREESY DOES IT ... Stephane Sessegnon rolls in No 3
HEAD PREVAILS ... Nicklas Bendtner nods Sunderland ahead

article.caption: I'm not afraid to drop Joey
Hughes: Priority is Mackem that result count
Mac's on the money
Mackie start plea

articles.articlebody:
IF Djibil Cisse could use his head half as well as Nicklas Bendtner, Martin O'Neill's side would not have eased to such a comfortable win at the Stadium of Light.

The Dane had already nodded the Black Cats ahead before QPR - and former Sunderland - striker Cisse saw red for a daft lunge on Frazier Campbell.

James McClean doubled the lead in the second half, with Stephane Sessegnon adding a simple third before a howizter from Taye Taiwo at least gave the visitors some cheer.

QPR boss Mark Hughes axed Joey Barton to the bench after the midfielder was booed by his own fans during the midweek victory over Liverpool.

Sunderland manager Martin O'Neill brought back John O'Shea, Jack Colback and Sessegnon and the home side started confidently by dominating possession.

Midfielder Colback might have put them ahead twice within seconds with 15 minutes gone.

First, he saw his weak side-footed effort from Sessegnon's cross blocked by Taiwo, and then he sent a volley a yard wide after running on to McClean's knock-down.

O'Shea limped off before the half-hour to leave his participation in Tuesday night's FA Cup quarter-final replay against Everton in some doubt.

Craig Gardner managed to get himself into the path Adel Taarabt's goal-bound 40th-minute effort but it was the Black Cats who took the lead a minute later.

McClean was given time to cross from the left and Bendtner, who had pulled away from Anton Ferdinand, climbed high above Taiwo to head firmly past Paddy Kenny.

With 54 minutes gone, Sunderland were awarded a free-kick 25 yards out. Gardner blasted a shot past Kenny's despairing dive, only to see the ball clatter the underside of the bar and bounce clear.

However, within a minute Cisse was sent off for an ugly challenge on Campbell, his second red card since his arrival at Loftus Road in January.

Taarabt made way for Shaun Wright-Phillips on the hour as Hughes sought a way back into the game, but the home side continued to dominate.

It might have been all over within four minutes after Gardner's cross was allowed to travel across the six-yard box to McClean, but his shot was blocked superbly by Young.

The home side doubled their lead through on 69 minutes. McClean's first shot was blocked but he responded the fastest to fire the rebound into the net.

The game look wrapped up seven minutes later when a neat pass from David Vaughan set up Sessegnon, who rolled the ball under the advancing Kenny to make it 3-0.

After Bendtner had seen his header drop on to the roof of the visitors net, Taiwo gave the 10-men some cheer when he smashed a free-kick past Simon Mignolet.

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS AVAILABLE FROM MONDAY
articles.teaser: IT was hard to mask 10-man Rangers' woes after Nicklas Bendtner nodded the home side towards an easy win
articles.headline: Sunderland 3 QPR 1

image.caption: GROWING BAINES ... Everton left-back Leighton Baines celebrates his opener

article.caption: Get on with it, Royston
Moyes takes strain
Latest Everton team news
Everton 0 Arsenal 1
Nervous time for Rodwell

articles.articlebody:
LEIGHTON BAINES' spectacular free-kick helped Everton grab all three points from a tough trip to Swansea.

The England left-back curled home just before the hour to give the Toffees a surprise lead.

Brendan Rodgers' side dominated possession but were dead and buried when Nikica Jelavic wrapped up the points after 76 minutes.

The impressive win sees David Moyes' side leapfrog their hosts into ninth place in the table.

The first chance fell Swansea's way in the seventh minute after Gylfi Sigurdsson's pass had played in Danny Graham, but the striker could not get hold of his shot and it was easily held by Tim Howard.

As with most visitors to the Liberty Stadium this season, Everton were having to cope without the ball for long periods.

Wayne Routledge blazed a presentable chance over after Joe Allen's cushioned lay-off, while Phil Jagielka bravely cleared a dangerous Gylfi Sigurdsson cut-back seconds later.

Everton's first effort on goal came after 27 minutes as Jelavic headed wide from Baines' free-kick with Osman poised in a better position behind him.

But Swansea were soon back in control and Jagielka was again Everton's saviour as he blocked Sigurdsson's shot after the Iceland international had been picked out by Routledge.

Everton did manage to finish the half strongly, with Darron Gibson volleying high over the bar and Jelavic failing to make contact with a dangerous flick-on from Tim Cahill, although they needed another Jagielka intervention to deny Graham a tap-in at the far post.

The Toffees were almost gifted a goal within moments of the restart when Williams dallied and saw his clearance blocked by Osman, but Jelavic could not keep his subsequent effort down as he stretched for the loose ball.

And their strong start to the second half continued as Sigurdsson was forced into a sharp challenge to deny Steven Pienaar a shot on goal.

Swansea keeper Michel Vorm had been a virtual spectator but he was alert enough to beat away a fierce Gibson drive, with Cahill failing to connect as Jelavic helped the rebound back across goal.

But, having soaked up so much first-half pressure, the Toffees grabbed the lead just before the hour.

Baines stepped up to curl a left-footed free-kick into the right corner of the net after Williams had brought the England international down on the edge of the box.

As the hosts pressed forward they left themselves vulnerable to the counter and, after Pienaar had curled an effort wide, the South African teed up Jelavic, who fired horribly off target with just Vorm to beat.

The former Rangers striker then missed another fine chance as he failed to connect with Baines' cut-back, but he made no such mistake in the 76th minute as substitute Fellaini turned past Williams in the box to give the striker a tap in.

Vorm then made a fantastic scrambling save to deny substitute Denis Stracqualursi a third after more trickery from Pienaar, but by then the result was never in doubt.

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS AVAILABLE FROM MONDAY
articles.teaser: LEIGHTON BAINES' spectacular free-kick helped Everton grab all three points from a tough trip to Swansea

articles.articlebody:
ARSENE WENGER warns Jack Wilshere will not go to the Euro finals this summer unless he plays for Arsenal first.

Wilshere has not played a competitive game since England's 2-2 draw with Switzerland in June.

And Wenger reckons the midfielder, 20, is still at least five weeks away from his comeback after missing the entire season with an ankle injury.

The Gunners boss said: "If Jack has played some games before the end of the season then it's a possibility he could go to the Euros.

"If he has not played at all, then I don't think it's realistic.

"I will only intervene if I believe he is at risk medically.

"If all goes well he will be back in full training in three weeks and then another two weeks to get match fit. But that is not certain yet.

"His last scan was positive and if he has no more setbacks then I think he will play again this season.

"But we have gone for a very cautious attitude with him and we will not force him into training with any pain. So we might have to be slower than expected.

"I would rather him go to the Euros than the Olympics. The Olympics destroy the start of next season for us.

"His position today is that he is back working with the ball and that is a huge step because the work we do with a ball is always demanding."

If all goes well for Wilshere, who underwent an operation to repair a stress fracture of his ankle last September, he could be available for Arsenal's last three Premier League games against Stoke, Norwich and West Brom.

Newcastle 1 Norwich 0

articles.articlebody:
ALAN PARDEW has warned the Premier League rivals chasing his top Toon stars: Come and have a go if you think you're rich enough.

Chelsea have long been tracking Newcastle midfield warrior Cheick Tiote, while Tim Krul, Demba Ba and Yohan Cabaye are also attracting a lot of interest.

Boss Pards is happy for the big guns to be looking at his players  yet knows trying to actually sign them will be anything but straightforward.

He said: "Speculation is part of the game and I have no problem with that  but all of our best players are on long-term contracts here.

"Anyone who looks at this football club will know we are difficult sellers. Someone is going to have to pay a lot of money to take one of our players away  especially considering where we are right now and are having success."

Tiote signed a whopping 6½-year deal last season, while Dutch keeper Krul penned a new one earlier this month.

Cabaye arrived only last summer so the only worry is a big club activating a £7million release clause in striker Ba's current contract.

Pardew is aiming to keep his Euro push on track at West Brom tomorrow, before facing Liverpool and Swansea.

He added: "We have some really, really good players here.

"My focus is to ensure that they are focused. If we can get one win and something from the other two, or get a couple of wins, then we are really well set for the last six.

"If we do it, it's not just a great reward for the players but it will help attract players.

"I said last week, we must now focus on that, change our goals to focus on Europe."

Toon are sixth and just two points behind fifth-placed Chelsea.

If Pardew manages to lead Newcastle into the Europa League or better, the chance of clinging on to his best players will increase big time.

It will also change his sales pitch for any prospective new signings.

The Toon gaffer added: "Last summer was a rebuild job.

"We did not make the mistake of setting our ambitions or goals too high. I think players look at you and, if they raise an eyebrow, you might be lying to them for the rest of the season.

"They do not want to play for a manager or a club like that. So we were very realistic in our talks about our aims.

"We said we were going to attack the top 10 and hopefully get a top-half finish.

"As it turns out, with nine games to go we have 47 points, two more than the whole of last year.

"That would have given us a top-10 finish last year and we at that mark already.

"So the players have stepped up to the plate and now it is a question of where are we going to finish with nine games to go."

s.brenner@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: MAGPIES boss is happy his top players are wanted men  but all have a massive value
articles.headline: Pardew: My stars worth a for-Toon!

image.caption: VISITORS ... Nigel Reo-Coker and Darren Pratley arrive to see Muamba in hospital
FIGHT FOR LIFE ... Bolton skipper watches as medics try to save his friend
SECONDS FROM HELL ... Reo-Coker watches Muamba turn on style

article.caption: Owen: Muamba can inspire us
Keep Muamba in your prayers
Blatt's a miracle
McLeish: Marvel Muamba
Steve is Kean to be mean

articles.articlebody:
THEY were three words he had heard his pal say hundreds of times before.

But this time they left midfield hardman Nigel Reo-Coker close to tears and too choked to speak.

"All right, Nige?"

Only three days earlier, the Bolton star had feared he would never hear his Trotters team-mate Fabrice Muamba say that, or anything else, ever again.

Reo-Coker was the first player to reach fellow midfielder Muamba, 23, who suffered a cardiac arrest and collapsed 41 minutes into last Saturday's FA Cup quarter-final at White Hart Lane.

He watched in horror as doctors first battled in vain to restart Muamba's heart on the pitch and then hurried him off on a stretcher to a waiting ambulance and away for crucial emergency treatment.

Back in their dressing room, the distraught Bolton players thought their friend was dead.

And, effectively, he was  for 78 minutes.

So to see him, alive and lucid, in the London Chest Hospital was overwhelming... even for a tough South Londoner like Reo-Coker.

He said: "It was Tuesday morning and I went in to see him with Darren Pratley.

"When I walked in there I choked up. He said 'All right, Nige?' But obviously he was not speaking so well because he was still a bit drugged up."

Even now, an emotional Reo-Coker struggles to find the words to express his feelings.

He admitted: "For me just to see him after what I saw on the pitch and the news we got in the dressing room...

"When your heart is not beating for that long, simply to be alive and recognise anyone is a miracle.

"Fabrice added, 'What happened?' I just choked up in all honesty. I couldn't even answer him.

"Darren told him, 'You just collapsed. But don't worry about it. You're going to be OK'.

"I was probably only in with him for about a minute, maximum. In and out.

"But to see him lying there with all the tubes and everything, it was tough."

Tough, yes, though just seeing Muamba again at all was a massive relief.

Make no mistake, last weekend the Wanderers players were sure that they had lost him.

Reo-Coker revealed: "We got back into the dressing room and heard they had shocked him six times.

"I spoke to the doctor and Fabrice's heart wasn't beating. Loads of people would come to their own conclusion. I feared the worst. That's me being honest. So to see him there and for him to open his eyes and say 'All right, Nige?' that was more than enough.

"I was overjoyed just to see him, even though he's still in a serious situation."

Last Saturday seemed like any other match-day for Bolton manager Owen Coyle and his side, who were putting up a decent battle in the Cup tie and holding fancied Tottenham at 1-1.

A Gareth Bale own goal had given the visitors the lead after only six minutes, with Kyle Walker levelling for the Londoners five minutes later. There was all to play for.

Then, just after 6.10pm, everything changed and nobody will ever forget what happened next  least of all 27-year-old Reo-Coker.

He recalled: "There were no signs. Nothing. I remember shortly before it happened. I asked him, 'Do you want to swap positions? Do you want me to push on and you can do the deep role?' Fabrice just laughed and said 'No'.

"Then I remember him running back and collecting a half-clearance from one of our centre-backs.

"Next thing, I remember facing towards our right-back position and then I turned round and saw Fabrice on the floor.

"I thought maybe there had been a collision with a Tottenham player. But I realised there was no one close to him.

"He was shaking. I didn't know what it was.

"I thought that he might have been having a fit but I had not known him to have any fits or epilepsy. I didn't realise how serious it was until the physio got there and I tried to help him turn Fabrice over. That's when I realised it was serious."

More than 35,000 supporters looked on in disbelief as medics battled desperately to save Muamba.

Minutes later, back in the Bolton dressing room, there was a feeling of total devastation.

Reo-Coker declared: "It was very emotional. From the time he was on the pitch to being carried into the ambulance felt like a lifetime.

"We have a very young team and a lot of them were in tears. Young Ryo Miyaichi, everyone was in tears.

"There was nothing you could say to comfort each other. It was totally unexpected.

"One minute you're playing a game, the next Fabrice is lying there. No one saw it coming."

Reo-Coker has always been a natural leader. Wimbledon saw it when he was just 18 and appointed him their skipper.

He is currently wearing the armband for Wanderers in the absence of Kevin Davies, sidelined by a knee injury, so wanted to visit Muamba on behalf of the whole squad.

He reported back to them on Wednesday morning. He said: "I told the boys I'd seen Fabrice and had a conversation with him.

"It did feel like a weight had been lifted off their shoulders. They feel a lot happier now.

"To see the miraculous recovery  he recognises his team-mates and family, he is talking and, the most important thing, he is alive.

"It lifts a big burden off the players."

Today, Reo-Coker will try to find the right words to get the Bolton players' minds back on football and their crunch relegation derby with Blackburn at the Reebok.

That team talk really could not be in better hands.

He explained: "For me, this has been a life-changing experience. It just shows how precious life is. Personally, I am ready to go. I know I will be fine. I am just making sure the young players are ready.

"This is a big game, a six-pointer and for now we are going to play for Fabrice."
articles.teaser: REO-COKER was left close to tears at the words he had heard so many times before
articles.headline: He saw me and said: 'All right, Nige..?'
