article.caption: Pep won't take the Blues job... and Jose is the reason why
Losing is not an option for Blues boss Di Matteo
£40m net

articles.articlebody:
JOHN TERRY has rubbished speculation that he has a massive say in first-team affairs at Chelsea.

Blues captain Terry, 31, last week branded suggestions senior players ran the dressing room at Stamford Bridge as "complete nonsense."

But 24 hours later, during the Champions League win over Napoli, the England defender was barking orders from the bench alongside stand-in boss Roberto Di Matteo.

Terry said: "In response to comments suggesting that I think I'm the manager, I'd like to say Robbie has stepped up and been immense.

"I am Chelsea through and through, whether I am on the pitch or off it.

"Had I still been on the pitch, I would have been saying the same things that I was from the bench.

"That is my role as captain of this club.

"Just because I have come off the pitch, it doesn't mean to say my mentality changes.

"People might see it in the wrong way, but I care about this football club  we all do  and Robbie and his backroom staff deserve full credit."
articles.teaser: JOHN TERRY has rubbished speculation he has a massive say in first-team affairs
articles.headline: Terry not too bossy
articles.subdeck: HITTING BACK ... John Terry

image.caption: HE'S BEHIND YOU ... but Jose sits out front in La Liga race

article.caption: £40m net
Take it for Granted... RDM has little hope

articles.articlebody:
THERE is one man who will stop Pep Guardiola from quitting Barcelona this summer to join Chelsea.

I am not talking about Barca president Sandro Rosell, even though he will undoubtedly do everything in his power to try to keep his outstanding coach at the Nou Camp.

Nor am I referring to Chelsea's Roman Abramovich, whose reputation for ruthlessly axing bosses is bound to make any prospective new candidate, even Guardiola, think twice about filling what has become the hottest hotseat in football.

Both of these kingmakers will hope to exert their huge power and influence on Grandmaster Guardiola as he ponders his next big move.

But I reckon a Portuguese fella previously employed by both clubs will ultimately have the final say in whether the super successful Spaniard sticks or twists.

Jose Mourinho.

The Special One has long been accused of being the spectre hanging over a succession of Chelsea chiefs.

Avram Grant, Big Phil Scolari, Carlo Ancelotti and Andre Villas-Boas were all shown the door at Stamford Bridge arguably because they could not hold a candle to their predecessor. It is ironic then Mourinho could now scupper the appointment of Guardiola as the Blues' next boss. How? Let me explain...

Having spent four years at the helm of Barcelona, I can understand why Guardiola would be looking for a new job. He has already taken the Catalan giants to a different world in terms of football.

And he has won everything there is to win.

He is only 41 and he will need a new challenge in the not-too-distant future. A Premier League club would be the next obvious mountain.

But I also believe Guardiola would want to bow out at Barcelona at the top. Of Europe. Of the world. And, most importantly, of La Liga.

They are currently second to Mourinho's Real Madrid, who look on course to finish as champions. If that happens, I cannot see Guardiola turning his back on Barcelona, even if they beat their El Clasico rivals to win the Champions League.

Guardiola is a natural competitor as well as a super-natural coach. He'd surely not want to walk away after losing his La Liga crown.

It is a shame for Chelsea because I think Guardiola would be the perfect choice for them. Or any top club in Europe for that matter.

What he has achieved since being appointed as Barcelona coach in 2008 is phenomenal. Three successive La Liga titles, two Champions League crowns, two UEFA Super Cups and two FIFA Club World Cups tells the story of his reign.

He has not only turned Barca into the best football team on the planet.

He has altered the perception of the sport, showing you no longer have to spend a fortune or select six-foot sprinters to secure success. Under his stewardship, the Catalans have become the standard-bearers for the way the Beautiful Game should be played.

Look in the dictionary under football and it should simply read: Barcelona. If he were to take over at Chelsea, it would be a completely different job.

But that would be part of the attraction for him. He needs something different on his CV to display his attributes as a well-rounded coach.

I don't know whether he would want a year off first, but it would be interesting to see how he would build a new team at Chelsea  even a new culture  while still acquiring the results to keep him in employment.

Abramovich and his senior players might even have to change their philosophies to accommodate him.

Interim-manager Roberto Di Matteo is doing a great job, despite Wednesday's 2-1 defeat at Manchester City.

Of course, Guardiola would be Abramovich's first choice  but then he would be most of Europe's first choice.

I can see the Barca coach managing Chelsea one day. Just not yet. I do not think he would want to quit with Jose's hands on the Spanish title.
articles.teaser: TERRY VENABLES says Pep will not want to quit Barca with Jose's hands on La Liga title
articles.headline: Why Pep won't take Blues job
articles.subdeck: HE'S BEHIND YOU ... but Jose sits out front in La Liga race

image.caption: PACE MAKERS ... Lewis Hamilton, Jenson Button and Michael Schumacher
LEW CAN DO IT ... Lewis Hamilton celebrates his pole position

article.caption: Red Bull gives you whinge
Heat is on

articles.articlebody:
LEWIS HAMILTON again spearheaded an all-McLaren front row in qualifying for the Malaysian Grand Prix.

Hamilton made it two pole positions in a row, finishing 0.149secs ahead of team-mate Jenson Button as they repeated their one-two from Australia last week.

Michael Schumacher will start third in his Mercedes after putting in his best qualifying performance since his return to F1.

Mark Webber grabbed fourth in his Red Bull, again finishing ahead of team-mate and reigning world champion Sebastian Vettel who repeated his sixth place from Melbourne.

Vettel, however, will move up to fifth tomorrow as Kimi Raikkonen will drop five places to 10th after the gearbox in his Lotus was changed overnight.

The Ferrari's disappointed for the second week in a row. Fernando Alonso will start in eighth and Felipe Massa in 12th after the Brazilian again missed out on a place in the top 10.

After claiming the 21st pole of his career, and his first in Malaysia, Hamilton said: "It's been a good weekend so far.

"I don't know if it's definitely the best place to start  it's a long haul down to Turn One.

"It's been a tough day with the change in weather conditions and the temperatures climbing.

"But we made some changes to the car and we managed to do some good times."

Button, who leapfrogged Hamilton at the start in Melbourne and went on to win, said: "Qualifying has been pretty good for me in the last two races, so I can't complain too much.

"It's a one-two, although obviously I would want it the other way around."

Schumacher added: "We have managed to work the car well over the whole weekend so far.

"We're third here, which shows it's a very tight business, but we can be more than happy with what we've achieved."

image.caption: THIRST PLACE ... Jenson Button takes on fluids
FUEL ... Lucozade will help fire Button and Hamilton

video.caption: CHRIS HOCKLEY and Jim Munro preview the second race of the new F1 season

article.caption: Massa ready to get hot and steamy in Malaysia
Kimi stuck in the wrong gear
There's no Di Rest for the wicked
Red Bull gives you whinge

articles.articlebody:
JENSON BUTTON and Lewis Hamilton will guzzle scientific drinks to help them combat the searing heat at the Malaysian Grand Prix tomorrow.

The McLaren drivers are working with sports-drink manufacturers Lucozade to create individually tailored fluids to ensure they stay at their peak during the race.

Hamilton, 27, and Button, 32, will endure temperatures of over 50 degrees in the cockpit and expect to lose around half a stone in weight due to sweating.

The conditions make this race one of the most demanding in Formula One and Button is hoping the pioneering drinks, which are being used for the first time, help him stay in shape.

He said: "Hydration is extremely important. I know that only too well from a past experience during the Malaysian Grand Prix when my fluid bottle broke.

"It meant I couldn't take on any liquids during one of the hottest and most physically tough races on the calendar.

"By the end of the race, I was in pretty bad shape  which shows you that, without proper hydration, your performance and your abilities behind the wheel are severely compromised.

"This is one of the toughest races because it's dealing with the humidity more than anything else. When you get on to the straight you can't breathe.

"That's normally a rest for us when we just change gears and play around with a few switches. But here you don't get that luxury as you can't breathe!

"The air coming into the car is so hot that it is very difficult to deal with it."

The weather here in Malaysia is so hot that Scottish driver Paul Di Resta joked that it is 'cruel' for the locals to live here.

The Force India ace added: "Physically this is the toughest race of the year. Every time I come back, I cannot imagine how people can live here. It's cruel. It's a true test to show how fit you are. It's probably about 16 degrees hotter in the cockpit than outside.

"The surfaces are hotter, too, as you have various electrical components in the car. You can't wear a cool suit either, because you couldn't fit into the car wearing it."

But even though both drivers admit this race will test them, Button insists they are all fit enough to cope.

After the shocking scenes at White Hart Lane last week when Bolton's Fabrice Muamba suffered a cardiac arrest, Button is hopeful that nothing like that will happen in F1.

He said: "We all have a medical test for our licences. That is the only thing we're obligated to do  but most of us do a lot of fitness to keep in pretty good shape.

"It's very different for a footballer. We're obviously racing for quite a long time and it's more about endurance. For them, there's a lot of sprinting, it's very peaky in terms of heart rate.

"A lot of people do physical activity outside to get used to the humidity because it's such a shock for a lot of people who haven't been here before.

"Jean-Eric Vergne and a few of the others haven't been here before  and it's a real shock walking out. It hits you when you walk out of the airport."

  • LUCOZADE are proud to fuel the Vodafone McLaren-Mercedes Team. For more information, visit www.lucozade.com/perform/formula-one/
articles.byline: From BEN HUNT in Kuala Lumpur
articles.teaser: THE Brit insists the heat is so extreme at the Sepang Circuit that you CANNOT BREATHE
articles.headline: Heat is on
articles.subdeck: THIRST PLACE ... Jenson Button takes on fluids

image.caption: HOT STREAK ... Pietersen uses an ice pack to cool down in Sri Lanka yesterday

article.caption: Ravi injury rocks England plans
Prior smashes England to strong win

articles.articlebody:
KEVIN PIETERSEN says anybody found guilty of match-fixing should be banned for life.

The England star insists the trio of corrupt Pakistan players should be finished because they betrayed the game and let down the fans.

He was speaking after teenage bowler Mohammad Amir this week claimed money was not the reason he deliberately bowled no-balls at Lord's in 2010.

Amir said he was conned and manipulated by former skipper Salman Butt and his agent Mazhar Majeed.

Butt, Majeed and speedster Mohammad Asif remain in prison while Amir was released from a young offenders' institute last month.

The three players are also serving five-year ICC bans.

Pietersen said: "A lot of people fell out of love with the game because of what a few had done. Anybody who gets caught needs to be finished.

"I love the game so much and to play in that fixture, to see what they did, is inexcusable.

"They have been caught, they should serve their time in a very big way because the game of cricket was dented."

Pietersen goes into Monday's First Test against Sri Lanka here insisting he has recaptured his magic formula.

Even soaring temperatures  which KP describes as a 'nightmare'  will not melt his drive to score a first ton on the island.

Pietersen scored back-to-back hundreds in the ODIs against Pakistan in February and has looked imperious ever since.

It all came down to a moment of enlightenment in a practice stint with England coach Mushtaq Ahmed.

KP explained: "I found it tough to hold on to my good form of last summer but then it clicked. I looked at Mushy, he looked at me, and it was like, 'We're back'.

"It can happen with just one ball. It's timing, picking the ball and judging the length. The best players pick length the quickest.

"Guys like Sachin pick length as soon as the ball is delivered. I pick it quicker than Jimmy Anderson will. Hence Jimmy gets hit all over the place and bats number 10 or 11. I could get nought and nought in Galle. But the likelihood is, I'm in a position to score some runs."

While KP has been transformed, Ian Bell continues to struggle and has scored just 136 runs in 15 innings.

But Pietersen said: "Bell averaged more than 100 last year.

"We're all around him, buzzing for him, he is one of the most beautiful batters to watch.

"He's world-class and there's nobody who can come in and bat like Ian Bell."

Pietersen, 31, is in hot form  much like the weather here.

He added: "This is as hot as I've been on a cricket field. It's a joke. It makes it harder to concentrate. You feel lethargic.

"I batted for 90 minutes and changed gloves four times.This is a challenge as I batted like a plonker last time here.

"I have home and away tons against every country except Sri Lanka and South Africa. That's one of my goals."
articles.teaser: KP insists the trio of Pakistan cheats should be finished as they betrayed the game
articles.headline: Ban 'em for life
articles.subdeck: HOT STREAK ... Pietersen uses an ice pack to cool down in Sri Lanka yesterday
